The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said firefighters are working to save \"as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others\".\n\nA few hours earlier, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\nJasper is being threatened by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents - along with 20,000 park visitors - fled on short notice late on Monday when the fires flared up.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said officials are \"mobilising every necessary resource available\". Alberta premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken\".\n\nA record number of wildfires last year forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the US, leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple US cities.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted three miles from Jasper earlier in the day. The southern fire had been reported five miles away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts sent it racing.\n\nShe said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed, crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards could not complete the work before having to pull out, and water bombers could not help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions\".\n\nThe hope was that rain forecast overnight would bring some relief.\n\nMs Ellsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly\".\n\nShe said: \"Given the intensity of fire behaviour being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"Jasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies a World Heritage Site in 1984 for the striking mountain landscape.\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie River Of No Return. More recently, TV show The Bachelorette was filmed there.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier on Wednesday looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away.\n\nSearchers looking through the remote trails of Jasper National Park had already picked up 245 people, and they continued the search on Wednesday in two helicopters, Ms Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late on Monday and Tuesday, and officials said on Wednesday that the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nMs Ellsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later on Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea where people are, but Ms Ellsworth said she was not sure how many people were left.\n\nAlberta has been baking in scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. {"uri": "8242512789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:52:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:52:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T06:52:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/c505420203b5fdba2bcf07e8b7f00d90/wildfire-burns-structures-town-canadian-rockies-largest", "title": "Wildfire burns structures in a town in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park", "body": "GRAND PRAIRIE, Alberta (AP) -- One of two raging wildfires menacing the town of Jasper in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park roared into town Wednesday and began burning buildings.\n\nJasper National Park officials said the fire entered the southern edge of the community Wednesday evening and crews were battling multiple structural fires and working to protect key infrastructure.\n\nForest firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses were told to evacuate to the nearby town of Hinton, with structural firefighters staying behind.\n\nParks Canada spokesperson James Eastham told reporters outside Jasper that the town is filled with smoke and there \"has been structural loss.\"\n\n\"At this point I can't confirm how many, locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said firefighters are working to save \"as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\nJasper is being menaced by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 more park visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said they are \"mobilizing every necessary resource available.\" Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken.\"\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted 5 kilometers (about 3 miles) from Jasper earlier in the day. The southern fire had been reported 8 kilometers (about 5 miles) away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong did go wrong as fire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed. Crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety. Water bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavorable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that rain forecast overnight would bring some relief.\n\nEllsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly.\"\n\nShe said, \"Given the intensity of fire behavior being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelorette\" was filmed there.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier Wednesday, looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away. Searchers looking through the backcountry trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people, and they continued the search Wednesday in two helicopters, Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late Monday and Tuesday, and officials said Wednesday the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nEllsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 177 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation center following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\n\"We're just waiting to go back home and see how many days we're going to be stuck here,\" Joyeuse said.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", {"uri": "8243520990", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:14:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:14:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:13:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Canada/498597/Alberta-premier-fights-back-tears-promises-help-as-Jasper-devastated-by-fire", "title": "Alberta premier fights back tears, promises help as Jasper devastated by fire - Canada News", "body": "UPDATE 11:10 a.m.\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith fought back tears Thursday as she sought to console Jasper residents coming to terms with a community devastated by wildfire.\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said at a fire update in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nSpecifics on what has been destroyed in the Rocky Mountain resort town of 5,000 remained sketchy.\n\nJasper Park officials, in a statement, said the firefighting situation remains dynamic.\n\nPhotos shared on social media Wednesday night depicted Jasper structures wrapped in sheets of flame.\n\nA video Thursday morning showed rain-slicked streets, cloudy skies and a wide swath of blackened, charred homes and buildings razed to their foundations.\n\n\"The images we're seeing out of Jasper are devastating,\" said Forestry Minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way.\n\nCalgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park, said they were sending resources to the fire scene.\n\nThe staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nIn Hinton Thursday morning, rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, urged them to stay strong.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Ireland wrote.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nPhoto: Woodlands County\n\nUPDATE 10:20 a.m.\n\nIn an update Thursday morning, Jasper National Park says there have been no reported injuries due to the wildfire that swept through Jasper fire overnight, and about 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town and national park.\n\n\"All residents, visitors and responders are safe,\" the park posted to social media.\n\nAdditionally, the region received a \"small amount of rain\" overnight, which has \"helped reduce fire activity slightly.\" But park officials say it hasn't made meaningful impact on the overall fire situation.\n\n\"Significant structural firefighting reinforcements arrived throughout the night and have continued to assist with firefighting efforts in the community overnight and this morning,\" the update reads.\n\n\"We are thankful to all of our partners and municipal fire agencies who have sent resources to help protect our community and national park. We also wish to acknowledge and thank all the communities who have received everyone who has been displaced by this fire.\"\n\nNo information has been released about the extent of the damage or specific locations in the town that have been hit by the fire.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures. We appreciate your patience and the community of people who have come together to support the people of Jasper and Parks Canada family.\"\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith is speaking Thursday morning about the situation in Jasper. She'll be joined by officials from Alberta Wildfire.\n\nUPDATE 9:05 a.m.\n\nAlberta's Jasper National Park and its townsite are under siege from two wind-whipped wildfires, one of which raced into the picturesque community on Wednesday night, causing extensive damage.\n\nParks Canada says the fire has caused significant losses within the town, and the social media account for Fairmont's famous Jasper Park Lodge says the flames had reached the hotel's grounds.\n\nAs the fire consumed more fuel, officials said the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to flee to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nPhotos on social media show lodges and other buildings wrapped in sheets of orange flame and devastation the following day.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance. Alberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked for help from the Canadian military.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nEarlier in the day, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThe fires are burning on the north and south sides of the town, which is home to 5,000 people. The residents have left, along with 20,000 park visitors.\n\nThe order to leave was issued around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to Jasper. Residents and visitors fled west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight procession through swirling smoke and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make the long drive around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday. The southern fire was farther away, but Parks Canada says strong winds sent it racing toward the town.\n\nThat forced crews using heavy equipment to pull back for safety. Water bombers were grounded due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled arriving in Jasper from Edmonton only to be told to get out.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" the 24-year-old said in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said she went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nPhoto: Contributed Jasper's Maligne Lodge on fire\n\nORIGINAL 5:35 a.m.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance after a fast-moving wildfire hit Jasper National Park and its townsite late Wednesday.\n\nThe park's social media account says the fire has caused significant loss within the townsite, but the specific locations or neighbourhoods affected are not being reported.\n\nOn the social media platform X, the account for Fairmont's Jasper Park Lodge says the flames have reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, is not yet known.\n\nAs the flames consumed more fuel, officials say the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to evacuate to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nStructural firefighters stayed behind in the Alberta mountain town in an effort to protect key infrastructure.\n\nPhoto: Kenneth Smith/Banff-Canmore Visitors\n\nEarlier, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith issued a statement on Facebook, saying her thoughts are with the evacuees and those still fighting the fire.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jasper_National_Park", "type": {"uri": "8243471924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:31:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:31:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:30:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Canada/498597/Significant-loss-from-wildfire-within-Jasper-no-injuries-reported", "title": "Significant loss from wildfire within Jasper, no injuries reported - Canada News", "body": "UPDATE 10:20 a.m.\n\nIn an update Thursday morning, Jasper National Park says there have been no reported injuries due to the wildfire that swept through Jasper fire overnight, and about 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town and national park.\n\n\"All residents, visitors and responders are safe,\" the park posted to social media.\n\nAdditionally, the region received a \"small amount of rain\" overnight, which has \"helped reduce fire activity slightly.\" But park officials say it hasn't made meaningful impact on the overall fire situation.\n\n\"Significant structural firefighting reinforcements arrived throughout the night and have continued to assist with firefighting efforts in the community overnight and this morning,\" the update reads.\n\n\"We are thankful to all of our partners and municipal fire agencies who have sent resources to help protect our community and national park. We also wish to acknowledge and thank all the communities who have received everyone who has been displaced by this fire.\"\n\nNo information has been released about the extent of the damage or specific locations in the town that have been hit by the fire.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures. We appreciate your patience and the community of people who have come together to support the people of Jasper and Parks Canada family.\"\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith is speaking Thursday morning about the situation in Jasper. She'll be joined by officials from Alberta Wildfire.\n\nUPDATE 9:05 a.m.\n\nAlberta's Jasper National Park and its townsite are under siege from two wind-whipped wildfires, one of which raced into the picturesque community on Wednesday night, causing extensive damage.\n\nParks Canada says the fire has caused significant losses within the town, and the social media account for Fairmont's famous Jasper Park Lodge says the flames had reached the hotel's grounds.\n\nAs the fire consumed more fuel, officials said the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to flee to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nPhotos on social media show lodges and other buildings wrapped in sheets of orange flame and devastation the following day.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance. Alberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked for help from the Canadian military.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nEarlier in the day, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThe fires are burning on the north and south sides of the town, which is home to 5,000 people. The residents have left, along with 20,000 park visitors.\n\nThe order to leave was issued around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to Jasper. Residents and visitors fled west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight procession through swirling smoke and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make the long drive around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday. The southern fire was farther away, but Parks Canada says strong winds sent it racing toward the town.\n\nThat forced crews using heavy equipment to pull back for safety. Water bombers were grounded due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled arriving in Jasper from Edmonton only to be told to get out.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" the 24-year-old said in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said she went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nPhoto: Contributed Jasper's Maligne Lodge on fire\n\nORIGINAL 5:35 a.m.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance after a fast-moving wildfire hit Jasper National Park and its townsite late Wednesday.\n\nThe park's social media account says the fire has caused significant loss within the townsite, but the specific locations or neighbourhoods affected are not being reported.\n\nOn the social media platform X, the account for Fairmont's Jasper Park Lodge says the flames have reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, is not yet known.\n\nAs the flames consumed more fuel, officials say the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to evacuate to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nStructural firefighters stayed behind in the Alberta mountain town in an effort to protect key infrastructure.\n\nPhoto: Kenneth Smith/Banff-Canmore Visitors\n\nEarlier, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith issued a statement on Facebook, saying her thoughts are with the evacuees and those still {"uri": "8243575188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:06:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:06:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:05:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://wfin.com/fox-world-news/thousands-flee-canadas-jasper-national-park-as-wildfire-spreads-to-town/", "title": "Thousands flee Canada's Jasper National Park as wildfire spreads to town - WFIN Local News", "body": "One of the two wildfires flanking the town of Jasper in the Canadian Rockies' Jasper National Park has breached the town and spread to buildings.The town's 5,000 residents and 20,000 more park visitors fled on short notice late Monday night when the fires flared up.Firefighters faced myriad challenges as bucketing efforts by helicopter proved ineffective and conditions were too dangerous for water bombers to fly. Crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete their work in time and controlled burns failed.\n\nOne of two raging wildfires menacing the town of Jasper in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park roared into town Wednesday and began burning buildings.\n\nJasper National Park officials said the fire entered the southern edge of the community Wednesday evening and crews were battling multiple structural fires and working to protect key infrastructure. There were significant losses in some areas, they said.\n\nForest firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses were told to evacuate to the nearby town of Hinton, with structural firefighters staying behind.\n\nFBI OFFERING $10,000 REWARD FOR INFO LEADING TO ARREST OF SUSPECTS IN DEADLY NEW MEXICO WILDFIRES\n\nParks Canada spokesperson James Eastham told reporters outside Jasper that the town is filled with smoke and there \"has been structural loss.\"\n\n\"At this point I can't confirm how many, locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said firefighters are working to save \"as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\nJasper is being menaced by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 more park visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said they are \"mobilizing every necessary resource available.\" Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken.\"\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted about 3 miles from Jasper earlier in the day. The southern fire had been reported about 5 miles away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong did go wrong as fire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed. Crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety. Water bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavorable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that rain forecast overnight would bring some relief.\n\nEllsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly.\"\n\nShe said, \"Given the intensity of fire behavior being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelorette\" was filmed there.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier Wednesday, looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away. Searchers looking through the backcountry trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people, and they continued the search Wednesday in two helicopters, Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late Monday and Tuesday, and officials said Wednesday the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nEllsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 177 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation center following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\n\"We're just waiting to go back home and see how many days we're going to be stuck here,\" Joyeuse said.", "source": {"uri": "wfin.com", {"uri": "8243644469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:14:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:14:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:14:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/25/nx-s1-5052037/jasper-alberta-canada-wildfire", "title": "In the Canadian Rockies, a fast-moving wildfire ravages the resort town of Jasper", "body": "GRANDE PRAIRIE, Alberta -- A fast-moving wildfire in the Canadian Rockies that had prompted 25,000 people to flee roared into the near-deserted town of Jasper overnight as a \"wall of fire,\" devastating up to half the structures in the picturesque resort, officials said Thursday.\n\nThere were no immediate reports of injuries, following a mass evacuation of the town and a neighboring national park earlier in the week, but Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland said in a letter on the town's website that the wildfire \"ravaged our beloved community.\"\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension, my deepest sympathies go out to each of you,\" he said. He said he was writing with \"profound sorrow as we being to come to terms with the devastating impact.\"\n\nDanielle Smith, the premier of Alberta province, said from 30% to 50% of the town's structures are potentially damaged. \"We don't know which structures have been damaged and which ones are destroyed, but that's going to be a significant rebuild and significant displacement,\" Smith said.\n\nSmith teared up talking about the beauty of Jasper, noting that many families from the province regularly visit.\n\nA postcard-perfect mountain town, Jasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all who live in town,\" Smith said at a news conference in Edmonton, Alberta. \"Alberta's government will provide the support needed to families and communities to recover and rebuild.\"\n\nJasper and the neighboring Jasper National Park had been menaced by fires from both the north and south, and the town's 5,000 full-time residents -- along with 20,000 visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday and Tuesday when the fires flared up. One of the fires entered the southern edge of the community Wednesday evening.\n\nAlberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis said a wind gust moved the wildfire about 5 kilometers (about 3 miles) in probably less than 30 minutes toward the town with a wall of fire that he estimated was 100 meters high.\n\n\"People need to picture what those wildfire folks were experiencing at that time. Any firefighter will tell you there is little to nothing you can do when a wall of fire like that is coming at you,\" Ellis said. \"Nobody anticipated the fire to come so fast, so large.\"\n\nParks Canada said in a post on X that there had been \"no reported injuries as the result of the Jasper Complex Wildfire. Approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town of Jasper and Jasper National Park. All residents, visitors and responders are safe.\"\n\nPark officials said efforts to fight the fire were continuing and that it was not immediately possible to give details of the damage. They asked for patience, and said that the fire remains out of control despite a small amount of rain that fell overnight.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said his administration has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance, including military resources.\n\nOn X, the account for the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge said the flames had reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, wasn't immediately known.\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 176 wildfires were burning across the province, including 54 that are burning out of control.\n\nAlberta Forestry and Parks Minister Todd Loewen said many of the fires are caused by lightning, and Alberta Wildfire spokesperson Christie Tucker said firefighters expect winds will raise the danger.\n\nTucker said hundreds firefighters from Australia, Mexico, New Zealand and South Africa are arriving to help fight the wildfires throughout the province.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "NPR"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243624759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:55:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:55:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:55:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10643218/jasper-wildfire-timeline/", "title": "Jasper wildfire: Here's how quickly flames engulfed a town  | Globalnews.ca", "body": "It took less than two days for fast-moving wildfires to reach the Alberta Rocky Mountain town of Jasper, where multiple structures were burned Wednesday night.\n\nParks Canada first reported two wildfires burning within Jasper National Park -- one north of the townsite, the other south -- late Monday night. Before the night was over, the entire town and park was ordered to evacuate as crews struggled to combat the flames being whipped by high winds and dry conditions.\n\nAbout 25,000 people were evacuated from the park, including roughly 5,000 residents of the town.\n\nBy Wednesday evening, both wildfires had encroached on the town.\n\nHere's a timeline of how the situation unfolded. All times are local.\n\n7 p.m.: The first wildfire burning to the northeast of the town of Jasper is reported to Parks Canada. A second fire to the south is reported shortly after.\n\n8:35 p.m.: The Municipality of Jasper and Jasper National Park issue a \"preventative\" evacuation alert, warning of \"multiple wildfires\" burning in the park.\n\n10 p.m.: A wildfire alert and evacuation order are issued for Jasper National Park, including the townsite, for the wildfire south of town. An updated alert incorrectly states the fire is expected to reach the town in five hours, but is corrected nearly an hour later to say the area should be evacuated within that time.\n\nEvacuees are forced to travel west into British Columbia, then turn around and head to reception centres set up in Calgary, Edmonton and Grande Prairie. Parks Canada later says \"thousands\" of people evacuated overnight, facing \"wall-to-wall\" traffic on Highway 16.\n\n10 a.m.: Alberta Public Safety and Emergency Services Minister Mike Ellis says during a provincial wildfire update that the fire burning south of Jasper is about 12 km from the town on both sides of the Athabasca River. He warned wind \"may exacerbate the situation.\"\n\n4:30 p.m.: Parks Canada says evacuation of the Municipality of Jasper is complete, \"and the evacuation of hikers in the backcountry is ongoing.\" Campsites within the park boundary are also being cleared.\n\n6 p.m.: Fire officials with Parks Canada say the \"north wildfire\" is estimated to be at least 270 hectares in size, burning between the Jasper transfer station and the Jasper air strip, on both sides of Highway 16.\n\nThe \"south wildfire\" is estimated to be 6,750 hectares in size and is burning further away from the town, down the Icefields Parkway.\n\nParks Canada incident commander Katie Ellsworth says during a media briefing that heavy smoke is making it difficult to properly assess the size of the fires. She says crews are using aerial suppression efforts, including water bucketing from helicopters, as well as ground water lines and other measures to try and control the flames.\n\n11:10 a.m.: Ellsworth with Parks Canada says the size of the southern fire is now estimated to have grown 60 per cent overnight to 10,800 hectares, and is about eight km from the town of Jasper. The north wildfire is five km from the town and remains at roughly 270 hectares in size.\n\nShe says the \"aggressive fire behaviour\" seen throughout Tuesday continued overnight, with consistently high and gusty winds that are expected to last through Wednesday and further grow both fires. Crews are installing high-pressure sprinkler lines in key areas and continuing suppression efforts.\n\nEllsworth notes crews are already preparing for the possibility of fire reaching the town. Some structures outside the town have already been impacted.\n\n1 p.m.: Parks Canada says evacuations in the backcountry are ongoing but have been completed in \"high priority areas.\" The frontcountry areas of Jasper National Park have also been fully evacuated.\n\n4:20 p.m.: Ellis, the provincial public safety and emergencies minister, says Alberta has asked the federal government for assistance, including resources from the Canadian Armed Forces.\n\n5:30 p.m.: First responders working in Jasper National Park will be relocated to the nearby town of Hinton, Alta., about 50 km away, due to \"significant fire activity and forecasted strong winds,\" Parks Canada says. Firefighting personnel, aircraft and a reduced incident command staff remain in Jasper to try and protect the town.\n\n6 p.m.: Portions of the south wildfire reach the outskirts of the town of Jasper. Parks Canada says suppression efforts by helicopter bucketing \"proved ineffective,\" and water bombers could not assist due to dangerous flying conditions. Conditions also prevented other fire control efforts.\n\n6:40 p.m.: Parks Canada says \"wildfire reached the Jasper townsite.\"\n\n7:20 p.m.: Global News receives a picture of what's later confirmed to be the Maligne Lodge, a hotel at the southwest end of town operated since 1961, completely engulfed in flames. The family operators of the hotel later confirm it was destroyed.\n\n8:30 p.m.: Parks Canada says wildland firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses are being evacuated to Hinton due to deteriorating air quality. Structural firefighters remain in town to try and protect critical infrastructure and save as many structures as possible.\n\n9:30 p.m. Fairmont Hotels and Resorts confirms to Global News that the fire reached the grounds of the historic Jasper Park Lodge, one of the most-well known and storied resorts in the area.\n\n10 p.m.: In its final update of the night, Parks Canada says \"significant loss has occurred within the townsite.\" Fire information officer James Eastham tells Global News crews witnessed \"300- to 400-foot flames\" that swept into town at a rate of 15 metres per minute.\n\n10:30 p.m.: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau says his government has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance, and will deploy military resources and other emergency supports \"immediately.\"\n\n\"Alberta, we're with you,\" Trudeau says on social media.\n\n10:30 a.m.: Parks Canada says despite a small amount of rain overnight, the Jasper wildfire remains out of control. Officials add that \"significant structural firefighting reinforcements arrived throughout the night and have continued to assist with firefighting efforts.\"\n\nConditions on the ground are making it impossible for crews to provide details about the status of specific buildings and sites, Parks Canada adds, as the focus remains on the \"response effort.\"\n\nImages shared with Global News show a wide swath of blackened, charred homes and buildings razed to their foundations.\n\n12 p.m.: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith tells reporters at an emotional news conference that initial estimates are between 30 to 50 per cent of structures within Jasper townsite were destroyed overnight. She said the town faces a \"significant rebuild.\"", "source": {"uri": "globalnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Global News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://globalnews.ca/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/Jasper-wildfire-wednesday-july-24-3.jpg?quality=85&strip=all&w=720&h=379&crop=1", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9760758", "eventUri": "eng-9760758", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.0980392156862745, "wgt": 199, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243810281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:31:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:31:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:31:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Canada/498597/Despite-significant-damage-Jasper-s-critical-infrastructure-was-saved-during-overnight-wildfire", "title": "Despite significant damage, Jasper's critical infrastructure was saved during overnight wildfire - Canada News", "body": "Photo: Woodlands County\n\nUPDATE: 4:20 p.m.\n\nWhile Jasper has suffered significant damage during the overnight wildfire that swept through the town, all \"critical infrastructure\" has been saved.\n\nIn a post to social media, Jasper National Park says Jasper's hospital, emergency services building, both elementary and junior/senior schools, activity centre and wastewater treatment plant were successfully protected during last night's fire fight.\n\n\"Structural fire protection units are still fighting fires within the town and continue to fight fires moving from one building to another,\" Jasper National Park says.\n\n\"Although more time is needed to complete a detailed damage assessment, it is clear that some homes and businesses have been lost.\n\n\"The most significant structural damage is concentrated on the west side of town, southwest of Miette Avenue. Firefighting efforts have prevented significant damage to much of the infrastructure in the east end of town. Our priority remains protecting structures that have not yet been impacted by fire.\"\n\nAdditionally, a number of bridges in the town and through the national park have been damaged, including the Moberly Bridge and the Old Fort Point Bridge.\n\nWinds in Jasper whipped up to 100 km/h Wednesday, forcing the spread of the fires that were north and south of the town, causing their eventual merging.\n\n\"With today's rain and cooler temperatures, fire activity is significantly subdued. However, it is important to note that the fire is still out of control and significant work remains before conditions are safe enough to allow for limited re-entry into the park,\" the park says in its recent update.\n\n\"Crews are taking advantage of today's conditions to make progress on containing the fire and the community, before conditions return to hot and dry.\"\n\nCanada Task Force 2 of the Canadian Armed Forces has now arrived in Jasper to assist in the response to the fire and with the town's eventual recovery.\n\nJasper National Park says they'll provide another update on the situation by 10 p.m. local time.\n\nUPDATE: 12 p.m.\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith says early reports indicate a third and perhaps up to half of all buildings in the historic Rocky Mountain resort town of Jasper have been destroyed in a wildfire.\n\nSmith says she's waiting for specifics but says there is no doubt the town is in for what she calls a \"significant rebuild.\"\n\nSmith made the comments after fighting back tears at a news conference as she sought to console residents who were evacuated from the townsite and now face significant hardship when they return.\n\nImages on social media depict blocks of homes and businesses burned to charred foundations, and vehicles torched to their hubcaps.\n\nParks Canada says it will provide details when it can but says crews continue to battle a swift and dynamic fire in Jasper National Park.\n\nAbout 20,000 park visitors and the 5,000 residents of Jasper had to flee on a moment's notice Monday night ahead of two wildfires.\n\nUPDATE: 11:10 a.m.\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith fought back tears Thursday as she sought to console Jasper residents coming to terms with a community devastated by wildfire.\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said at a fire update in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nSpecifics on what has been destroyed in the Rocky Mountain resort town of 5,000 remained sketchy.\n\nJasper Park officials, in a statement, said the firefighting situation remains dynamic.\n\nPhotos shared on social media Wednesday night depicted Jasper structures wrapped in sheets of flame.\n\nA video Thursday morning showed rain-slicked streets, cloudy skies and a wide swath of blackened, charred homes and buildings razed to their foundations.\n\n\"The images we're seeing out of Jasper are devastating,\" said Forestry Minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way.\n\nCalgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park, said they were sending resources to the fire scene.\n\nThe staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nIn Hinton Thursday morning, rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, urged them to stay strong.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Ireland wrote.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nPhoto: Woodlands County\n\nUPDATE 10:20 a.m.\n\nIn an update Thursday morning, Jasper National Park says there have been no reported injuries due to the wildfire that swept through Jasper fire overnight, and about 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town and national park.\n\n\"All residents, visitors and responders are safe,\" the park posted to social media.\n\nAdditionally, the region received a \"small amount of rain\" overnight, which has \"helped reduce fire activity slightly.\" But park officials say it hasn't made meaningful impact on the overall fire situation.\n\n\"Significant structural firefighting reinforcements arrived throughout the night and have continued to assist with firefighting efforts in the community overnight and this morning,\" the update reads.\n\n\"We are thankful to all of our partners and municipal fire agencies who have sent resources to help protect our community and national park. We also wish to acknowledge and thank all the communities who have received everyone who has been displaced by this fire.\"\n\nNo information has been released about the extent of the damage or specific locations in the town that have been hit by the fire.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures. We appreciate your patience and the community of people who have come together to support the people of Jasper and Parks Canada family.\"\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith is speaking Thursday morning about the situation in Jasper. She'll be joined by officials from Alberta Wildfire.\n\nUPDATE 9:05 a.m.\n\nAlberta's Jasper National Park and its townsite are under siege from two wind-whipped wildfires, one of which raced into the picturesque community on Wednesday night, causing extensive damage.\n\nParks Canada says the fire has caused significant losses within the town, and the social media account for Fairmont's famous Jasper Park Lodge says the flames had reached the hotel's grounds.\n\nAs the fire consumed more fuel, officials said the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to flee to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nPhotos on social media show lodges and other buildings wrapped in sheets of orange flame and devastation the following day.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance. Alberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked for help from the Canadian military.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nEarlier in the day, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThe fires are burning on the north and south sides of the town, which is home to 5,000 people. The residents have left, along with 20,000 park visitors.\n\nThe order to leave was issued around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to Jasper. Residents and visitors fled west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight procession through swirling smoke and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make the long drive around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday. The southern fire was farther away, but Parks Canada says strong winds sent it racing toward the town.\n\nThat forced crews using heavy equipment to pull back for safety. Water bombers were grounded due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled arriving in Jasper from Edmonton only to be told to get out.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" the 24-year-old said in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said she went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nPhoto: Contributed Jasper's Maligne Lodge on fire\n\nORIGINAL 5:35 a.m.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance after a fast-moving wildfire hit Jasper National Park and its townsite late Wednesday.\n\nThe park's social media account says the fire has caused significant loss within the townsite, but the specific locations or neighbourhoods affected are not being reported.\n\nOn the social media platform X, the account for Fairmont's Jasper Park Lodge says the flames have reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, is not yet known.\n\nAs the flames consumed more fuel, officials say the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to evacuate to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nStructural firefighters stayed behind in the Alberta mountain town in an effort to protect key infrastructure.\n\nPhoto: Kenneth Smith/Banff-Canmore Visitors\n\nEarlier, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith issued a statement on Facebook, saying her thoughts are with the evacuees and those still {"uri": "2024-07-433524646", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:09:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:09:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:09:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://foxwilmington.com/thousands-flee-canadas-jasper-national-park-as-wildfire-spreads-to-town/", "title": "Thousands flee Canada's Jasper National Park as wildfire spreads to town", "body": "A tractor-trailer exploded and caught fire on Route 3 in Clifton, New Jersey, on Monday, according to local reports. (Credit: gelo__25 /TMX)\n\nOne of two raging wildfires menacing the town of Jasper in the Canadian Rockies\u00e2\u0080\u0099 largest national park roared into town Wednesday and began burning buildings.\n\nJasper National Park officials said the fire entered the southern edge of the community Wednesday evening and crews were battling multiple structural fires and working to protect key infrastructure. There were significant losses in some areas, they said.\n\nForest firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses were told to evacuate to the nearby town of Hinton, with structural firefighters staying behind.\n\nFBI OFFERING $10,000 REWARD FOR INFO LEADING TO ARREST OF SUSPECTS IN DEADLY NEW MEXICO WILDFIRES\n\nParks Canada spokesperson James Eastham told reporters outside Jasper that the town is filled with smoke and there \"has been structural loss.\"\n\n\"At this point I can't confirm how many, locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said firefighters are working to save \"as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\nJasper is being menaced by fires from the north and south, and the town\u00e2\u0080\u0099s 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 more park visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said they are \"mobilizing every necessary resource available.\" Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken.\"\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted about 3 miles from Jasper earlier in the day. The southern fire had been reported about 5 miles away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong did go wrong as fire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed. Crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t complete the work before having to pull back for safety. Water bombers couldn\u00e2\u0080\u0099t help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavorable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that rain forecast overnight would bring some relief.\n\nEllsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly.\"\n\nShe said, \"Given the intensity of fire behavior being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelorette\" was filmed there.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier Wednesday, looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away. Searchers looking through the backcountry trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people, and they continued the search Wednesday in two helicopters, Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late Monday and Tuesday, and officials said Wednesday the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nEllsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 177 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation center following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\n\"We\u00e2\u0080\u0099re just waiting to go back home and see how many days we\u00e2\u0080\u0099re going to be stuck here,\" Joyeuse said.", {"uri": "8242641044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "08:19:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T08:19:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T08:18:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-07-25/canada-firefighters-protect-pipeline-as-wildfires-reach-jasper/104143014", "title": "Canada fires threaten oil pipeline at idyllic tourist town", "body": "Evacuees are yet to return to the town as buildings on its southern edge have begun to burn.\n\nA wildfire reached the Canadian town of Jasper, Alberta, on Wednesday evening local time as firefighters battled to save key facilities including the Trans Mountain Pipeline.\n\nThe pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels of oil per day from Edmonton to Vancouver, runs through a national park in the Canadian Rockies near the picturesque tourist town.\n\n\"Firefighters ... are working to save as many structures as possible and protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline,\" Parks Canada said in a Facebook post.\n\nPark officials say the fire entered the southern edge of the community, where it has begun burning buildings.\n\nParks Canada spokesman James Eastham told reporters outside Jasper that the town was filled with smoke and there had been \"structural loss\".\n\n\"At this point I can't confirm how many, locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nThe pipeline operator did not immediately respond to a Reuters request for comment, but said earlier it was safely operating the pipeline and had deployed sprinkler protection as a preventive measure.\n\nJasper National Park said it could not report on the extent of damage to specific locations or neighbourhoods, and that it would provide further updates on Thursday.\n\nJasper is being menaced by fires from the north and south.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier in the day.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong did go wrong as fire perimeters changed minute to minute.\n\nMs Ellsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions\".\n\nAbout 25,000 people were forced to evacuate the town on Monday night, including 15,000 visitors to Jasper National Park.\n\nThe park draws around two million tourists per year and is considered a national treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie River of No Return.\n\nMore recently, the TV show The Bachelorette was filmed there.\n\nRangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier on Wednesday, looking for stragglers still there despite Monday night's mass evacuation.\n\nSearchers looking through the back-country trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people and they continued the search on Wednesday in two helicopters, Ms Ellsworth said.\n\nLater on Wednesday, officials said the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse said she was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation centre following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\nDeteriorating air quality forced firefighters and others lacking breathing equipment to evacuate to the town of Hinton about 100 kilometres away, park authorities said on Facebook on Wednesday evening.\n\nMs Ellsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to Hinton just outside the eastern edge of the park had \"not been made lightly\".\n\n\"Given the intensity of fire behaviour being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk,\" she said.\n\nOfficials of Parks Canada earlier said they expected rain to arrive overnight.\n\nThe fire marks one of hundreds ravaging the western provinces of Alberta and British Columbia.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities.\n\nWildfires burning uncontrolled across the region include 433 in British Columbia and 176 in Alberta, more than a dozen in the oil sands hub of Fort McMurray.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said the Canadian government was \"mobilising every necessary resource available\" to contain the fires.\n\n\"We're deploying Canadian Armed Forces resources, evacuations support, and more emergency wildfire resources to the province immediately -- and we're coordinating firefighting and airlift assistance. Alberta, we're with you.\"\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken\" by the damage.\n\nIn Canada, authorities issued an air quality advisory for Calgary due to the wildfire smoke.\n\nA government agency called it high risk and said children and the elderly should avoid outdoor physical exertion.\n\nAir quality warnings have also been sent across the western United States.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the US, leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple US cities.\n\nWildfire smoke can cause unhealthy air quality in areas many kilometres away from fires.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Jillian Code reports on the evacuation process as shared on social media.\n\nThe massive wildfire south of Jasper has gotten larger and closer to town after aggressive fire behaviour throughout the day and night Tuesday.\n\nThe south wildfire grew to 10,800 hectares and is eight kilometres from Jasper -- four km closer than it was the day before. It's also 2.5 km from the Valley of the Five, a popular hiking trail in Jasper National Park.\n\nThe north wildfire remains at 270 hectares and is five km from the town.\n\n\"We are seeing fire progression,\" said Parks Canada incident commander Katie Ellsworth.\n\nParks Canada is expecting increased fire behaviour on all flanks of both fires on Wednesday due to continued high and gusty winds -- 20 km and more -- as well as the general \"exceptional dryness\" of the area.\n\n\"We are still expecting some strong winds to come in,\" Ellsworth said.\n\nRain is in the forecast but isn't expected to hit until the evening and into Thursday, and there won't be enough of it to control the wildfire, Parks Canada says.\n\nAn estimated 25,000 people -- residents, workers and visitors -- were forced to evacuate Jasper on Monday night into Tuesday morning. Officials are unable to provide a timeline on when the evacuation order might end, or when residents may be able to return temporarily to recover some belongings.\n\n\"It is not safe for you to return to town,\" Ellsworth said.\n\n\"We do ask for your patience.\"\n\nParks Canada says 245 people on backcountry trails have been evacuated, with more evacuations happening Wednesday. {"uri": "8243808510", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:28:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:28:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:28:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/07/25/breaking-news/wildfire-burns-down-part-of-western-canadian-tourist-town/", "title": "Wildfire burns down part of western Canadian tourist town | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "Flames and smoke rise from a burning wildfire, as seen from a highway, in Jasper, Alberta, Canada, in this screen grab obtained from a social media video.\n\nA raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper, potentially destroying up to 50% of structures, and firefighters were trying Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of mountainous Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draw more than 2 million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were up to 10,000 people in the town and a further 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, while choking back tears.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild,\" she said, adding the fire was still out of control.\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage, or which areas had been burned and it urged residents not to return.\n\nVideo from the town showed vehicles and entire blocks burned to the ground, including a historic Anglican church.\n\nJasper resident Eva Korduliakova heard the news that her home was burning from thousands of kilometers (miles) away on Thursday morning, while visiting family in the Czech Republic with her seven-year-old son.\n\n\"I am a single mum who became homeless and jobless overnight,\" she wrote in an email. \"Our house is gone. I didn't get a chance to grab any of my belongings.\"\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of the fire.\n\n\"Last night's wildfires have simply ravaged our small tight-knit mountain community, the destruction and the loss that so many of our residents are facing simply defies description,\" he told a press conference, his voice breaking. One major concern for responders is if the fire damages the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nCN Rail said it suspended rail operations through the town on Wednesday afternoon as the wildfire conditions worsened.\n\nThe Port of Vancouver, Canada's largest, said it expected to see delays to the movement of goods through the port in the coming days due to the events in Jasper.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\n'WALL OF FLAMES'\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where there are 423 wildfires burning and dozens of evacuation orders and alerts.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Thursday afternoon he had convened a meeting of the Incident Response Group to discuss the Alberta wildfires.\n\n\"Every federal agency is coordinated, sending resources to Jasper, deploying evacuations support to the area, and reinforcing firefighting efforts on the ground,\" Trudeau said in a post on X.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder-dry forests meant this could be a catastrophic year for wildfires in Canada.\n\nThe Jasper fire was caused by a lightning strike on Monday afternoon and fuelled by strong winds, according to Parks Canada.\n\nFlames from the blaze rose 100 meters (328 feet) high, and strong wind gusts on Wednesday afternoon pushed the fire 5 km(3 miles ) in less than 30 minutes, said Alberta Public Safety and Emergency Services Minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"Any firefighter will tell you there's little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that,\" Ellis said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm to 20 mm (0.4 to 0.8 inch) of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents and destroying 10% of all structures in the city.", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Honolulu Star {"uri": "2024-07-433718404", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:10:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:10:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:10:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/c505420203b5fdba2bcf07e8b7f00d90/fast-moving-wildfire-canadian-rockies-ravages-picturesque", "title": "Fast-moving wildfire in the Canadian Rockies ravages the picturesque resort town of Jasper", "body": "GRANDE PRAIRIE, Alberta (AP) -- A fast-moving wildfire in the Canadian Rockies that had prompted 25,000 people to flee roared into the near-deserted town of Jasper overnight with flames as high as treetops, devastating up to half of its structures, officials said Thursday.\n\nThere were no immediate reports of injuries, following a mass evacuation of the picturesque resort and a neighboring national park earlier in the week, but Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland said in a letter on the town's website that the wildfire \"ravaged our beloved community.\"\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension, my deepest sympathies go out to each of you,\" he said. He said he was writing with \"profound sorrow as we being to come to terms with the devastating impact.\"\n\nDanielle Smith, the premier of Alberta province, said from 30% to 50% of the town's structures are potentially damaged. \"We don't know which structures have been damaged and which ones are destroyed, but that's going to be a significant rebuild and significant displacement,\" Smith said.\n\nSmith teared up talking about the beauty of Jasper, noting that many families from the province regularly visit.\n\nA postcard-perfect mountain town, Jasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all who live in town,\" Smith said at a news conference in Edmonton, Alberta. \"Alberta's government will provide the support needed to families and communities to recover and rebuild.\"\n\nJasper and the neighboring Jasper National Park had been menaced by fires from both the north and south, and the town's 5,000 full-time residents -- along with 20,000 visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday and Tuesday when the fires flared up.\n\nOne of the fires raced into the southern edge of the community Wednesday evening as firefighters tried to limit the damage.\n\nAlberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis said a wind gust moved the wildfire about 5 kilometers (about 3 miles) in probably less than 30 minutes toward the town with a wall of fire that he estimated was 100 meters high.\n\n\"People need to picture what those wildfire folks were experiencing at that time. Any firefighter will tell you there is little to nothing you can do when a wall of fire like that is coming at you,\" Ellis said. \"Nobody anticipated the fire to come so fast, so large.\"\n\nPierre Martel, director of fire management at Parks Canada, said lightning, winds and drought made the fire grow rapidly on Monday and that flames were above the treetops when it entered the town Wednesday. He also estimated they were about 100 meters (300 feet) tall.\n\n\"It's just a monster at that point. There are no tools we have in our tool box to deal with that at that point. You get out of the way, you retreat,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said in a post on X that there had been \"no reported injuries,\" adding that \"Approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town of Jasper and Jasper National Park. All residents, visitors and responders are safe.\"\n\nPark officials said efforts to fight the fire were continuing and that it was not immediately possible to give details of the damage. They asked for patience, and said that the fire remains out of control despite a small amount of rain that fell overnight.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said his administration has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance, including military resources.\n\nOn X, the account for the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge said the flames had reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage wasn't immediately known.\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 176 wildfires were burning across the province, including 54 that are burning out of control.\n\nAlberta Forestry and Parks Minister Todd Loewen said many of the fires are caused by lightning, and Alberta Wildfire spokesperson Christie Tucker said firefighters expect winds will raise the danger.\n\nTucker said hundreds firefighters from Australia, Mexico, New Zealand and South Africa are arriving to help fight the wildfires throughout the province.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Associated Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
