{"uri": "8242587899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:43:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:43:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:42:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41443363.html", "title": "Wildfire burns buildings in Canadian Rockies town of Jasper", "body": "Forest firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatus were told to evacuate to the nearby town of Hinton, with structural firefighters staying behind.\n\nParks Canada spokesperson James Eastham told reporters outside Jasper that the town is filled with smoke and there \"has been structural loss\".\n\n\"At this point I can't confirm how many locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said firefighters are working to save \"as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others\".\n\nA few hours earlier, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\nJasper is being threatened by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents - along with 20,000 park visitors - fled on short notice late on Monday when the fires flared up.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said officials are \"mobilising every necessary resource available\". Alberta premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken\".\n\nA record number of wildfires last year forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the US, leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple US cities.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted three miles from Jasper earlier in the day. The southern fire had been reported five miles away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts sent it racing.\n\nShe said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed, crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards could not complete the work before having to pull out, and water bombers could not help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions\".\n\nThe hope was that rain forecast overnight would bring some relief.\n\nMs Ellsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly\".\n\nShe said: \"Given the intensity of fire behaviour being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"Jasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies a World Heritage Site in 1984 for the striking mountain landscape.\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie River Of No Return. More recently, TV show The Bachelorette was filmed there.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier on Wednesday looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away.\n\nSearchers looking through the remote trails of Jasper National Park had already picked up 245 people, and they continued the search on Wednesday in two helicopters, Ms Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late on Monday and Tuesday, and officials said on Wednesday that the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nMs Ellsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later on Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea where people are, but Ms Ellsworth said she was not sure how many people were left.\n\nAlberta has been baking in scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. {"uri": "8243305891", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "15:23:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T15:23:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T15:23:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/local-news/multiple-structures-ablaze-as-wildfire-roars-into-jasper-alta-townsite-9259948", "title": "Multiple structures ablaze as wildfire roars into Jasper, Alta., townsite", "body": "EDMONTON -- One of two raging, wind-whipped fires menacing Jasper, Alta., roared into town Wednesday night and began burning buildings.\n\nParks officials say the fire entered the southern edge of the community about 6:40 p.m.\n\nPictures on social media depicted lodges and other buildings wrapped in fiery sheets of orange flame.\n\nThe park's social media account said the fire has caused significant loss within the townsite, but the specific locations or neighbourhoods affected are not being reported.\n\nOn the social media platform X, the account for Fairmont's Jasper Park Lodge said the flames have reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, is not yet known.\n\nAs the flames consumed more fuel, officials said the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to evacuate to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\n\"(The) air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses needed to evacuate to Hinton,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThat launched a line of cars and trucks snaking east to the town of Hinton, outside the park gates.\n\nJasper was under attack by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 park visitors -- have already left.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong earlier Wednesday did go wrong.\n\nFire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nThe 25,000 fled at a moment's notice two nights earlier.\n\nThe order to go went out around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nJasper National Park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is considered a national and international treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIt has hosted glitz and glitter. In 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelor\" was filmed there.\n\nJasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nIt is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 24, 2024.\n\n-- with files from Fakiha Baig in Grande Prairie\n\nDean Bennett and Lisa Johnson, The Canadian Press", "source": {"uri": "timescolonist.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Times Colonist"}, {"uri": "8242208645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:05:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:05:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/wildfire-reaches-outskirts-of-town-in-the-canadian-rockies-largest-national-park/article_3cab33f7-1378-5873-996f-804524f2746f.html", "title": "Wildfire reaches outskirts of town in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park", "body": "GRAND PRAIRIE, Alberta (AP) -- One of two wildfires bearing down on the town of Jaspar in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park reached the southern outskirts of the community on Wednesday.\n\nMany first responders have been ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\n\"Firefighters remain in town combating multiple structural fires and are working to protect critical infrastructure,\" Parks Canada said in a post on X.\n\nTwo fires whipped by strong winds are bearing down on the town of Jasper, from the north and the south.\n\nKatie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said the southern one reached the outskirts of the town just before 6 p.m. A last-ditch effort to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed.\n\nAbout 5,000 people live in Jasper, and they, along with about 20,000 visitors, had to flee at a moment's notice Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier Wednesday, looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away.\n\nSearchers looking through the backcountry trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people, and they continued the search Wednesday in two helicopters, Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late Monday and Tuesday, and officials said Wednesday the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nEllsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 177 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nCrews scrambled Wednesday to protect homes in Jasper.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nThey began work to bulldoze a fireguard on the town's southern edge. They went house to house in Jasper clearing flammables. Massive sprinklers were being set up.\n\n\"All our efforts are focused on controlling further fire spread and protecting our community,\" Ellsworth said.\n\nRain was expected into Thursday but not enough to control the fires, with no word yet on when people could return, Ellsworth said.\n\nAlberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis, in a late afternoon post on the social media site X, said he and Forestry Minister Todd Loewen \"have requested assistance from the Canadian Armed Forces to ensure all resources are brought to bear on this situation.\"\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he spoke to Jasper's mayor.\n\n\"These fires escalated rapidly, and I'm grateful for the brave first responders -- and the neighboring towns opening their homes to evacuees. Jasper, we're here for you,\" Trudeau posted on X.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation center following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\n\"We're just waiting to go back home and see how many days we're going to be stuck here,\" Joyeuse said.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nEdmonton's skyline was hazy. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 177 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nCrews scrambled Wednesday to protect homes in Jasper.\n\nThey began work to bulldoze a fireguard on the town's southern edge. They went house to house in Jasper clearing flammables. Massive sprinklers were being set up.\n\n\"All our efforts are focused on controlling further fire spread and protecting our community,\" Ellsworth said.\n\nRain was expected into Thursday but not enough to control the fires, with no word yet on when people could return, Ellsworth said.\n\nAlberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis, in a late afternoon post on the social media site X, said he and Forestry Minister Todd Loewen \"have requested assistance from the Canadian Armed Forces to ensure all resources are brought to bear on this situation.\"\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said he spoke to Jasper's mayor.\n\n\"These fires escalated rapidly, and I'm grateful for the brave first responders -- and the neighboring towns opening their homes to evacuees. {"uri": "2024-07-432598715", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:59:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:59:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:24:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/24/park-rangers-in-canada-search-for-stragglers-in-evacuation-zone-of-two-big-wildfires/", "title": "Park rangers in Canada search for stragglers in evacuation zone of two big wildfires", "body": "GRAND PRAIRIE, Alberta (AP) -- Park rangers scoured the Canadian Rockies' largest national park in helicopters Wednesday to look for stragglers still inside it despite a mass evacuation aiming to move 25,000 visitors and residents away from two large wildfires.\n\nSearchers looking through the backcountry trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people, and they continued the search Wednesday in two helicopters, Parks Canada Incident Commander Katie Ellsworth said.\n\nAs many as 15,000 people were believed to be in the park and 10,000 in the neighboring town of Jasper late Monday when authorities issued an alert asking everyone in the area to evacuate. Residents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late Monday and Tuesday, and officials said Wednesday the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nEllsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nImages shared on social media showed long lines of vehicles, their headlights glowing, inching through swirling tendrils of smoke.\n\nAddison McNeill, 24, said she had just moved to Jasper from the Alberta capital of Edmonton when she got the stressful alert Monday night to evacuate. Thousands of Jasper's 4,700 full-time residents left in vehicles but were trapped in gridlock and hot, smoky air for hours.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes, and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nA fire to the northeast cut off highway access east to Edmonton. Another fire roaring up from the south forced the closure of the north-south Icefields Parkway. That left one route open, going west to British Columbia.\n\nBut Alberta fire officials said British Columbia had its hands full with its own evacuations. Alberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis said reception centers were instead being set up in Grande Prairie and Calgary in Alberta, requiring long detours through British Columbia by the drivers fleeing Jasper.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 170 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nEllsworth said the north fire, spanning about 272 hectares, is about 5 kilometers (3 miles) from Jasper. She said the south fire, about 10,800 hectares, is about 8 kilometers (about 5 miles) from the town.\n\nCrews scrambled Wednesday to protect homes in Jasper.\n\nThey began work to bulldoze a fireguard on the town's southern edge. They went house to house in Jasper clearing flammables. Massive sprinklers were being set up.\n\n\"All our efforts are focused on controlling further fire spread and protecting our community,\" Ellsworth said.\n\nRain was expected into Thursday but not enough to control the fires, with no word yet on when people could return, Ellsworth said.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation center following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\n\"We're just waiting to go back home and see how many days we're going to be stuck here,\" Joyeuse said.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@tribtown.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": {"uri": "8242563292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "07:27:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T07:27:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T07:26:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://jerseyeveningpost.com/morenews/worldnews/2024/07/25/wildfire-burns-buildings-in-canadian-rockies-town-of-jasper/", "title": "Wildfire burns buildings in Canadian Rockies town of Jasper", "body": "One of two wildfires threatening the town of Jasper in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park has roared into town and started burning buildings.\n\nJasper National Park officials said the fire entered the southern edge of the community on Wednesday evening and crews were battling multiple structural fires and working to protect key infrastructure.\n\nForest firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatus were told to evacuate to the nearby town of Hinton, with structural firefighters staying behind.\n\nParks Canada spokesperson James Eastham told reporters outside Jasper that the town is filled with smoke and there \"has been structural loss\".\n\n\"At this point I can't confirm how many locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said firefighters are working to save \"as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others\".\n\nA few hours earlier, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\nJasper is being threatened by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents - along with 20,000 park visitors - fled on short notice late on Monday when the fires flared up.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said officials are \"mobilising every necessary resource available\". Alberta premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken\".\n\nA record number of wildfires last year forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the US, leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple US cities.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted three miles from Jasper earlier in the day. The southern fire had been reported five miles away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts sent it racing.\n\nShe said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed, crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards could not complete the work before having to pull out, and water bombers could not help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions\".\n\nThe hope was that rain forecast overnight would bring some relief.\n\nMs Ellsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly\".\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie River Of No Return. More recently, TV show The Bachelorette was filmed there.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier on Wednesday looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away.\n\nSearchers looking through the remote trails of Jasper National Park had already picked up 245 people, and they continued the search on Wednesday in two helicopters, Ms Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late on Monday and Tuesday, and officials said on Wednesday that the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nMs Ellsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later on Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea where people are, but Ms Ellsworth said she was not sure how many people were left.\n\nAlberta has been baking in scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. {"uri": "2024-07-433583034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:11:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:11:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:41:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://gazette.com/ap/international/fast-moving-wildfire-in-the-canadian-rockies-largest-national-park-ravages-the-town-of-jasper/article_3cab33f7-1378-5873-996f-804524f2746f.html", "title": "Fast-moving wildfire in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park ravages the town of Jasper", "body": "GRANDE PRAIRIE, Alberta (AP) -- A fast-moving wildfire in the Canadian Rockies that had prompted thousands of people to flee the town of Jasper roared into the near-deserted community overnight, causing devastating damage, the mayor said Thursday.\n\nOfficials said it was too early to confirm how many houses were burned, but Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland said in a letter to residents on the town's website that the wildfire \"ravaged our beloved community.\"\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension, my deepest sympathies go out to each of you,\" he said. He said he was writing with \"profound sorrow as we being to come to terms with the devastating impact.\"\n\nJasper had been menaced by fires from both the north and south, and the town's 5,000 full-time residents -- along with 20,000 more park visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday night and on Tuesday when the fires flared up.\n\nJasper National Park officials said the one of the fires had entered the southern edge of the community Wednesday evening and crews were battling structure fires and working to protect key infrastructure. There were significant losses in some areas, they said.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said his government has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance, including military resources.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"At this point I can't confirm how many, locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" Parks Canada spokesperson James Eastham said outside Jasper over night.\n\nOn X, the account for the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge says the flames have reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, is not yet known.\n\nKatie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent the south wildfire racing into the community.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. {"uri": "2024-07-433817066", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:00:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:00:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:08:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/critical-infrastructure-successfully-protected-jasper-park-officials-1.6977222", "title": "Critical infrastructure 'successfully protected': Jasper park officials", "body": "This is a developing story and will be updated throughout the day.\n\n4:45 p.m. MT: Critical infrastructure successfully protected\n\nJasper National Park officials in an update said all critical infrastructure in the townsite has been \"successfully protected, including the hospital, emergency services building, both elementary and junior/senior schools, activity centre and wastewater treatment plant,\" according to its Incident Command.\n\nThey said the most significant damage to the town occurred on the west side, southwest of Miette Avenue, and that much of the infrastructure on the east side has avoided significant damage thanks to firefighting efforts.\n\n\"Our priority remains protecting structures that have not yet been impacted by fire,\" said the update.\n\n4 p.m.: 5 mm of rain forecast to fall Thursday night\n\nEnvironment and Climate Change Canada is calling for the rain falling on the Town of Jasper and the national park to end early this evening followed by a 60-per-cent chance of showers.\n\nWind from the west is forecast to gust 20-40 km/h before becoming light this evening, with a low of 7 C. Wind gusts are expected to return Friday morning with a 30-per-cent chance of showers and a high of 18 C.\n\n3:45 p.m. MT: Ottawa deploys more resources\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said in a social media post that federal agencies are coordinated and are \"sending resources to Jasper,\" including evacuations support and firefighting reinforcements.\n\nThe additional support comes following a call between Trudeau, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith and staff.\n\n2:30 p.m. MT: Phone services hampered by fire\n\nTelus says some landline and cell phone services around Jasper are down due to wildfire damage to infrastructure.\n\nTechnicians are now working to restore services and priority is being given to restoring voice calls, including those to 9-1-1 and emergency services.\n\nIt says the company is securing helicopters to help get critical cell towers operational again.\n\n\"Multiple structures, including a number of businesses and homes, in and around the town of Jasper, have been lost\" to wildfire, officials from Parks Canada and Jasper said.\n\nHowever, they would not confirm the \"30 to 50 per cent\" estimate Alberta's premier made earlier in the day, with a spokesperson saying, \"At this time, those are not numbers that we have from the incident side, so we cannot confirm or speak to that at this time.\"\n\nThey also would not provide a timeline for crews being able to assess and report back the extent of damage.\n\n\"Of course, it is one of the pressing issues for nearly all of our community right now. And yes, they are privy to posts on social media and other platforms. But until we can verify from people on the ground what is there, our stance is that it would be irresponsible to try and confirm things based on unverified facts,\" Jasper mayor Richard Ireland told reporters.\n\n\"I appreciate people see that as a frustration, but we need the information before we share it. And we fully appreciate that those on the ground have a challenging job at their hands right now still fighting the fire and protecting some of the homes that still are standing.\"\n\nPierre Martel with Parks Canada's national fire management program said he expects campgrounds and recreational areas south of Jasper were \"significantly\" damaged.\n\nThe fire that was sparked about eight kilometres south of Jasper Monday evening by a lightning strike fuelled up quickly because of the extended drought conditions, he said.\n\n\"By the time the fires were detected, we already had significant smoke columns and it was already beyond capacity for doing quick initial attack,\" he recalled.\n\nBy Wednesday, flames were 100 metres above the tree tops. Spotting - embers carried by the wind - allowed the blaze to move five kilometres in less than one hour.\n\n\"It's just a monster at that point. There is (sic) no tools we have in our toolbox to deal with that at that point. You get out of the way, you retreat, and you do what you can to protect communities and infrastructure as best as you can.\"\n\nMartel's team has not been able to better assess the size of the fire, which he said is in the \"tens of thousands of hectares\" likely.\n\nMore structural firefighters are on their way to the town to assist those already there.\n\nWildland firefighters, who left Jasper Wednesday evening because they did not have the respiratory equipment to stay while structures were burning, have returned to the front lines.\n\nIn total, 20,000 people - the majority of whom were visitors - safely left Jasper and Jasper National Park by Wednesday.\n\n11:30 a.m. MT: Premier and Alberta Wildfire update\n\nThere are 176 wildfires burning in Alberta's protected forests currently, 54 of which are burning out of control, Alberta Wildfire reported in a Thursday morning news conference.\n\nThat number does not include mutual aid fires such as the two near Jasper in which another agency - Parks Canada, in this case - is leading the fire response.\n\nAccording to Alberta Wildfire public information officer Christie Tucker, 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in Alberta between Thursday and Monday.\n\nThey, as well as military resources, will be deployed where they are needed most, Tucker said.\n\nSpeaking about the winds that quickly pushed the fires in Jasper National Park toward the townsite on Wednesday, Tucker said, \"We're expecting more of those winds in the province today, which will raise the fire danger for those areas particularly that didn't get much rain.\"\n\nRain in parts of northern Alberta reduced \"some\" of the wildfire danger, she said, but it remains extreme in the northeast and south parts of the province.\n\nFighting tears, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith told those listening to the press conference how she, like many Albertans, grew up going to Jasper with family.\n\n\"To those in Alberta and around the world who have experience the magic of Jasper, the magic is not lost and it never will be. Alberta's government will provide the support needed to families and community to recover and rebuild stronger so that future generations can continue to experience this one of a kind community and feel the magic of being able to come home.\"\n\nShe estimated the townsite had suffered \"potentially 30 to 50 per cent structural damage.\"\n\nSmith also told reporters she and her ministers would be speaking with their federal counterparts Thursday, including a call with the prime minister in the afternoon and a meeting with the federal minister of emergency preparedness in person in Edmonton.\n\n8:30 a.m. MT: Update from Jasper mayor\n\n\"It's been a sleepless night, as I'm sure it has been for all of our evacuated residents,\" Jasper's mayor, Richard Ireland, told CTV Edmonton Morning Live.\n\nHe said support from people across Canada has helped him come to terms with the devastating news of at least some destruction.\n\n\"It is gratifying to know that people appreciate our community and are fully prepared to step up to help us rebuild,\" Ireland said.\n\nSpeaking about the toll the COVID-19 pandemic took on Jasper, he added, \"We've learned to come together and work our way through that and that hopefully has prepared us to come together once again ... as we start to face the really daunting prospect of rebuilding an entire community, perhaps.\"\n\n7:10 a.m. MT: First government update\n\nOfficials are waiting to learn Thursday morning the extent of wildfire damage in the Jasper townsite of Jasper National Park, which flames began to eat away at the night before.\n\nFirefighters that remained in Jasper overnight were working to save what buildings they could.\n\nAlberta's forestry and parks minister said the government has not received any more information overnight but was expecting an update from Parks Canada later in the day.\n\n\"Obviously, it's a pretty dire situation over there, but still no extra information,\" Todd Loewen said.\n\nIn its last update Wednesday evening, Parks Canada said \"significant loss\" had occurred in the townsite.\n\nPictures on social media showed flames engulfing Maligne Lodge and encroaching on other buildings in the Canadian Rockies town.\n\nManagement at Fairmont's famous Jasper Park Lodge confirmed fire had reached that hotel's grounds, too, but did not know Wednesday evening what kind of damage had been caused.\n\n\"Our hearts go out to them. I can't imagine the trauma that it causes seeing something like that and those pictures,\" Loewen said.\n\n\"We don't know exactly what's been lost, but hopefully it's better than what we're thinking right now anyways.\"\n\nThe federal government has approved Alberta's request for military help.\n\nMunicipalities around the province are also sending crews and resources to Jasper.", "source": {"uri": "8243601702", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:33:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:33:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:32:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.lakecowichangazette.com/national-news/alberta-premier-fights-back-tears-as-wildfire-devastates-iconic-jasper-7457326", "title": "Alberta premier fights back tears as wildfire devastates iconic Jasper", "body": "Alberta Premier Danielle Smith fought back tears Thursday as she sought to console Jasper residents coming to terms with a community devastated by wildfire.\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said at a fire update in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nSpecifics on what has been destroyed in the Rocky Mountain resort town of 5,000 remained sketchy.\n\nJasper Park officials, in a statement, said the firefighting situation remains dynamic.\n\n\"Due to the ongoing fire conditions and our focus on the response effort, it is impossible to share information about specific locations and the extent of damage at this time,\" said the statement.\n\n\"The accuracy of this information is critical because it has a direct impact on members of the community. We will share more information as soon as we are able to ensure its accuracy.\"\n\nPhotos shared on social media Wednesday night depicted Jasper structures wrapped in sheets of flame.\n\nA video Thursday morning showed rain-slicked streets, cloudy skies and a wide swath of blackened, charred homes and buildings razed to their foundations.\n\n\"The images we're seeing out of Jasper are devastating,\" said Forestry Minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way.\n\nCalgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park, said they were sending resources to the fire scene.\n\nThe staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nIn Hinton Thursday morning, rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nCritical infrastructure has been affected by the wildfires that have raged through Jasper National Park, Alta. and into the picturesque townsite itself.\n\nTelus Corp. confirmed Thursday that some of its infrastructure in the Jasper area was damaged Wednesday in the blaze.\n\nA Telus spokeswoman said some home phone and mobility services in the area are down, and technicians are working hard to restore service.\n\nPriority is being given to restoring the ability to make voice calls, including those to 911, emergency services and hospital communication, said spokeswoman Brandi Merker in an email.\n\nShe said the company is securing helicopters to refuel critical cell tower sites and has also brought in backup generators to ensure the company can maintain wireless coverage for first responders.\n\n\"We know this is a difficult time and we are doing all we can to support our customers and team members who have been impacted, including supplying resources to the evacuation centre in Hinton, Alberta,\" Merker said.\n\nTelus said Thursday it is committing $100,000 to support rebuilding efforts in Jasper.\n\nCanadian National Railway Co., whose main line runs through Jasper, suspended operations in the area Wednesday afternoon as conditions worsened.\n\nCN first suspended rail service through Jasper on Tuesday but restarted it briefly Wednesday before shutting it down again a few hours later.\n\n\"Early reports indicate the wildfires caused significant damage to the town. We stand in support and solidarity with the community, home to many of our CN team members and their families,\" said CN spokeswoman Ashley Michnowski in an email.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, urged them to stay strong.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Ireland wrote.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nAbout 25,000 people, including about 5,000 residents in the Jasper townsite, were forced to flee west at a moment's notice late Monday night as twin wildfires from the south and north roared up and cut off access to the east and south.\n\nA day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist.\n\nOn Wednesday, efforts to contain the fires -- include buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by raging, gusting winds.\n\nAround 6 p.m. Wednesday, the fire roared in and began torching structures.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nREAD ALSO: Jasper wildfire evacuees find relief after long journey to Within 48 hours, the wildfires reached the Jasper townsite.\n\nDespite the rapid pace of the fire, no injuries have been reported. Parks Canada says that approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town of Jasper and Jasper National Park. All residents, visitors and responders are reportedly safe.\n\nThough there is not yet official confirmation on the scale of loss to the town, photos and videos of structures ablaze and homes burned to the ground have been circulating on social media.\n\nA Facebook post from Woodlands County, approximately 300 km east of Jasper National Park, shared heartbreaking photos of the town, including one of the historic Jasper Anglican Church burnt to the ground.\n\nJasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight, and while it helped to reduce fire activity, the update said that it was \"not enough to have made a meaningful impact on the overall wildfire situation,\" which remains out of control.\n\nSignificant structural firefighting reinforcements arrived throughout the night and have continued to assist with firefighting efforts in the community overnight and this morning.\n\n\"We are thankful to all of our partners and municipal fire agencies who have sent resources to help protect our community and national park. {"uri": "2024-07-432739427", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:56:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:56:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:56:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/c505420203b5fdba2bcf07e8b7f00d90/wildfire-reaches-town-canadian-rockies-largest-national", "title": "Wildfire reaches town in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park as attempt to reroute it fails", "body": "GRAND PRAIRIE, Alberta (AP) -- One of two wildfires bearing down on the town of Jaspar in the Canadian Rockies' largest national park reached the community on Wednesday as a last-ditch attempt to reroute it failed.\n\nAround the same time, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety. But firefighters stayed.\n\n\"Firefighters remain in town combating multiple structural fires and are working to protect critical infrastructure,\" Parks Canada said in a post on X.\n\nTwo fires whipped by strong winds are bearing down on the town of Jasper, from the north and the south.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted 5 kilometers (about 3 miles) from Jasper earlier in the day.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported 8 kilometers (about 5 miles) away from the town, but Katie Ellsworth of Parks Canada said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong did go wrong as fire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed. Crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety. Water bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavorable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that some rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nEllsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to the town of Hinton, Alberta just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly.\"\n\nShe said, \"Given the intensity of fire behavior being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIn 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelorette\" was filmed there.\n\nAbout 5,000 people live in Jasper, and they, along with about 20,000 visitors, had to flee at a moment's notice Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nPark rangers in helicopters scoured the park earlier Wednesday, looking for stragglers still there despite a mass evacuation aimed at moving visitors and residents away.\n\nSearchers looking through the backcountry trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people, and they continued the search Wednesday in two helicopters, Ellsworth said.\n\nResidents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late Monday and Tuesday, and officials said Wednesday the evacuation of the town of Jasper was complete.\n\nEllsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 177 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nAlberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis, in a late afternoon post on the social media site X, said he has \"requested assistance from the Canadian Armed Forces to ensure all resources are brought to bear on this situation.\"\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation center following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\n\"We're just waiting to go back home and see how many days we're going to be stuck here,\" Joyeuse said.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Associated Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jasper_National_Park", {"uri": "8243847443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-26", "time": "00:25:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-26T00:25:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-26T00:24:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.oregonlive.com/wildfires/2024/07/jasper-canadian-rockies-resort-town-devastated-by-fast-moving-wildfire.html", "title": "Jasper, Canadian Rockies resort town, devastated by fast-moving wildfire", "body": "GRANDE PRAIRIE, Alberta -- A fast-moving wildfire in the Canadian Rockies that had prompted 25,000 people to flee roared into the near-deserted town of Jasper overnight with flames higher than treetops, devastating up to half of its structures, officials said Thursday.\n\nThere were no immediate reports of injuries, following a mass evacuation of the picturesque resort and a neighboring national park earlier in the week, but Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland said in a letter on the town's website that the wildfire \"ravaged our beloved community.\"\n\nThe Oregonian/OregonLive wildfire tracker\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension, my deepest sympathies go out to each of you,\" he said.\n\nDanielle Smith, the premier of Alberta province, said from 30% to 50% of the town's structures are potentially damaged or destroyed, saying \"that's going to be a significant rebuild and significant displacement.\"\n\nSmith teared up talking about the beauty of Jasper, noting that many families from the province regularly visit. A postcard-perfect mountain town, Jasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all who live in town,\" Smith said at a news conference in Edmonton, Alberta, while pledging her government's support for the community to rebuild.\n\nParks Canada officials later said all critical infrastructure was protected including the hospital, schools and the wastewater treatment plant. They said the most significant structural damage is concentrated on the west side of town. Some bridges around town and throughout the park were damaged.\n\nJasper and the neighboring Jasper National Park had been menaced by fires from both the north and south, and the town's 5,000 full-time residents -- along with 20,000 visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday and Tuesday when the fires flared up.\n\nOne of the fires raced into the southern edge of the community Wednesday evening as firefighters tried to limit the damage.\n\nAlberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis said a wind gust moved the wildfire about 5 kilometers (about 3 miles) in probably less than 30 minutes toward the town with a wall of fire that he estimated was 100 meters high.\n\n\"People need to picture what those wildfire folks were experiencing at that time. Any firefighter will tell you there is little to nothing you can do when a wall of fire like that is coming at you,\" Ellis said. \"Nobody anticipated the fire to come so fast, so large.\"\n\nPierre Martel, director of fire management at Parks Canada, said lightning, winds and drought made the fire grow rapidly on Monday and that flames were above the treetops when it entered the town Wednesday.\n\n\"It's just a monster at that point. There are no tools we have in our tool box to deal with that at that point. You get out of the way, you retreat,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said in a post on X that there had been \"no reported injuries,\" adding that \"Approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town of Jasper and Jasper National Park. All residents, visitors and responders are safe.\"\n\nAnnelies Lagger, who has owned and lived in the Austrian Haven B&B for 30 years, said she's waiting to hear if it's been destroyed but isn't optimistic because all the houses nearby are gone. She said she fled with her 13 cats and dog.\n\n\"I have no clue where I go now. Heaven or hell. It was my life. You can imagine how much work it was,\" she said. \"I'm think I'm in shock.\"\n\nShe said relatives including her daughter and son-in-law had their homes destroyed. \"It was the heat that dried everything out. And now the town is gone,\" she said.\n\nLagger was sheltering with a kind stranger in Valemount, British Columbia, but said she eventually will need to find new homes for her family members and \"for my critters.\"\n\n\"I'm a very tough women. Whatever happens I start again even though I'm 82 years old,\" she said.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said his administration has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance, including military resources.\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 176 wildfires were burning across the province, including 54 that are burning out of control.\n\nAlberta Forestry and Parks Minister Todd Loewen said many of the fires are caused by lightning, and Alberta Wildfire spokesperson Christie Tucker said firefighters expect winds will raise the danger.\n\nTucker said hundreds firefighters from Australia, Mexico, New Zealand and South Africa are arriving to help fight the wildfires throughout the province.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.", "source": {"uri": "oregonlive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Oregon Live"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The town of Jasper and Jasper National Park in Alberta have closed and are being evacuated due to active wildfires, the park said Tuesday.\n\nTrudeau said he was sending \"resources, evacuations support, and more emergency wildfire resources to the province immediately -- and we're coordinating firefighting and airlift assistance.\"\n\n\"Alberta, we're with you,\" he added.\n\nThe evacuation impacts 15,000 people who were visiting and staying in the park when the order was issued, as well as about 10,000 people in the town of Jasper, including seasonal workers, according to the Alberta Emergency Management Agency.\n\n\"The Town of Jasper and Parks Canada's priority is the safety of our staff, residents and visitors,\" Jasper National Park said in a statement on Tuesday. \"We acknowledge this is a stressful time and appreciate patience as this is an evolving and complex situation.\"\n\nThousands of residents and visitors already evacuated overnight, as multiple wildfires burn in Jasper National Park, the largest national park in the Canadian Rockies, the park said.\n\nParks Canada is mobilizing additional firefighting resources and aircraft to assist in battling the blazes, according to Jasper National Park.\n\n\"Our priority is to protect the town and community of Jasper, limiting wildfire growth towards town, Highway 16 and critical infrastructure,\" Jasper National Park said.\n\nReservations through Aug. 6 in Jasper National Park have been canceled. A reopening date has not yet been announced.\n\nAlberta is experiencing \"extreme wildfire conditions,\" with more than 170 wildfires burning across the province, according to the government of The moisture would be of benefit as officials said \"suppression efforts by helicopter bucketing proved ineffective.\"\n\nAttempts to build fireguards using heavy equipment were not able to be finished before it was needed to be pulled back for safety. Water bomber planes were \"unable to assist due to dangerous flying conditions.\"\n\nIn an earlier social media post, Parks Canada announced first responders would be relocated to Hinton, except for firefighters working to protect the town.\n\nIn a Wednesday afternoon update, the province of Alberta said the government is now requesting assistance from the Canadian Armed Forces to help with the ongoing wildfire efforts in Jasper and Jasper National Park.\n\n\"Supports requested include firefighting and wildfire mitigation resources to reduce the risk to homes, businesses, critical infrastructure and communities,\" the province said.\n\nThe Jasper townsite remains under threat from two nearby wildfires that have damaged infrastructure while converging from opposite directions and expected to grow Wednesday amid continued high winds.\n\nCritical infrastructure in the townsite is being protected with sprinkler systems and fire barriers are being set up with bulldozers. Crews are also going through neighbourhoods and removing potentially flammable materials including dried brush and propane tanks.\n\n\"The priorities from this incident remain to keep people safe and keep the main wildfire away from the main town of Jasper,\" said Katie Ellsworth, an incident commander with Parks Canada.\n\n\"The town of Jasper has not been impinged by fire at this time. {"uri": "8243779093", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:52:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:52:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:52:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/523201/devastating-wildfire-burns-down-part-of-western-canadian-tourist-town", "title": "Devastating wildfire burns down part of western Canadian tourist town", "body": "A raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper, potentially destroying up to 50 percent of structures, and firefighters were working on Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of mountainous Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draw more than two million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were up to 10,000 people in the town and a further 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, while choking back tears.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30 percent to 50 percent structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild,\" she said, adding the fire was still out of control.\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage, or which areas had been hit and it urged residents not to return.\n\nVideo from the town showed vehicles and entire blocks burned to the ground, including a historic Anglican church.\n\nJasper resident Eva Korduliakova heard the news that her home was burning from thousands of kilometers away Thursday morning, while visiting family in the Czech Republic with her seven-year-old son.\n\n\"I am single mum who became homeless and jobless overnight,\" she wrote in an email. \"Our house is gone. I didn't get a chance to grab any of my belongings.\"\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of the fire.\n\n\"Last night's wildfires have simply ravaged our small tight-knit mountain community, the destruction and the loss that so many of our residents are facing simply defies description,\" he told a press conference, his voice breaking.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire damages the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nCN Rail said it suspended rail operations through the town on Wednesday afternoon as the wildfire conditions worsened.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where there 423 wildfires burning and dozens of evacuation orders and alerts.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be a catastrophic year for wildfires in Canada. The Jasper fire was caused by a lightning strike on Monday afternoon and fuelled by strong winds, according to Parks Canada.\n\nFlames from the blaze rose 100 metres high, and strong wind gusts on Wednesday afternoon pushed the fire 5 kilometres in less than 30 minutes, said Alberta public safety minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"Any firefighter will tell you there's little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that,\" Ellis said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10mm to 20mm of rain for Thursday (local time), which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents and destroying 10 percent of all structures in the city.", "source": {"uri": "rnz.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "RNZ"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8243615233", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:46:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:46:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:46:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/national-news/2024/07/25/alberta-premier-says-a-third-perhaps-half-of-all-jasper-buildings-burned-by-fire/", "title": "Alberta premier says a third, perhaps half, of all Jasper buildings burned by fire - Medicine Hat News", "body": "A wildfire burns as an empty street in Jasper, Alta. is shown in this Wednesday, July 24, 2024 handout photo from the Jasper National Park Facebook page. THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO, Facebook, Jasper National Park *MANDATORY CREDIT*EDMONTON - Alberta Premier Danielle Smith says early reports indicate a third and perhaps up to half of all buildings in the historic Rocky Mountain resort town of Jasper have burned in a wildfire. \"You've seen the images as I have,\"\u009d Smith said Thursday. \"We're seeing potentially 30 to 50 per cent structural damage to give you some idea. \"We don't know which structures have been damaged and which ones have been destroyed, but that's going to be a significant rebuild.\" Smith made the comments after fighting back tears at a news conference as she sought to console residents who were evacuated from the townsite and now face significant hardship when they return. \"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it,\"\u009d Smith said. \"And to those in Alberta and around the world who have experienced the magic of Jasper: The magic is not lost, and it never will be.\"\u009d Parks Canada, in a statement said it will provide details on lost structures when it can accurately and responsibly confirm what burned. But it says crews continue to battle a swift and dynamic fire in Jasper National Park. \"Jasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight,\"\u009d said the statement. \"While the rain helped reduce fire activity slightly, it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\u009d Images surfacing on social media depicted blocks of homes and businesses burned to charred foundations and vehicles torched to the hubcaps. Calgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park dispatched resources to the fire scene. The province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way. The staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park. In Hinton Thursday rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck. Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, said, \"In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\u009d About 20,000 park visitors and the 5,000 residents of the Jasper municipality had to flee on a moment's notice Monday night ahead of two wildfires that cut off road access everywhere but west to British Columbia. A day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist. Those without a place to stay have been directed to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary. Crews lost the fight to save Jasper Wednesday just after 6 p.m., as waves of orange and red breached the southern outskirts and began devouring homes and livelihoods. Frantic efforts to contain the fires -- including buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by high winds. \"That wind gust moved that fire five kilometres in probably less than 30 minutes, with a wall of fire that was about 100 metres high,\"\u009d said Alberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis. \"There is little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that.\"\u009d \"Nobody anticipated that fire to come so fast, so large and so quickly.\"\u009d Pierre Martel, who oversees fire management with Parks Canada, echoed Ellis. \"There are no tools we have in our toolbox to deal with that,\"\u009d Martel told an online news conference. \"It's just a monster at that point.\"\u009d This report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024. -- with files from Jeremy Simes in Regina and Fakiha Baig in Hinton", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", {"uri": "2024-07-433641729", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:22:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:22:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:22:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://dailyhive.com/canada/jasper-wildfire-alberta-premier-update", "title": "Jasper wildfire destroys \"potentially 50%\" of town: Alberta premier", "body": "Alberta Premier Danielle Smith was noticeably upset during the province's update on the rapidly evolving wildfire situation in Jasper National Park and the rest of Alberta.\n\nDuring a press briefing in Edmonton on Thursday morning, Smith choked back tears as she described a \"wall of flames\" hitting the townsite, claiming that potentially 50% of the town has burned.\n\n\"To those in Alberta and around the world who experienced the magic of Jasper, the magic is not lost and it never will be,\" Smith said.\n\nSmith, like many Albertans have expressed today, described the special place the park and townsite hold in people's hearts.\n\n\"For many generations, the town of Jasper and the parking surrounding it have been a source of pride, with some of the most beautiful scenery in the world. Our grandparents visited to experience the majesty of this place, with its mountains and lakes and meadows. They took our parents who then took us to this special spot that they'd spend time in as children,\" she said tearfully.\n\n\"And now we take our own children and visitors from around the world to get that same feeling that you get with your first glimpse of the mountains on the horizon. A feeling that even though you've just left home, you're coming home.\"\n\nProvincial officials added that they would be moving to a \"unified command centre\" so that various levels of government could collaborate on the wildfire response. Federal Minister of Emergency Preparedness Harjit Sajan will be in Edmonton later today to help coordinate the response.\n\nAccording to provincial officials and the most recent update from Jasper National Park, the wildfire situation in Jasper remains out of control.\n\nJasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight, and while it helped to reduce fire activity, it was \"not enough to have made a meaningful impact on the overall wildfire situation.\"\n\nThe wildfire situation in the beloved national park evolved rapidly, from the first report of a wildfire starting to the northeast of the town of Jasper on Monday evening to a second fire south of town shortly after. Within 48 hours, the wildfires reached the Jasper townsite.\n\nDespite the rapid pace of the fire, no injuries have been reported. Parks Canada says that approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town of Jasper and Jasper National Park. All residents, visitors and responders are reportedly safe.\n\nParks Canada has yet to confirm the scale of loss to the town, though photos and videos of structures ablaze and homes burned to the {"uri": "8241955750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:10:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:10:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:08:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/24/canadian-wildfires-prompt-more-evacuation-orders-air-quality-warnings", "title": "Canadian wildfires prompt more evacuation orders, air-quality warnings", "body": "Hundreds of wildfires are burning in Canada's western provinces of British Columbia and Alberta.\n\nHundreds of out-of-control wildfires are burning across western Canada, putting more communities under evacuation alert and raising concerns about air quality.\n\nAuthorities at the BC Wildlife Service said on Wednesday that 430 active wildfires were burning in British Columbia (BC) along with 177 more in neighbouring Alberta, including near Jasper National Park in the Canadian Rockies, one of the country's most popular tourist destinations.\n\nCanada's westernmost province, BC was hit by more than 58,000 lightning strikes, according to the provincial wildfire agency, sparking scores of new blazes in forests that are tinder-dry after a three-week heat wave.\n\nPark rangers scoured Jasper National Park in helicopters on Wednesday to look for people still inside despite a mass evacuation aiming to move 25,000 visitors and residents away from two large wildfires.\n\nSearchers looking through the backcountry trails of the park already had picked up 245 people, Parks Canada Incident Commander Katie Ellsworth told reporters.\n\nAs many as 15,000 people were believed to be in the park and 10,000 in the neighbouring town of Jasper late Monday when authorities issued an alert asking everyone in the area to evacuate.\n\n\"The town of Jasper and Jasper National Park have been evacuated due to two active wildfires,\" Jasper National Park said in a social media post.\n\n\"The evacuation of the townsite and frontcountry is complete. Evacuations in the backcountry are ongoing and complete in high priority areas,\" it said.\n\n\"Our highest priorities are to protect the town of Jasper and limit wildfire growth towards the town, Highway 16, and critical infrastructure.\"\n\nEllsworth said the north fire, spanning about 272 hectares (672 acres), is about 5km (three miles) from Jasper while the south fire, about 10,800 hectares (26,600 acres), is some 8km (about five miles) away.\n\nRain was expected into Thursday but not enough to control the blazes, with no word yet on when people could return, she added.\n\nPhotos and videos shared on social media overnight from Monday to Tuesday showed a line of bumper-to-bumper cars and trucks crawling through smoke to try to get out of the area.\n\nJasper resident Addison McNeill, 24, said she had just moved to the town from Edmonton when she got the stressful alert on Monday night to evacuate.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes, and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she told The Associated Press.\n\nMany communities in western Canada also have been blanketed by thick smoke, including Alberta's largest city, Calgary, where residents were advised to limit time outdoors.\n\nThe Canadian government warned Calgary residents on Wednesday morning that wildfire smoke was causing \"very poor air quality and reduced visibility\".\n\n\"During heavy smoke conditions, everyone is at risk regardless of their age or health. The fine particles in wildfire smoke pose the main health risk,\" it said in a weather advisory.\n\nIn April, federal officials said Canada risked another \"catastrophic\" wildfire season amid higher-than-normal spring and summer temperatures across much of the country.\n\nLast year, the country experienced a record fire season that saw more than 6,600 wildfires burn 15 million hectares (37 million acres).\n\nExperts have said that climate change has extended the Canadian wildfire season and made it easier for blazes to start and spread.", "source": {"uri": "aljazeera.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8243750154", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:13:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:13:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:12:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://nationnews.com/2024/07/25/devastating-wildfire-burns-down-part-of-western-canadian-tourist-town/", "title": "Devastating wildfire burns down part of western Canadian tourist town - nationnews.com", "body": "A raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper, potentially destroying up to 50% of structures, and firefighters were working on Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of mountainous Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draw more than 2 million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were up to 10,000 people in the town and a further 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, while choking back tears.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild,\" she said, adding the fire was still out of control.\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage, or which areas had been hit and it urged residents not to return.\n\nVideo from the town showed vehicles and entire blocks burned to the ground, including a historic Anglican church.\n\nJasper resident Eva Korduliakova heard the news that her home was burning from thousands of kilometers away Thursday morning, while visiting family in the Czech Republic with her seven-year-old son.\n\n\"I am single mum who became homeless and jobless overnight,\" she wrote in an email. \"Our house is gone. I didn't get a chance to grab any of my belongings.\"\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of the fire.\n\n\"Last night's wildfires have simply ravaged our small tight-knit mountain community, the destruction and the loss that so many of our residents are facing simply defies description,\" he told a press conference, his voice breaking.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire damages the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nCN Rail said it suspended rail operations through the town on Wednesday afternoon as the wildfire conditions worsened.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where there 423 wildfires burning and dozens of evacuation orders and alerts.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be a catastrophic year for wildfires in Canada.\n\nThe Jasper fire was caused by a lightning strike on Monday afternoon and fuelled by strong winds, according to Parks Canada.\n\nFlames from the blaze rose 100 meters high (328 feet), and strong wind gusts on Wednesday afternoon pushed the fire 5 kilometers (3 miles) in less than 30 minutes, said Alberta public safety minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"Any firefighter will tell you there's little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that,\" Ellis said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents and destroying 10% of all structures in the city. (Reuters)", "source": {"uri": "nationnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Nation Newspaper, The"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ashminnie_moonsammy@nationnews.com", "name": "Ashminnie Moonsammy", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Town"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildfire", "type":
