{"uri": "8242346730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "04:34:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T04:34:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T04:34:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Canada/498410/-Significant-loss-Wildfire-roars-in-Jasper-as-first-responders-ordered-to-leave", "title": "'Significant loss': Wildfire roars in Jasper as first responders ordered to leave - Canada News", "body": "Photo: Banff-Canmore Visitors Facebook Jasper's Maligne Lodge on fire\n\nUPDATE 9:25 p.m.\n\nParks Canada says firefighters continue to battle to save as many structures as possible in the Jasper townsite.\n\n\"Today has been an exceptionally difficult day for Jasperites, incident personnel and everyone who loves Jasper,\" said the agency.\n\nCrews working to save homes, businesses and critical infrastructure will be supported by \"many more\" structural firefighters en route to the community.\n\n\"As the pictures and videos circulating online show, significant loss has occurred within the townsite,\" Parks Canada said.\n\n\"We are sensitive that residents, business owners, visitors and those with connections to Jasper want to know the state of their homes, businesses, treasures and favourite places.\"\n\nInformation about the extent of damage to specific locations or neighbourhoods is not available while crews focus on saving as many structures as possible.\n\n\"We are grateful for the support, encouragement, care and kind words we have received from all over the country and world.\" No additional updates are expected from Parks Canada this evening.\n\nThe Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge, in a statement, confirmed that the flames have reached the hotel's property, but the extent of damage is unclear.\n\n\"At this time, we know parts of the resort remain untouched,\" the resort said, thanking first responders for their efforts.\n\nPhotos of the Maligne Lodge are circulating widely, showing the hotel in flames.\n\nJasper is under attack by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 park visitors -- have already left.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong earlier Wednesday did go wrong.\n\nFire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nUPDATE 7:50 p.m.\n\nWildland firefighters and anyone else without self contained breathing apparatuses have now been evacuated from Jasper.\n\nPark Canada says that everyone with the exception of structural firefighters were ordered at 8:30 p.m. MST to evacuate to Hinton due to toxic air quality.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others,\" said the statement.\n\nAdditional structural protection crews are en route, Parks Canada said.\n\n\"Our hearts go out to all of the affected community members, their families and their friends, many of which include our local first responders.\"\n\nUPDATE: 6:53 p.m.\n\nOne of two raging, wind-whipped wildfires bearing down on the historic Jasper townsite reached its southern outskirts early Wednesday night as a last-ditch attempt to reroute it failed.\n\nAround the same time, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nFirefighters remained in the town to douse spot fires and maintain sprinkler lines. Everyone else was reminded to get out.\n\n\"If you have not yet evacuated town you must leave now,\" Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said in a statement posted on Facebook.\n\n\"Our hearts go out to all of the affected community members, their families and their friends, many of which include our local first responders.\"\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier in the day.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Ellsworth said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong did go wrong as fire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nEllsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to the town of Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly.\"\n\nShe said, \"Given the intensity of fire behaviour being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nAbout 5,000 people live in Jasper. They, along with about 20,000 park visitors had to flee on a moment's notice Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nThe order to go went out around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nJasper National Park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is considered a national and international treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIt has hosted glitz and glitter. In 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelorette\" was filmed there.\n\nJasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nIt is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\nUPDATE 6:30 p.m.\n\nParks officials say one of two wildfires bearing down on the Jasper, Alta., townsite has reached the community.\n\nAll first responders have been ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nTwo fires whipped by strong winds are bearing down on the town, from the north and the south.\n\nKatie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said the southern one reached the outskirts of the townsite just before 6 p.m.\n\n\"Firefighters remain in town combating multiple structural fires and are working to protect critical infrastructure,\" said Parks Canada on X.\n\nA last-ditch effort to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed.\n\nAbout 5,000 live in Jasper, and they, along with about 20,000 visitors, had to flee at a moment's notice Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nUPDATE 4:15 p.m.\n\nAbigail Popple, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter / The Rocky Mountain Goat\n\nThe south fire in Jasper National Park has grown over 4,000 hectares since yesterday evening, now totalling at least 10,800 hectares. It is roughly eight kilometres away from the Town of Jasper, according to Incident Commander Katie Ellsworth.\n\nThe north fire, which is about five kilometres away from town, is still about 270 hectares.\n\nRain is forecasted for this evening and into Thursday morning. Ellsworth says commanders anticipate a reduction in fire activity if Jasper does receive precipitation, but gusty conditions mean the fire will likely grow before then.\n\nEllsworth confirmed to media that the town has not been impacted by fire. She added that there is no timeline for re-entry, including for temporary visits to gather items that evacuees left behind.\n\n\"We understand that this is stressful. We do ask for your patience, and we will provide you with a timeline (once) you are able to return to retrieve the items that you may have left behind,\" Ellsworth said.\n\nIn a Facebook post this afternoon, the Municipality of Jasper encouraged evacuees to prepare to stay elsewhere. They advise evacuees to make arrangements with friends or family if possible, or go to reception centres in Edmonton, Calgary, or Grande Prairie. Additionally, free camping for evacuees is available at Buck Lake in the County of Wetaskiwin, and at the Dr. Duncan Murray Recreation Centre Field in the Town of Hinton.\n\nThe Municipality also advises residents and business owners to call their insurance provider as soon as possible, and apply for Employment Insurance using their temporary address.\n\nThe status of structures outside of town - such as the Palisades Centre, Caribou Recovery Centre, and the HI Athabasca Falls Wilderness Hostel - is unknown at this time. Heavy smoke and aggressive fire behavior have made it unsafe for responders to access these structures, according to Ellsworth.\n\n\"In terms of the Palisades Centre, we can confirm that it has been impacted. Because of the fire behavior yesterday, we don't know the extent of those impacts,\" Ellsworth said. \"We are hoping to be able to confirm those impacts as soon as we can, so that we can share that information both to the public and the business owners. But we do ask for your continued patience.\"\n\nFirefighters are taking steps to protect the town's infrastructure in case the southern fire continues to move northward. This includes the installation of high-volume sprinklers on the south side of the Parks Canada compound, and around the southwest perimeter of town from Patricia Place to the entrance of Stone Mountain Village. Sprinklers will also be installed around Pyramid Bench from west to east. Additionally, firefighters are removing combustible material and dry vegetation from town today, Ellsworth added.\n\nEllsworth asks that the public look to Parks Canada, the Municipality of Jasper, and Alberta Wildfire for accurate information on the fire, rather than using other resources like NASA's MODIS and FIRMS satellite imagery.\n\n\"At this time due to heavy, thick smoke conditions in Jasper, we cannot confirm the MODIS or FIRMS hits that you can see if you're looking at the satellite imagery,\" she said. \"These satellites do indicate heat registers, and it's not uncommon after a fairly aggressive burning day when things calm down for that heat to sink back down to the surface and be registered as a fire point.\"\n\nAlert hiccups\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, who also attended the press conference, thanked Jasper residents and visitors for their cooperation during the evacuation. However, he said he received reports this morning that the alert system used by the municipality did not work as intended.\n\n\"We gave out an emergency alert on our system - we use something called Voyent,\" he told journalists. \"It has come to my attention that some subscribers to that service did not receive the messages that we thought that they had received.\"\n\nIreland added that the Alberta Emergency Alerts system worked as expected.\n\nThe glitch that caused the error has been fixed since the municipality learned of it earlier this morning, according to Ireland.\n\n\"All of these incidents undergo an after-action debrief. The whole system will be reviewed and we will see whether any corrections have to be made to prevent this happening, either in our location or other locations with the same sorts of mass alert systems,\" he said.\n\nHighway 16 partially cleared\n\nAccording to Drive BC, about 350 kilometres of Highway 16 has been cleared between Victoria Street and the B.C.-Alberta border, as of 11:01 a.m. today. There is still limited visibility due to smoke from 16 kilometres east of Tete Jaune to the Alberta border.\n\nHighway 16 eastbound is closed from the Mount Robson Visitor Centre to the Alberta border. The westbound lane is open only for evacuation purposes. Drive BC anticipates an update to Highway 16 at 4:30 p.m. today.\n\nUPDATE 12:25 p.m.\n\nFuelled by whipping winds, fires in Jasper National Park are edging closer from two directions to the historic Rocky Mountain townsite of Jasper.\n\nParks Canada says a wildfire to the north is five kilometres away while another approaching from the south is eight kilometres distant.\n\nNo critical infrastructure in Jasper has been damaged, and crews are scrambling to protect the homes of almost 5,000 residents by bulldozing a fireguard on the southern edge, clearing flammables house-by-house, and installing massive sprinkler systems.\n\nParks Canada official Katie Ellsworth says windy conditions are making things worse, and says the southern blaze has doubled in size to more than 100 square kilometres.\n\nOfficials say they can't accurately update what's happening to infrastructure outside the townsite, such as picnic areas or power lines, because of smoky conditions.\n\nAbout 25,000 people, including residents and visitors, were forced to flee Jasper National Park earlier this week ahead of the fires.\n\nThe Canadian Press\n\nORIGINAL 5:45 a.m.\n\nSome wildfire evacuees who were trapped in traffic for hours while leaving Jasper National Park say they are feeling relieved to have found safety.\n\nAddison McNeill, who is 24, says she felt stressed when she got an alert on Monday night to evacuate Jasper about two hours after she moved to the alpine town from Edmonton.\n\nWhen she got on the road, she says she saw many of Jasper's 4,700 residents exiting the town calmly along with visitors despite being trapped in gridlock and hot, smoky air for hours.\n\nEvacuees were initially ordered to go to British Columbia but were directed on Tuesday to make a wide U-turn as that province was dealing with its own wildfires.\n\nSince then, reception centres have been set up north of Jasper in Grande Prairie as well as in Calgary and Edmonton, where evacuees are being helped with accommodations.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse says she feels relieved to have made it to Grande Prairie after having been on the road for nearly 20 hours but she is worried about how the wildfires will affect her town.\n\nThe Canadian Press", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Some residents of Jasper National Park who were trapped in traffic for hours while evacuating due to wildfires say they are feeling relieved they've found safety. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Jeff McIntoshEDMONTON - Parks officials say one of two wildfires bearing down on the Jasper, Alta., townsite has reached the southern outskirts of the community. All first responders have been ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate. Two fires whipped by strong winds are bearing down on the town, from the north and the south. Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said the southern one reached the outskirts of the townsite just before 6 p.m. A last-ditch effort to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed. About 5,000 live in Jasper, and they, along with about 20,000 visitors, had to flee at a moment's notice Monday night when the fires flared up. As a bus carries her out of the town, which has since been evacuated, she films burnt landscapes surrounding an intact but empty Jasper townsite.\n\nBy Thursday morning, the town had suffered \"significant\" damage from the wildfire.\n\nParks Canada says that approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the town of Jasper and Jasper National Park. No injuries have been reported, and all residents, visitors and responders are said to be safe.\n\nThe situation rapidly escalated, from the first report of a wildfire starting to the northeast of the town of Jasper on Monday evening to a second fire south of town shortly after. Within 48 hours, the wildfires reached the Jasper townsite.\n\nJasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight, and while it helped to reduce fire activity, it was not enough to have made a meaningful impact.\n\nWhile Parks Canada has not yet confirmed the extent of the damage as fires are still burning in the town, Premier Danielle Smith told reporters Thursday afternoon that Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nPreliminary reports indicate a third and possibly up to half the structures in the town of Jasper have been destroyed in a wildfire, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said in an update on Thursday afternoon.\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said at a press conference in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW Damage to Jasper National Park still unknown\n\nThe damage to homes and infrastructure from the wildfires is still being evaluated, Jasper National Parks officials said in a statement posted to X.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures,\" officials wrote, adding that no injuries have been reported as a result of the Jasper wildfire.\n\nThe park received a small amount of rain overnight on Wednesday, but it was \"not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way. Late into Wednesday evening, Minister of Emergency Preparedness Harjit Sajjan posted on X that he had \"approved a request from Alberta to provide immediate and urgent support from the Federal Government to protect people and homes in Jasper and communities across Alberta.\"\n\nWildfire in Jasper prompts evacuations\n\nAbout 25,000 people have been forced to flee from Jasper, Alta. as wildfires have torn through the iconic town known for its hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nEveryone in Jasper National Park, including tourists, hikers and residents, were ordered to evacuate late Monday evening as wildfires overtook escape routes to the east and south. Pictures posted to social media showed long, snaking lines of cars and trucks heading westward to B.C.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAt 7:10 p.m. (MT) on Wednesday evening, portions of the southern fire in Jasper reached the townsite, according to Jasper National Park's updates. Nearly an hour later, air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others \"without self contained breathing apparatuses\" had to evacuate Jasper to the nearby town of Hinton.\n\nVideos posted to social media showed charred streets and homes, covered in black soot and swirling smoke.\n\nThis story is developing. {"uri": "8241927812", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:48:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:48:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:42:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13669429/Park-rangers-Canada-search-stragglers-evacuation-zone-two-big-wildfires.html", "title": "Park rangers in Canada search for stragglers in evacuation zone of...", "body": "GRAND PRAIRIE, Alberta (AP) - Park rangers scoured the Canadian Rockies' largest national park in helicopters Wednesday to look for stragglers still inside despite a mass evacuation aiming to move 25,000 visitors and residents away from two large wildfires.\n\nSearchers looking through the backcountry trails of Jasper National Park already had picked up 245 people, and they continued the search Wednesday in two helicopters, Parks Canada Incident Commander Katie Ellsworth said.\n\nAs many as 15,000 people were believed to be in the park and 10,000 in the neighboring town of Jasper late Monday when authorities issued an alert asking everyone in the area to evacuate. Residents and visitors streamed out by the thousands late Monday and Tuesday, and officials said Wednesday the evacuation of Jasper was complete.\n\nEllsworth said park officials expected the evacuation of the park's backcountry areas to be completed later Wednesday. Reservations are required for the park, so authorities have an idea of where people are, though Ellsworth said she wasn't immediately sure how many people were left.\n\nImages shared on social media showed long lines of vehicles, their headlights glowing, inching through swirling tendrils of smoke.\n\nAddison McNeill, 24, said she had just moved to Jasper from the Alberta capital of Edmonton when she got the stressful alert Monday night to evacuate. Thousands of Jasper's 4,700 full-time residents left in vehicles but were trapped in gridlock and hot, smoky air for hours.\n\nA reception centre is readied for wildfire evacuees forced from Jasper National Park in Calgary, Alta., Tuesday, July 23, 2024. (Jeff McIntosh/The Canadian Press via AP)\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes, and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nA fire to the northeast cut off highway access east to Edmonton. Another fire roaring up from the south forced the closure of the north-south Icefields Parkway. That left one route open, going west to British Columbia.\n\nBut Alberta fire officials said British Columbia had its hands full with its own evacuations. Alberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis said reception centers were instead being set up in Grande Prairie and Calgary in Alberta, requiring long detours through British Columbia by the drivers fleeing Jasper.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. About 170 wildfires were burning across the province.\n\nEllsworth said the north fire, spanning about 272 hectares, is about 5 kilometers (3 miles) from Jasper. She said the south fire, about 10,800 hectares, is about 8 kilometers (about 5 miles) from the town.\n\nRain was expected into Thursday but not enough to control the fires, with no word yet on when people could return, Ellsworth said.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse was relieved but exhausted after reaching the Grand Prairie evacuation center following 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\n\"We\u00b4re just waiting to go back home and see how many days we\u00b4re going to be stuck here,\" Joyeuse said.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nThis photo provided by Carolyn Campbell shows cars clogging the highway as people evacuate because of wildfires early Tuesday, July 23, 2024, in Jasper, Alberta. Multiple wildfires in Canada's Jasper National Park have flared up, forcing all park visitors along with the 4,700 residents of the Jasper townsite to flee. (Carolyn Campbell/The Canadian Press via AP)\n\nA reception center is readied for wildfire evacuees forced from Jasper National Park in Calgary, Alberta, Canada, Tuesday, July 23, 2024. (Jeff McIntosh/The Canadian Press via AP)\n\nA reception center is readied for wildfire evacuees forced from Jasper National Park in Calgary, Alberta, Canada, Tuesday, July 23, 2024. (Jeff McIntosh/The Canadian Press via AP)\n\nA reception centre is readied for wildfire evacuees forced from Jasper National Park in Calgary, Alta., Tuesday, July 23, 2024. {"uri": "8243718392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:35:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:35:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:34:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/687394/international/forest-fire-reaches-town-in-canadian-national-park", "title": "Forest fire reaches town in Canadian national park", "body": "In this image courtesy of Le Minh Khue, visitors evacuate Jasper National Park in Canada due to a wildfire. - AFP A raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper and firefighters were working yesterday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta.\n\nThe town and the park, which draw more than 2mn tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, saying that the fire was still out of control.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage or which areas had been hit.\n\nVideo from the town showed entire blocks had burned to the ground, including a church.\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of a fire that had ravaged the community.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension,\" he said in a letter to residents.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire reaches the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said on Wednesday that his government had approved a request by Alberta province for federal assistance.\n\n\"We're deploying @CanadianForces resources, evacuations support, and more emergency wildfire resources to the province immediately - and we're co-ordinating firefighting and airlift assistance,\" Trudeau wrote on X.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\nThere are 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control.\n\nAround 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where dozens of fires are also out of control.\n\n\"Many of the wildfires we're seeing at this time of year are lightning caused and we unfortunately can't control the weather,\" said Alberta forestry minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada.\n\nOfficials said that at one point on Wednesday the flames had reached a height of 120m (400') and were moving at 15m (50') a minute.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said that the fire had reached its grounds.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents.\n\nThe blaze destroyed 10% of all structures in the city.", "source": {"uri": "gulf-times.com", The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nParks Canada said firefighters are working to save \"as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, many first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety.\n\nJasper is being menaced by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 more park visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said they are \"mobilizing every necessary resource available.\" Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken.\"\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the U.S., leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted 5 kilometers (about 3 miles) from Jasper earlier in the day. The fire continues to burn,\" Parks Canada spokesperson James Eastham said outside Jasper overnight.\n\nOn X, the account for the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge says the flames have reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, is not yet known.\n\nKatie Ellsworth, of Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent the south wildfire racing into the community.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the US, leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. {"uri": "8242047964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:51:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:51:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:50:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.burnslakelakesdistrictnews.com/national-news/growing-wildfires-menacing-historic-jasper-townsite-from-2-directions-7456220", "title": "Growing wildfires, menacing historic Jasper townsite from 2 directions", "body": "No critical infrastructure damaged since 25,000 people fled the area Monday evening\n\nFuelled by whipping winds, fires in Jasper National Park bore down from two directions Wednesday on the historic Rocky Mountain townsite of Jasper.\n\nParks Canada said a wildfire to the north was five kilometres away while another approaching from the south was eight kilometres distant.\n\nNo critical infrastructure in Jasper had been damaged since the fires roared out of control late Monday night, forcing 25,000 people - park visitors and all of the 5,000 Jasper residents - to flee.\n\nCrews scrambled to protect homes in Jasper.\n\nThey began work to bulldoze a fireguard on the town's southern edge. They went house to house in Jasper clearing flammables. Massive sprinklers were being set up.\n\nParks Canada official Katie Ellsworth said the southern blaze had doubled in size to more than 100 square kilometres.\n\n\"All our efforts are focused on controlling further fire spread and protecting our community,\" Ellsworth told reporters.\n\n\"We expect today that we're going to have strong winds continuing, and we expect that this will increase our fire behaviour and fire growth on both fires on all flanks.\"\n\nOfficials could not accurately update what was happening to infrastructure outside the townsite along the Icefields Parkway and Highway 16, such as picnic areas or power lines, because of smoky conditions.\n\nWith fire perimeters changing minute-by-minute, Ellsworth said the flames were about 2.5 kilometres from the Valley of the Five Lakes, a popular hiking spot.\n\nThe fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south on Monday night, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nEllsworth has said that it only took two hours between the first reports of fires starting in the area on Monday until they had become huge enough to spark the need for the overnight evacuation.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill didn't reach Grand Prairie until Tuesday evening.\n\nThe centre has helped 50 evacuees since Monday night and 20 of them were staying in hotels, said Dan Lemieux, with the City of Grande Prairie.\n\n\"In addition to the evacuees from Jasper, we have several evacuees here from the First Nations that are further north in Alberta that have been evacuated,\" he said.\n\nJasper resident Leanne Maeva Joyeuse said she felt relieved to have made it to Grande Prairie after 20 hours on the road with her grandmother, parents and younger brother.\n\nShe said she was anxious about how the wildfires would affect her town, but laughed as she recalled that her grandmother had just arrived from Mauritius to visit a few days before the wildfires began.\n\nShe recalled turning to her grandmother as they fled to say, \"Welcome to Alberta.\"\n\nREAD ALSO: Town of Jasper, national park under evacuation alert due to wildfire", "source": The fire continues to burn,\" Parks Canada spokesperson James Eastham said outside Jasper overnight.\n\nOn X, the account for the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge says the flames have reached the hotel's grounds, but the extent of damage, if any, is not yet known.\n\nKatie Ellsworth, of Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent the south wildfire racing into the community.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the US, leading to hazy skies and health advisories in multiple U.S. cities.\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people out of remote communities. {"uri": "8243819977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:47:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:47:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:46:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/jasper-wildfires-more-than-400-foreign-firefighters-on-the-way-up-to-half-the-town/article_28adb81c-4ab0-11ef-aaa1-43e944b69f7d.html", "title": "Jasper wildfires: More than 400 foreign firefighters on the way, up to half the town may have been destroyed", "body": "One of Canada's most famous national parks is burning.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nPreliminary reports indicate a third and possibly up to half the structures in the town of Jasper have been destroyed in a wildfire, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said in an update on Thursday afternoon.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau posted on X Thursday afternoon that more than 400 firefighters from Australia, New Zealand, Mexico and South Africa are en route to Alberta to help quell the flames. The additional support is expected to arrive this weekend.\n\nHe later convened the Incident Response Group -- a committee of ministers and senior government officials who co-ordinate the federal government's response in emergency situations -- with Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland, Emergency Preparedness Minister Harjit Sajjan, Treasury Board President Anita Anand, Defence Minister Bill Blair, Public Safety Minister Dominic LeBlanc, and Citizens' Services Minister Terry Beech.\n\nFollowing the meeting, Sajjan, who travelled to Edmonton Thursday, held a press conference with his Alberta counterpart Mike Ellis, who said no number of firefighters could have tamed the growing walls of flame that were travelling at rapid speeds.\n\nIn a show of cross-jurisdictional unity, Ellis commended Sajjan and Trudeau for their responsiveness, saying the prime minister had been \"engaged\" and ensured all fires in the province -- not just Jasper -- received the necessary resources. The federal government has already approved the Alberta government's request for military aid.\n\nAlberta government to provide daily updates on Jasper fire\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said, holding back tears, at a press conference in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nStrong winds are expected to raise the fire risk in the northeast and south of the province, where danger from the wildfires is still \"extreme,\" Alberta Wildfire information unit manager Christie Tucker said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAlberta currently has 176 active wildfires, with 54 classified as \"out of control,\" Tucker said.\n\nCanada In photos: Tragic scenes from Jasper unfold as wildfire leaves trail of destruction\n\nThe fire reached Jasper on Wednesday evening and has begun ravaging the town, with a third of it destroyed.\n\nSmith said her government will move to providing daily updates with the province's minister of forestry and parks and its minister of public safety.\n\n\"Alberta stands ready to assist in every way that we can,\" Smith said, adding that she had asked LeBlanc to establish a \"unified command structure\" to co-ordinate the response to the wildfire.\n\n\"Alberta's government will provide the support needed to families and communities to recover and to rebuild stronger than ever, so that future generations can continue to experience this one-of-a-kind community.\"\n\nDamage to Jasper National Park still unknown\n\nThe damage to homes and infrastructure from the wildfires is still being evaluated, Jasper National Parks officials said in a statement posted to X.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures,\" officials wrote, adding that no injuries have been reported as a result of the Jasper wildfire.\n\nThe park received a small amount of rain overnight on Wednesday, but it was \"not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nHome phone and mobility services in the area were also impacted by the fires, Telus Corp. confirmed to The Canadian Press on Thursday. Priority was being given to restoring voice calls, including those to emergency services.\n\nCanadian National Railway Co., whose main line runs through Jasper, suspended its operations in the area on Wednesday.\n\nWildfire in Jasper prompts evacuations\n\nAbout 25,000 people have been forced to flee from Jasper, Alta. as wildfires have torn through the iconic town known for its hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland wrote in a post to Facebook on Thursday. \"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension; my deepest sympathies go out to each of you.\"\n\n\"This experience is tremendously traumatic for each of us and for the community. I encourage you to reach out to your neighbours, colleagues and friends: share your grief; share your pain; stay connected,\" he added. \"Offer a helping hand, a listening ear, a supportive word where you can, and know that we are all in this together.\"\n\nEveryone in Jasper National Park, including tourists, hikers and residents, were ordered to leave the area late Monday evening as wildfires overtook escape routes to the east and south. Pictures posted to social media showed long, snaking lines of cars and trucks heading westward to B.C.\n\nEvacuees were then directed to make a U-turn as B.C. grapples with wildfires and evacuations of its own.\n\n\"(B.C.) had no capacity to house Albertans,\" Stephen Lacroix, managing director of the Alberta Emergency Management Agency, said on Tuesday.\n\nAt 7:10 p.m. (MT) on Wednesday evening, portions of the southern fire in Jasper reached the townsite, according to Jasper National Park's updates. Nearly an hour later, air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others \"without self-contained breathing apparatuses\" had to leave Jasper for the nearby town of Hinton.\n\nVideos posted to social media showed charred streets and homes, covered in black soot and swirling smoke.\n\nWith files from The Canadian Press.", "source": {"uri": "thestar.com", {"uri": "8243506416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:01:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:01:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:00:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/national-news/2024/07/25/alberta-premier-fights-back-tears-promises-help-as-jasper-devastated-by-fire/", "title": "Alberta premier fights back tears, promises help as Jasper devastated by fire - Medicine Hat News", "body": "A wildfire burns as an empty street in Jasper, Alta. is shown in this Wednesday, July 24, 2024 handout photo from the Jasper National Park Facebook page. THE CANADIAN PRESS/HO, Facebook, Jasper National Park *MANDATORY CREDIT*JASPER, ALTA. - Alberta Premier Danielle Smith fought back tears Thursday as she sought to console Jasper residents coming to terms with a community devastated by wildfire. \"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\"\u009d Smith said at a fire update in Edmonton. \"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\u009d Specifics on what has been destroyed in the Rocky Mountain resort town of 5,000 remained sketchy. Jasper Park officials, in a statement, said the firefighting situation remains dynamic. \"Due to the ongoing fire conditions and our focus on the response effort, it is impossible to share information about specific locations and the extent of damage at this time,\"\u009d said the statement. \"The accuracy of this information is critical because it has a direct impact on members of the community. We will share more information as soon as we are able to ensure its accuracy.\"\u009d Photos shared on social media Wednesday night depicted Jasper structures wrapped in sheets of flame. A video Thursday morning showed rain-slicked streets, cloudy skies and a wide swath of blackened, charred homes and buildings razed to their foundations. \"The images we're seeing out of Jasper are devastating,\"\u009d said Forestry Minister Todd Loewen. The province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way. Calgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park, said they were sending resources to the fire scene. The staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park. In Hinton Thursday morning, rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck. Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, urged them to stay strong. \"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\"\u009d Ireland wrote. \"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension. \"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\u009d About 25,000 people, including about 5,000 residents in the Jasper townsite, were forced to flee west at a moment's notice late Monday night as twin wildfires from the south and north roared up and cut off access to the east and south. A day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist. On Wednesday, efforts to contain the fires -- include buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by raging, gusting winds. Around 6 p.m. Wednesday, the fire roared in and began torching structures. Jasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984. {"uri": "8243625934", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:57:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:57:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:56:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/jasper-wildfires-as-much-as-a-third-of-town-may-have-been-destroyed-alberta-premier/article_28adb81c-4ab0-11ef-aaa1-43e944b69f7d.html", "title": "Jasper Wildfires: As much as a third of town may have been destroyed, Alberta premier says", "body": "Here's the latest on the battle against wildfires in Alberta as of Thursday.\n\nOne of Canada's most famous national parks is burning.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nPreliminary reports indicate a third and possibly up to half the structures in the town of Jasper have been destroyed in a wildfire, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said in an update on Thursday afternoon.\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said, holding back tears, at a press conference in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nStrong winds are expected to raise the fire risk in the northeast and south of the province, where danger from the wildfires is still \"extreme,\" Alberta Wildfire information unit manager Christie Tucker said.\n\nAlberta currently has 176 active wildfires, with 54 classified as \"out of control,\" Tucker said.\n\nDamage to Jasper National Park still unknown\n\nThe damage to homes and infrastructure from the wildfires is still being evaluated, Jasper National Parks officials said in a statement posted to X.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures,\" officials wrote, adding that no injuries have been reported as a result of the Jasper wildfire.\n\nThe park received a small amount of rain overnight on Wednesday, but it was \"not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way. Late into Wednesday evening, Minister of Emergency Preparedness Harjit Sajjan posted on X that he had \"approved a request from Alberta to provide immediate and urgent support from the Federal Government to protect people and homes in Jasper and communities across Alberta.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHome hone and mobility services in the area were also impacted by the fires, Telus Corp. confirmed to the Canadian Press on Thursday. Priority was being given to restoring voice calls, including those to emergency services.\n\nCanadian National Railway Co., whose main line runs through Jasper, suspended its operations in the area on Wednesday.\n\nWildfire in Jasper prompts evacuations\n\nAbout 25,000 people have been forced to flee from Jasper, Alta. as wildfires have torn through the iconic town known for its hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland wrote in a post to Facebook on Thursday. \"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension; my deepest sympathies go out to each of you.\"\n\n\"This experience is tremendously traumatic for each of us and for the community. I encourage you to reach out to your neighbours, colleagues and friends: share your grief; share your pain; stay connected,\" he added. \"Offer a helping hand, a listening ear, a supportive word where you can, and know that we are all in this together.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nEveryone in Jasper National Park, including tourists, hikers and residents, were ordered to leave the area late Monday evening as wildfires overtook escape routes to the east and south. Pictures posted to social media showed long, snaking lines of cars and trucks heading westward to B.C.\n\nEvacuees were then directed to make a U-turn as B.C. grapples with wildfires and evacuations of its own.\n\n\"(B.C.) had no capacity to house Albertans,\" Stephen Lacroix, managing director of the Alberta Emergency Management Agency, said on Tuesday.\n\nAt 7:10 p.m. (MT) on Wednesday evening, portions of the southern fire in Jasper reached the townsite, according to Jasper National Park's updates. Nearly an hour later, air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others \"without self contained breathing apparatuses\" had to leave Jasper for the nearby town of Hinton.\n\nVideos posted to social media showed charred streets and homes, covered in black soot and swirling smoke.\n\nThis story is developing. {"uri": "2024-07-432872207", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "06:16:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T06:16:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T05:43:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://chatnewstoday.ca/2024/07/24/multiple-structures-ablaze-as-wildfire-roars-into-jasper-townsite/", "title": "Multiple structures ablaze as wildfire roars into Jasper townsite", "body": "Some fire crews were ordered out as the battle switched from the forest to the streets.\n\n\"(The) air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses needed to evacuate to Hinton,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThat launched a line of cars and trucks snaking east to the town of Hinton, outside the park gates.\n\nJasper was under attack by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 park visitors -- have already left.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong earlier Wednesday did go wrong.\n\nFire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nThe 25,000 fled at a moment's notice two nights earlier.\n\nThe order to go went out around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nJasper National Park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is considered a national and international treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIt has hosted glitz and glitter. In 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelor\" was filmed there.\n\nJasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nIt is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.", "source": {"uri": "chatnewstoday.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8243657797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:29:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:29:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:28:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cp24.com/news/alberta-premier-says-a-third-perhaps-half-of-all-jasper-buildings-destroyed-by-fire-1.6976943", "title": "Alberta premier says a third, perhaps half, of all Jasper buildings destroyed by fire", "body": "Alberta Premier Danielle Smith says early reports indicate a third and perhaps up to half of all buildings in the historic Rocky Mountain resort town of Jasper have burned in a wildfire.\n\n\"You've seen the images as I have,\" Smith said Thursday.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30 to 50 per cent structural damage to give you some idea.\n\n\"We don't know which structures have been damaged and which ones have been destroyed, but that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nSmith made the comments after fighting back tears at a news conference as she sought to console residents who were evacuated from the townsite and now face significant hardship when they return.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it,\" Smith said.\n\n\"And to those in Alberta and around the world who have experienced the magic of Jasper: The magic is not lost, and it never will be.\"\n\nParks Canada, in a statement said it will provide details on lost structures when it can accurately and responsibly confirm what burned. But it says crews continue to battle a swift and dynamic fire in Jasper National Park.\n\n\"Jasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight,\" said the statement.\n\n\"While the rain helped reduce fire activity slightly, it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nImages surfacing on social media depicted blocks of homes and businesses burned to charred foundations and vehicles torched to the hubcaps.\n\nCalgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park dispatched resources to the fire scene.\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way.\n\nThe staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nIn Hinton Thursday rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, said, \"In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nAbout 20,000 park visitors and the 5,000 residents of the Jasper municipality had to flee on a moment's notice Monday night ahead of two wildfires that cut off road access everywhere but west to British Columbia.\n\nA day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist.\n\nThose without a place to stay have been directed to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nCrews lost the fight to save Jasper Wednesday just after 6 p.m., as waves of orange and red breached the southern outskirts and began devouring homes and livelihoods.\n\nFrantic efforts to contain the fires -- including buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by high winds.\n\n\"That wind gust moved that fire five kilometres in probably less than 30 minutes, with a wall of fire that was about 100 metres high,\" said Alberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"There is little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that.\"\n\n\"Nobody anticipated that fire to come so fast, so large and so quickly.\"\n\nPierre Martel, who oversees fire management with Parks Canada, echoed Ellis.\n\n\"There are no tools we have in our toolbox to deal with that,\" Martel told an online news conference.\n\n\"It's just a monster at that point.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.", "source": {"uri": "cp24.com", {"uri": "8243249443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:45:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:45:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:44:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cheknews.ca/jasper-wildfire-burns-buildings-while-poor-air-quality-forces-some-fire-crews-out-1215895/", "title": "Jasper wildfire burns buildings, while poor air quality forces some fire crews out", "body": "Alberta's Jasper National Park and its townsite are under siege from two wind-whipped wildfires, one of which raced into the picturesque community on Wednesday night, causing extensive damage.\n\nParks Canada says the fire has caused significant losses within the town, and the social media account for Fairmont's famous Jasper Park Lodge says the flames had reached the hotel's grounds.\n\nAs the fire consumed more fuel, officials said the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to flee to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nPhotos on social media show lodges and other buildings wrapped in sheets of orange flame.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance. Alberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked for help from the Canadian military.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nEarlier in the day, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThe fires are burning on the north and south sides of the town, which is home to 5,000 people. The residents have left, along with 20,000 park visitors.\n\nThe order to leave was issued around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to Jasper. Residents and visitors fled west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight procession through swirling smoke and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make the long drive around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday. The southern fire was farther away, but Parks Canada says strong winds sent it racing toward the town.\n\nThat forced crews using heavy equipment to pull back for safety. Water bombers were grounded due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled arriving in Jasper from Edmonton only to be told to get out.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" the 24-year-old said in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said she went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.", "source": {"uri": "cheknews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CHEK"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jasper_National_Park", {"uri": "2024-07-432552035", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:46:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:46:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:20:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://dailyhive.com/calgary/jasper-fire-update-size-today-structures", "title": "Parks Canada says Jasper wildfires have impacted some structures", "body": "Officials in Jasper National Park say two wildfires currently burning in the park have impacted some structures and infrastructure.\n\nAccording to a post on its Facebook page, the park says there have been some impacts to structures and infrastructure on the Icefields Parkway and along Highway 16. The exact details of these losses have not yet been confirmed as conditions have not permitted accurate assessment.\n\nThere have been no impacts to the town of Jasper itself.\n\n\"Parks Canada will share further information on structure losses once an assessment has been conducted. Individuals and businesses who have been impacted will be contacted directly by Parks Canada,\" it added.\n\nAn update was also given on the size of the wildfires impacting the area. The north wildfire is estimated at 270 hectares and is approximately five kilometres from the town of Jasper, located between the Transfer Station and the Jasper Air Strip on both sides of Highway 16.\n\nThe south wildfire is estimated at 10,800 hectares and approximately eight km from the town of Jasper.\n\nParks Canada added that both fires currently pose a threat to the town of Jasper. All efforts are focused on containing further spread and protecting the community, and no timeline can be given for a re-entry plan.\n\nLooking at fire activity, the post said that winds have been consistently high and gusty, and there was significant fire activity and spread overnight. Similar windy conditions are expected today and further growth is anticipated.", "source": {"uri": "dailyhive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "dailyhive.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242006340", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:04:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:04:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:02:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/canada/wildfire-spreads-closer-to-jasper-townsite/article_563b3bba-5e68-5bf6-9f0f-0888b1464dbd.html", "title": "Wildfire spreads closer to Jasper townsite", "body": "By Jessica Lee, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter Rocky Mountain Outlook\n\nWildfires burning north and south of Jasper National Park's townsite are closing in as Parks Canada incident management teams focus on protecting visitors and residents still remaining in the park, as well as critical infrastructure.\n\nIn the latest update, Parks Canada officials said the larger wildfire south of the Jasper townsite grew overnight Tuesday (July 23) to 10,800 hectares and is now about eight kilometres away. A 270-hectare fire five kilometres north of the mountain town is also still classified as out-of-control, but has not grown since Tuesday.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nA perfect storm of a lightning outbreak Monday night that is believed to have ignited the fires, exceptional heat and dryness, and high winds led to what wildfire officials are calling \"aggressive, blow-up fire behaviour.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We did see some aggressive fire behaviour during the day [Tuesday] and that fire behaviour did continue throughout the night,\" said Katie Ellsworth, a fire management officer with the Jasper field unit.\n\nAbout 260 firefighters, two water tankers, one off-road water supply, 13 fire trucks and nine aircraft have kept fires from touching the townsite but Parks Canada has confirmed damage to infrastructure along the Icefield Parkway, otherwise known as Highway 93.\n\nExtent of the damage is still being assessed as heavy smoke clears.\n\n\"Once we are able to access the area safely, either from the air or from the ground, we will provide further information on structural loss once those impact assessments are complete,\" said Ellsworth.\n\n\"We can confirm that there is infrastructure down there that consists of Parks Canada facilities, campgrounds, day-use areas, washroom facilities, picnic areas, as well as power lines. But again, we can't confirm at this time what's been impinged or impacted and the level or extent of those impacts.\"\n\nParks Canada said so far 245 people in the backcountry have been flown out by helicopter and evacuations are progressing. Parks also confirmed in a Tuesday update that everyone had been evacuated from the Jasper townsite, however, there are still some remaining who are not responding to wildfires.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nJasper Mayor Ken Ireland said those people include a well-known local caterer - Glenda the Great Catering Ltd. - helping to feed first responders, as well as municipal staff dealing with infrastructure needs.\n\n\"I can't give you an entire list, but you get the picture; it's a select, small number and they are doing the work that needs to be done to support the first responders and others who have remained in the community for essential work,\" he said.\n\nThe wildfire north of the townsite is located between the transfer station and Jasper airstrip, and is burning on both sides of Highway 16. The south wildfire is located near Kerkeslin Campground and follows Highway 93 north to Horseshoe Lake.\n\n\"This wildfire crosses Highway 93 a few kilometres south of Wabasso Campground and the northeast extent of this wildfire is near Wabasso Lake,\" said Ellsworth, who noted Parks is working hard to keep fires from reaching the townsite.\n\nThe federal agency currently has its incident management team fighting the fires, with support from Alberta Wildfire and the Alberta Emergency Management Agency.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nFire crews are removing flammable vegetation within the boundary of the Jasper community, with officials also removing and cleaning properties of combustibles such as propane tanks.\n\nA high-volume 12-inch sprinkler system is also being deployed at the southern part of the townsite. Parks is assessing where to create fireguards using heavy equipment.\n\n\"Fire specialists are currently planning those lines out. I anticipate those plans will be ready by the end of this afternoon, so that we can start putting in those containment features to the southern flank or wherever they get planned - most likely in the southern portion of the community,\" said Ellsworth.\n\n\"We are also planning other sprinkler lines up towards the western flank of our community, near the Pyramid Bench area. That's going to extend from west to east to protect the properties and the infrastructure up there.\"\n\nCritical infrastructure, including water and wasterwater facilities, backup generators, the 911 dispatch centre, as well as locations for the Parks Canada's incident command staff are already protected with sprinkler systems.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nParks is also working with CN Rail to patrol tracks north of the townsite with specialized water traincars, extinguishing spot fires and cooling down areas along the tracks so the company can continue rail operations.\n\n\"This is a dynamic and evolving situation. Things are changing minute-to-minute,\" said Ellsworth.\n\nParks Canada said its evacuation team, which has one to two helicopters at its disposal, will continue to evacuate backcountry visitors throughout the day Wednesday (July 24).\n\nEllsworth could not confirm how many registered backcountry users were still in the national park, but said that information is known to the evacuation team. She noted rescuers are now directing attention to lower priority areas such as the Brazeau, and north and south boundary trails, which are lower priority due to distance from the active wildfire area.\n\nAs the situation progresses, those remaining in the townsite not responding to the wildfires will also continue to be kept informed of fire danger and encouraged to evacuate if risk to safety increases.\n\nThe Municipality of Jasper said an after-action review of how evacuations were handled will also take place once there is capacity. It was reported that some who were subscribed to the alert system used - Voyent Alert - did not receive notification to evacuate.\n\nThere was also mixed messaging Monday (July 22), at the time of the evacuation alert, around 10 p.m., about how soon the fire was expected to reach the Jasper townsite.\n\nIt was first reported via an Alberta Emergency Alert that fire would encroach on the town within five hours. This was corrected about 45 minutes later to state residents had five hours to evacuate.\n\nIreland said it is not yet known how the miscommunication happened.\n\n\"The short answer is, we don't yet know how that error occurred. We do know that, as soon as it was identified, it was corrected,\" he said.\n\n\"For a mistake of that nature, although in the long run, it may have increased levels of anxiety of people, it did not negatively impact the evacuation of the town.\"\n\nParks Canada wildfire officials noted this is one of the largest wildfire events in Jasper National Park's recorded history at over 10,000 hectares burned, so far. The Chetamon wildfire of 2022 burned about 6,000 hectares.", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": Evacuations in the backcountry are ongoing and complete in high priority areas,\" it said.\n\n\"Our highest priorities are to protect the town of Jasper and limit wildfire growth towards the town, Highway 16, and critical infrastructure.\"\n\nEllsworth said the north fire, spanning about 272 hectares (672 acres), is about 5km (three miles) from Jasper while the south fire, about 10,800 hectares (26,600 acres), is some 8km (about five miles) away.\n\nRain was expected into Thursday but not enough to control the blazes, with no word yet on when people could return, she added.\n\nPhotos and videos shared on social media overnight from Monday to Tuesday showed a line of bumper-to-bumper cars and trucks crawling through smoke to try to get out of the area.\n\nThe Canadian government warned Calgary residents on Wednesday morning that wildfire smoke was causing \"very poor air quality and reduced visibility\".\n\n\"During heavy smoke conditions, everyone is at risk regardless of their age or health. The fine particles in wildfire smoke pose the main health risk,\" it said in a weather advisory.\n\nIn April, federal officials said Canada risked another \"catastrophic\" wildfire season amid higher-than-normal spring and summer temperatures across much of the country.\n\nLast year, the country experienced a record fire season that saw more than 6,600 wildfires burn 15 million hectares (37 million acres).\n\nExperts have said that climate change has extended the Canadian wildfire season and made it easier for blazes to start and spread.", "source": {"uri": "tv360nigeria.com",
