{"uri": "2024-07-433630045", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:08:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:08:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T09:14:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/alberta-premier-fights-back-tears-promises-help-as-jasper-devastated-by-fire-1.6976942", "title": "Alberta premier fights back tears, promises help as Jasper devastated by fire", "body": "Alberta Premier Danielle Smith fought back tears Thursday as she sought to console Jasper residents coming to terms with a community devastated by wildfire.\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said at a fire update in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nSpecifics on what has been destroyed in the Rocky Mountain resort town of 5,000 remained sketchy.\n\nJasper Park officials, in a statement, said the firefighting situation remains dynamic.\n\n\"Due to the ongoing fire conditions and our focus on the response effort, it is impossible to share information about specific locations and the extent of damage at this time,\" said the statement.\n\n\"The accuracy of this information is critical because it has a direct impact on members of the community. We will share more information as soon as we are able to ensure its accuracy.\"\n\nPhotos shared on social media Wednesday night depicted Jasper structures wrapped in sheets of flame.\n\nA video Thursday morning showed rain-slicked streets, cloudy skies and a wide swath of blackened, charred homes and buildings razed to their foundations.\n\n\"The images we're seeing out of Jasper are devastating,\" said Forestry Minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way.\n\nCalgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park, said they were sending resources to the fire scene.\n\nThe staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nIn Hinton Thursday morning, rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, urged them to stay strong.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Ireland wrote.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nAbout 25,000 people, including about 5,000 residents in the Jasper townsite, were forced to flee west at a moment's notice late Monday night as twin wildfires from the south and north roared up and cut off access to the east and south.\n\nA day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist.\n\nOn Wednesday, efforts to contain the fires -- include buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by raging, gusting winds.\n\nAround 6 p.m. Wednesday, the fire roared in and began torching structures.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. {"uri": "2024-07-433655492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:41:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:41:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:41:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "http://www.tap.info.tn/en/Portal-World/17718712-devastating", "title": "Devastating wildfire burns down part of western Canadian town", "body": "July 25 (TAP) - A raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper and firefighters were working on Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draw more than 2 million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, saying the fire was still out of control.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage or which areas had been hit.\n\nVideo from the town showed entire blocks had burned to the ground, including a church.\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of a fire that had ravaged the community.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension,\" he said in a letter to residents.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire reaches the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\n'END OF AN ERA'\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where dozens of fires are also out of control.\n\n\"Many of the wildfires we're seeing at this time of year are lightning caused and we unfortunately can't control the weather,\" said Alberta forestry minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada.\n\nOfficials said that at one point on Wednesday the flames had reached a height of 400 feet and were moving at 15 meters (50 feet) a minute.\n\nAshley Kliewer, co-owner of a restaurant in the middle of Jasper, told the Canadian Broadcasting crop she was devastated.\n\n\"I don't think anyone will be returning to Jasper any time soon and life is not going to be anywhere near what it was - it really is the end of an era,\" she said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents. The blaze destroyed 10% of all structures in the city and shut in more than a million barrels per day of oil output.\n\nFort McMurray is forecast to receive up to 65 mm of rain in the next day, {"uri": "8243667594", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:41:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:41:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:38:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/monster-wildfire-may-destroyed-50-203446836.html", "title": "'Monster' wildfire may have destroyed up to 50% of Canadian town", "body": "A Canadian resort town has been devastated by a raging wildfire that officials say may have destroyed 30 to 50% of the municipality.\n\nThe fires in Jasper National Park, which were sparked earlier this week, forced about 25,000 people to flee the area earlier this week, officials said on Thursday.\n\nSome 400 firefighters from around the world are on their way to Canada to help battle the flames.\n\nOfficials warned that there are only limited details currently available on which structures were damaged, and that the focus is on containing the flames and preventing further destruction.\n\nStill, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said during an emotional press conference that the township of Jasper will require a \"significant rebuild\".\n\nJasper's mayor, Richard Ireland, said that the wildfire has \"ravaged our small, tight-knit mountain community\"\n\n\"To all of the responders on the ground in the town [and] in our home, words cannot express the admiration and the gratitude I have for your professionalism, dedication and their unyielding efforts.\"\n\nHe said his town is still coming to term with the wildfire.\n\nJasper National Park is the largest national park in the Canadian Rockies. The famous Rockies resort town of Jasper has about 5,000 residents, but the park had almost 2.5 million visitors last year.\n\nHundreds of firefighters are flying in to help with the efforts, including 100 firefighters from Jalisco, Mexico, 200 from South Africa and 100 from Australia and New Zealand.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau turned to social media to thank first responders for their response to the wildfires.\n\n\"As the heartbreaking images from Jasper emerge, I want to thank the brave first responders who are in Alberta right now, fighting to save every home and every community they can,\" he posted.\n\nPierre Martel, director for the national fire management programme at Parks Canada, said the fire was started by a lightning storm and escalated on Wednesday, fanned by powerful wind gusts.\n\n\"It [was] just a monster at that point,\" Mr Martel said. \"There are no tools we have in our tool box to deal with it\"\n\nThe fire reached 100m (328ft) high, covering \"an inordinate amount of space in a very little amount of time,\" one official said.\n\nMike Ellis, Alberta's minister for public safety, said the fire was 5km (3 miles) outside of Jasper when it was pushed by a powerful wind gust to the town in \"less than 30 minutes\".\n\n\"Any firefighter will tell you there is little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that,\" he said.\n\n\"Nobody anticipated that fire to come so fast, so large and so quickly.\"\n\nBBC journalist Wendy Hurrell was in Jasper National park with her husband and daughter when the fires began to burn on Monday.\n\nShe drove through the night in a rush to leave town.\n\n\"The storm was ferocious - the skies went dark red and there were whipping winds, fierce rain and lightning,\" she said.\n\n\"We are some of the last travellers to see Jasper in its full beauty - it will be a very long time before it will recover. It's utterly devastating for them all and my heart is breaking.\"\n\nEnvironment Canada said there might soon be a reprieve from the hot and dry weather, which allowed the fire to grow, as 1cm to 2cm (0.4in to 0.8in) of rain is expected on Thursday.\n\nThis marks another year of difficult fire conditions for the province. Last year, some 2.2 million hectares burned in Alberta between 1 March and 31 October.\n\nThe area burned during those wildfires was record breaking, officials said.\n\nOutside Alberta, fires are burning in California and Utah.\n\nScientists have longed pointed to human-led climate change as the cause of worsening natural disasters including wildfires.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", {"uri": "8243784929", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:01:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:01:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:58:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/world/2803865/", "title": "Canadian Rockies resort town of Jasper destroyed by fireExBulletin - ExBulletin", "body": "GRANDE PRAIRIE, Alberta A fast-moving wildfire in the Canadian Rockies that had prompted the evacuation of 25,000 people burned through the nearly deserted town of Jasper overnight with flames up to the treetops, destroying up to half of its structures, officials said. on Thursday.\n\nThere were no immediate reports of injuries following a mass evacuation of the scenic resort and neighboring national park earlier in the week, but Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland said in a letter on the city's website that the fire has devastated our beloved community. .\n\nThe devastation and loss you are facing and felt by many is beyond description and understanding, my deepest condolences go out to each and every one of you,\" he said.\n\nDanielle Smith, the premier of the province of Alberta, said between 30% and 50% of the city's structures were damaged or potentially destroyed, saying it would be significant rebuilding and significant displacement.\n\nSmith teared up talking about Jasper's beauty, noting that many families from the province visit regularly. A postcard-perfect mountain town, Jasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goat, puma, lynx, black bear and grizzly bear.\n\nWe share the sense of loss with everyone who lives in the city, Smith told a news conference in Edmonton, Alberta, as she pledged her government's support for the community to rebuild.\n\nJasper and neighboring Jasper National Park were threatened by fires from both the north and south, and the towns of 5,000 full-time residents -- along with 20,000 visitors -- were evacuated on short notice late Monday and Tuesday when the fires lit up.\n\nOne of the fires spread to the south end of the community Wednesday evening as firefighters tried to contain the damage.\n\nAlberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis said a wind carried the fire about 5 kilometers (about 3 miles) in perhaps less than 30 minutes toward the city with a wall of fire he estimated to be 100 meters high.\n\nPeople have to imagine what those fire people were experiencing at that time. Any firefighter will tell you there's little or nothing you can do when a wall of fire like that is coming your way, Ellis said. No one expected the fire to come so fast, so big.\n\nPierre Martel, director of fire management at Parks Canada, said lightning, winds and drought caused the fire to grow rapidly on Monday and that flames were above the treetops when he entered the city on Wednesday.\n\nIt's just a monster at that point. There are no tools we have in our toolbox to deal with that at that point. You get out of the way, you pull over, he said.\n\nParks Canada said in a post on X that there were no reported injuries, adding that \"Approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the City of Jasper and Jasper National Park. All residents, visitors and responders are safe.\"\n\nPark officials said efforts to fight the fire were continuing and that it was too early to give details of the damage. They asked for patience and said the fire remains out of control despite a small amount of rain that fell overnight.\n\nAnnelies Lagger, who has owned and lived in the Austrian Haven B&B for 30 years, said she is waiting to hear if it has been destroyed, but is not optimistic because all the nearby houses are gone. She said she ran away with her 13 cats and dog.\n\nI have no idea where to go now. Heaven or hell. It was my life. You can imagine how much work it was, she said. I think I'm in shock.\"\n\nShe said that relatives, including her daughter and son-in-law, had their houses destroyed. It was the heat that dried everything. And now the city is gone, she said.\n\nLagger had taken up with a kind stranger in Valemount, British Columbia, but said she will eventually have to find new homes for her family members and my pets.\n\nI am a very tough woman. Whatever happens, I start again even though I am 82 years old, she said.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau said his administration has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance, including military resources.\n\nJasper National Park is considered a national treasure. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its magnificent mountain scenery.\n\nAlberta has been baking under scorching temperatures that have already forced another 7,500 people to flee remote communities. About 176 fires are burning across the province, including 54 that are burning out of control.\n\nAlberta Forests and Parks Minister Todd Loewen said many of the fires were caused by lightning, and Alberta Fire spokeswoman Christie Tucker said firefighters expect winds to increase the danger.\n\nTucker said hundreds of firefighters from Australia, Mexico, New Zealand and South Africa are arriving to help fight fires across the province.\n\nA record number of wildfires in 2023 forced more than 235,000 people across Canada to evacuate and sent thick smoke into parts of the US, leading to hazy skies and health advisories in numerous US cities.", "source": {"uri": "exbulletin.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ExBulletin"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-433718059", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:10:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:10:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:39:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://lethbridgeherald.com/news/national-news/2024/07/25/alberta-premier-says-a-third-perhaps-half-of-all-jasper-buildings-burned-by-fire/", "title": "Alberta premier says a third, perhaps half, of all Jasper buildings burned by fire", "body": "EDMONTON - Alberta Premier Danielle Smith says early reports indicate a third and perhaps up to half of all buildings in the historic Rocky Mountain resort town of Jasper have burned in a wildfire.\n\n\"You've seen the images as I have,\"\u009d Smith said Thursday.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30 to 50 per cent structural damage to give you some idea.\n\n\"We don't know which structures have been damaged and which ones have been destroyed, but that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nSmith made the comments after fighting back tears at a news conference as she sought to console residents who were evacuated from the townsite and now face significant hardship when they return.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it,\"\u009d Smith said.\n\n\"And to those in Alberta and around the world who have experienced the magic of Jasper: The magic is not lost, and it never will be.\"\u009d\n\nParks Canada, in a statement said it will provide details on lost structures when it can accurately and responsibly confirm what burned. But it says crews continue to battle a swift and dynamic fire in Jasper National Park.\n\n\"Jasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight,\"\u009d said the statement.\n\n\"While the rain helped reduce fire activity slightly, it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\u009d\n\nImages surfacing on social media depicted blocks of homes and businesses burned to charred foundations and vehicles torched to the hubcaps.\n\nCalgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park dispatched resources to the fire scene.\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way.\n\nThe staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nIn Hinton Thursday rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, said, \"In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\u009d\n\nAbout 20,000 park visitors and the 5,000 residents of the Jasper municipality had to flee on a moment's notice Monday night ahead of two wildfires that cut off road access everywhere but west to British Columbia.\n\nA day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist.\n\nThose without a place to stay have been directed to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nCrews lost the fight to save Jasper Wednesday just after 6 p.m., as waves of orange and red breached the southern outskirts and began devouring homes and livelihoods.\n\nFrantic efforts to contain the fires -- including buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by high winds.\n\n\"That wind gust moved that fire five kilometres in probably less than 30 minutes, with a wall of fire that was about 100 metres high,\"\u009d said Alberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"There is little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that.\"\u009d\n\n\"Nobody anticipated that fire to come so fast, so large and so quickly.\"\u009d\n\nPierre Martel, who oversees fire management with Parks Canada, echoed Ellis.\n\n\"There are no tools we have in our toolbox to deal with that,\"\u009d Martel told an online news conference.\n\n\"It's just a monster at that point.\"\u009d\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.\n\n-- with files from Jeremy Simes in Regina and Fakiha Baig in Hinton", "source": {"uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Lethbridge Herald - News and Sports {"uri": "8242228007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:27:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:27:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:26:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/jasper-wildfire-reaches-townsite-as-first-responders-ordered-to-leave-5693268", "title": "Jasper Wildfire Reaches Townsite as First Responders Ordered to Leave", "body": "One of two raging, wind-whipped wildfires bearing down on the historic Jasper townsite reached its southern outskirts early Wednesday night as a last-ditch attempt to reroute it failed.\n\nAround the same time, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nFirefighters remained in the town to douse spot fires and maintain sprinkler lines. Everyone else was reminded to get out.\n\n\"If you have not yet evacuated town you must leave now,\" Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said in a statement posted on Facebook.\n\n\"Our hearts go out to all of the affected community members, their families and their friends, many of which include our local first responders.\"\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier in the day.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Ellsworth said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong did go wrong as fire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nEllsworth said the decision to relocate all first responders to the town of Hinton, just outside the eastern edge of the park, \"has not been made lightly.\"\n\nShe said, \"Given the intensity of fire behaviour being observed the decision has been made to limit the number of responders exposed to this risk.\"\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nAbout 5,000 people live in Jasper. They, along with about 20,000 park visitors had to flee on a moment's notice Monday night when the fires flared up.\n\nThe order to go went out around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nJasper National Park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is considered a national and international treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIt has hosted glitz and glitter. In 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelor\" was filmed there.\n\nJasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking, and biking.\n\nIt is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears, and grizzly bears.", "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8243610299", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:41:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:41:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:40:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.livemint.com/news/alberta-wildfire-tears-through-jasper-in-canadian-rockies-11721936355786.html", "title": "Alberta Wildfire Tears Through Jasper in Canadian Rockies", "body": "(Bloomberg) -- A fast-moving wildfire has ripped through the Rocky Mountain resort town of Jasper, destroying homes and businesses and threatening key infrastructure in the evacuated Alberta community.\n\n\"The wildfire is still out of control and crews are working in dangerous conditions to try and protect critical infrastructure in the town,\" Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said Thursday in a media briefing. \"We share a sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it and who have helped build it.\"\n\nThe week-old wildfire spread out of control on Monday, prompting authorities to order town residents and Jasper National Park visitors to leave. Around 25,000 people had been evacuated as of Thursday, according to government agencies. The Jasper fire, dubbed Utopia, was reported a week ago and is believed to have started from a lightning strike.\n\nHigh temperatures, dry conditions and lightning storms have been plaguing much of western North America this month, causing numerous wildfires including in the Western Canadian provinces of British Columbia and Alberta.\n\nJasper is at the heart of a huge national park in the Canadian Rockies that shares its name and at the northern end of the Icefields Parkway, a highway that connects the wilderness area to Banff National Park in the south. The town of 4,100 residents is prime tourist spot and is known for its natural beauty and wildlife, including grizzly bears, elk and moose. Almost 2.5 million people visited Jasper last year, according to Parks Canada.\n\n\"Multiple structures, including a number of businesses and homes, in and around the Town of Jasper have been lost,\" Parks Canada said in a Thursday statement. \"Structural firefighters remain in the town and are working to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure.\"\n\nCanadian National Railway Co., whose rail link between the country's interior and the Pacific coast passes through Jasper, suspended rail operations in what it described a \"dynamic and fluid\" wildfire situation in the area, according to an emailed statement.\n\n\"Early reports indicate the wildfires caused significant damage to the town,\" Canada's largest rail company said Thursday, adding that the community is home to many employees and their families.\n\nThe newly expanded Trans Mountain oil pipeline passes through Jasper. The wildfires have not damaged Trans Mountain's infrastructure and pipeline operations continue to operate, the company said in a Thursday statement. The operator is using its own firefighting equipment in Jasper and has deployed a sprinkler system to protect its facilities.\n\nSome evacuees have ended up in Hinton, a town northeast of Jasper, that is serving as a crisis center and temporary base for the municipality of Jasper.\n\n\"There's been fire trucks coming down the highway from communities all across the province,\" Hinton Mayor Nicholas Nissen said in an interview. \"I can see the lights go as they rip through town, headed quickly toward Jasper.\"\n\nA July heat wave has sparked wildfires across Western Canada. In Alberta alone, 176 wildfires were burning Thursday and 54 are out of control, according to provincial government agency Alberta Wildfire. Cooler temperatures and potential rain is expected to bring some relief in the next several days in the northern part of the province, the agency said.\n\nSome 1,900 firefighters, contractors and support staff are fighting the Alberta blazes, according to Christie Tucker, a spokesperson for Alberta Wildfire. About 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are joining the local crews, according to Alberta's premier.\n\nThe fires have cause deteriorating air quality across Western Canada, with nearby financial hubs Edmonton and Calgary facing unhealthy conditions, according to AirNow.gov.\n\nOil Sands\n\nThe blazes have prompted the curtailment of oil and gas facilities including Suncor Energy Inc.'s Firebag oil sands site, which produced more than 230,000 barrels a day of crude in June, according to Alberta Energy Regulator data. Other companies including Imperial Oil Ltd., Cenovus Energy Inc. and MEG Energy Corp. have evacuated some workers from oil sands sites. Alberta's oil sands are the world's third-largest crude reserves.\n\nThe equivalent of about 389,000 barrels a day of oil and more than 19,000 barrels a day of gas production was within 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) of one or more wildfires that were larger than 10 hectares (25 acres) as of early Thursday, according to Alberta Energy Regulator and Alberta Wildfire data.\n\nFor several years, major fires have burned large swaths of Western Canada, razing communities and sending residents fleeing while ruining air quality across the country and into the US.\n\n(Adds comments from Alberta premier, {"uri": "8243734625", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:55:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:55:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:55:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.timescolonist.com/local-news/alberta-premier-says-a-third-perhaps-half-of-all-jasper-buildings-burned-by-fire-9265291", "title": "Alberta premier says a third, perhaps half, of all Jasper buildings burned by fire", "body": "EDMONTON, ALBERTA, CANADA -- Alberta Premier Danielle Smith says early reports indicate a third and perhaps up to half of all buildings in the historic Rocky Mountain resort town of Jasper have burned in a wildfire.\n\n\"You've seen the images as I have,\" Smith said Thursday.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30 to 50 per cent structural damage to give you some idea.\n\n\"We don't know which structures have been damaged and which ones have been destroyed, but that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nSmith made the comments after fighting back tears at a news conference as she sought to console residents who were evacuated from the townsite and now face significant hardship when they return.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it,\" Smith said.\n\n\"And to those in Alberta and around the world who have experienced the magic of Jasper: The magic is not lost, and it never will be.\"\n\nParks Canada, in a statement said it will provide details on lost structures when it can accurately and responsibly confirm what burned. But it says crews continue to battle a swift and dynamic fire.\n\n\"Jasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight,\" said the statement.\n\n\"While the rain helped reduce fire activity slightly, it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nImages and video surfacing on social media depict blocks of homes and businesses burned to charred foundations and vehicles torched to the hubcaps.\n\nOn the social media platform X, the account for Fairmont's Jasper Park Lodge said the flames had reached the hotel's grounds but the extent of damage, if any, was not known.\n\nAlberta was getting fire crews and help from 32 municipalities across the province. The province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has promised aid is on the way.\n\nCrews worked to preserve critical infrastructure like Jasper's wastewater treatment plant and the Trans Mountain pipeline.\n\nTelus reported some landline and cellphone services were down due to wildfire damage.\n\nThe company said it was securing helicopters to get cell towers operating, with the priority on restoring voice calls, including those to 9-1-1 and emergency services.\n\nThe firefighting staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nIn Hinton Thursday, rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, said, \"In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nAbout 20,000 park visitors and the 5,000 residents of the Jasper municipality had to flee on a moment's notice Monday night ahead of two wildfires that cut off road access everywhere but west to British Columbia.\n\nA day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist.\n\nThose without a place to stay have been directed to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nCrews lost the fight to save Jasper Wednesday just after 6 p.m., as waves of orange and red breached the southern outskirts and began devouring homes and livelihoods.\n\nFrantic efforts to contain the fires -- including buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by high winds.\n\n\"That wind gust moved that fire five kilometres in probably less than 30 minutes, with a wall of fire that was about 100 metres high,\" said Alberta Public Safety Minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"There is little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that.\"\n\nPierre Martel, who oversees fire management with Parks Canada, echoed Ellis.\n\n\"There are no tools we have in our tool box to deal with that,\" Martel told an online news conference.\n\n\"It's just a monster at that point.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.\n\n-- with files from Jeremy Simes in Regina and Fakiha Baig in Hinton\n\nLisa Johnson, The Canadian Press", {"uri": "8243656596", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:27:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:27:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:27:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/jasper-wildfires-more-than-400-foreign-firefighters-on-the-way-up-to-a-third-of/article_28adb81c-4ab0-11ef-aaa1-43e944b69f7d.html", "title": "Jasper Wildfires: More than 400 foreign firefighters on the way, up to a third of town may have been destroyed", "body": "One of Canada's most famous national parks is burning.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nPreliminary reports indicate a third and possibly up to half the structures in the town of Jasper have been destroyed in a wildfire, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said in an update on Thursday afternoon.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau posted on X Thursday afternoon that more than 400 firefighters from Australia, New Zealand, Mexico and South Africa are en route to Alberta to help quell the flames.\n\nHe is expected to convene the Incident Response Group -- a committee of ministers and senior government officials who co-ordinate the federal government's response in emergency situations -- this afternoon. A government official told the Star on the condition they not be named that Trudeau, Deputy Prime Minister and Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland, Emergency Preparedness Minister Harjit Sajjan, Treasury Board President Anita Anand, Defence Minister Bill Blair, Public Safety Minister Dominic LeBlanc, and Citizens' Services Minister Terry Beech will be in attendance\n\nSmith confirmed at her press conference that she has been in contact with LeBlanc and is expected to meet with Sajjan later this afternoon. On Wednesday night, Ottawa approved the Alberta government's request for military aid.\n\nAlberta government to provide daily updates on Jasper fire\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said, holding back tears, at a press conference in Edmonton.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nStrong winds are expected to raise the fire risk in the northeast and south of the province, where danger from the wildfires is still \"extreme,\" Alberta Wildfire information unit manager Christie Tucker said.\n\nAlberta currently has 176 active wildfires, with 54 classified as \"out of control,\" Tucker said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSmith said her government will move to providing daily updates with the province's minister of forestry and parks and its minister of public safety.\n\nCanada In photos: Tragic scenes from Jasper unfold as wildfire leaves trail of destruction\n\nThe fire reached Jasper on Wednesday evening and has begun ravaging the town, with a third of it destroyed.\n\n\"Alberta stands ready to assist in every way that we can,\" Smith said, adding that she had asked LeBlanc to establish a \"unified command structure\" to co-ordinate the response to the wildfire.\n\n\"Alberta's government will provide the support needed to families and communities to recover and to rebuild stronger than ever, so that future generations can continue to experience this one-of-a-kind community.\"\n\nDamage to Jasper National Park still unknown\n\nThe damage to homes and infrastructure from the wildfires is still being evaluated, Jasper National Parks officials said in a statement posted to X.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures,\" officials wrote, adding that no injuries have been reported as a result of the Jasper wildfire.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe park received a small amount of rain overnight on Wednesday, but it was \"not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way. Late into Wednesday evening, Minister of Emergency Preparedness Harjit Sajjan posted on X that he had \"approved a request from Alberta to provide immediate and urgent support from the Federal Government to protect people and homes in Jasper and communities across Alberta.\"\n\nHome phone and mobility services in the area were also impacted by the fires, Telus Corp. confirmed to The Canadian Press on Thursday. Priority was being given to restoring voice calls, including those to emergency services.\n\nCanadian National Railway Co., whose main line runs through Jasper, suspended its operations in the area on Wednesday.\n\nWildfire in Jasper prompts evacuations\n\nAbout 25,000 people have been forced to flee from Jasper, Alta. as wildfires have torn through the iconic town known for its hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland wrote in a post to Facebook on Thursday. \"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension; my deepest sympathies go out to each of you.\"\n\n\"This experience is tremendously traumatic for each of us and for the community. I encourage you to reach out to your neighbours, colleagues and friends: share your grief; share your pain; stay connected,\" he added. \"Offer a helping hand, a listening ear, a supportive word where you can, and know that we are all in this together.\"\n\nEveryone in Jasper National Park, including tourists, hikers and residents, were ordered to leave the area late Monday evening as wildfires overtook escape routes to the east and south. Pictures posted to social media showed long, snaking lines of cars and trucks heading westward to B.C.\n\nEvacuees were then directed to make a U-turn as B.C. grapples with wildfires and evacuations of its own.\n\n\"(B.C.) had no capacity to house Albertans,\" Stephen Lacroix, managing director of the Alberta Emergency Management Agency, said on Tuesday.\n\nAt 7:10 p.m. (MT) on Wednesday evening, portions of the southern fire in Jasper reached the townsite, according to Jasper National Park's updates. Nearly an hour later, air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others \"without self contained breathing apparatuses\" had to leave Jasper for the nearby town of Hinton.\n\nVideos posted to social media showed charred streets and homes, covered in black soot and swirling smoke.\n\nThis story is developing. {"uri": "8243364759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:35:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:35:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:06:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13672845/Huge-wildfire-burns-western-Canadian-town-rain-forecast.html", "title": "Huge wildfire burns down part of western Canadian town; rain in...", "body": "By David Ljunggren\n\nJuly 25 (Reuters) - A raging wildfire has burned down part of the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper and firefighters were working on Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draws more than 2 million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"As the pictures and videos circulating online show, significant loss has occurred within the town site,\" Parks Canada said in a statement, but gave no details.\n\nOfficials said that at one point on Wednesday the flames in Jasper had reached a height of 400 feet and were moving at 15 meters (50 feet) a minute.\n\nAshley Kliewer, co-owner of a restaurant in the middle of Jasper, said she had been informed the entire east end of the town had burned down.\n\n\"I am absolutely devastated. ... I don't think anyone will be returning to Jasper any time soon and life is not going to be anywhere near what it was - it really is the end of an era,\" she told the Canadian Broadcasting Corp.\n\nThe Alberta government is due to brief media at 11 am local time (1700 GMT).\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThere are currently 175 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where dozens of fires are also out of control.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. One major concern for responders is if the fire reaches the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"Losing structures, community, is like losing a close friend ... (but) the people have been saved and that is significant. We can find a way to rebuild,\" Jasper mayor Richard Ireland told the CBC.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil center of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents. The blaze destroyed 10% of all structures in the city and shut in more than a million barrels per day of oil output.\n\nFort McMurray is forecast to receive up to 65 mm of rain in the next day, according to Environment Canada. {"uri": "8242332730", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "04:22:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T04:22:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T04:21:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.ckom.com/2024/07/24/924821/", "title": "Multiple structures ablaze as wildfire roars into Jasper, Alta., townsite", "body": "By Dean Bennett and Lisa Johnson, The Canadian Press\n\nOne of two raging, wind-whipped fires menacing Jasper, Alta., roared into town Wednesday night and began burning buildings.\n\nPictures on social media depicted lodges and other buildings wrapped in fiery sheets of orange flame.\n\nfiery sheets of orange flame.\n\nSome fire crews were ordered out as the battle switched from the forest to the streets.\n\n\"(The) air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses needed to evacuate to Hinton,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThat launched a line of cars and trucks snaking east to the town of Hinton, outside the park gates.\n\nJasper was under attack by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 park visitors -- have already left.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong earlier Wednesday did go wrong.\n\nFire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nThe 25,000 fled at a moment's notice two nights earlier.\n\nThe order to go went out around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nJasper National Park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is considered a national and international treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIt has hosted glitz and glitter. In 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelor\" was filmed there.\n\nJasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nIt is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 24, 2024.", {"uri": "8243618271", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:50:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:50:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:49:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.dailymaverick.co.za/article/2024-07-25-alberta-wildfire-tears-through-jasper-in-canadian-rockies/", "title": "Alberta Wildfire Tears Through Jasper in Canadian Rockies", "body": "\"The wildfire is still out of control and crews are working in dangerous conditions to try and protect critical infrastructure in the town,\" Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said Thursday in a media briefing. \"We share a sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it and who have helped build it.\"\n\nThe week-old wildfire spread out of control on Monday, prompting authorities to order town residents and Jasper National Park visitors to leave. Around 25,000 people had been evacuated as of Thursday, according to government agencies. The Jasper fire, dubbed Utopia, was reported a week ago and is believed to have started from a lightning strike.\n\nHigh temperatures, dry conditions and lightning storms have been plaguing much of western North America this month, causing numerous wildfires including in the Western Canadian provinces of British Columbia and Alberta.\n\nJasper is at the heart of a huge national park in the Canadian Rockies that shares its name and at the northern end of the Icefields Parkway, a highway that connects the wilderness area to Banff National Park in the south. The town of 4,100 residents is prime tourist spot and is known for its natural beauty and wildlife, including grizzly bears, elk and moose. Almost 2.5 million people visited Jasper last year, according to Parks Canada.\n\n\"Multiple structures, including a number of businesses and homes, in and around the Town of Jasper have been lost,\" Parks Canada said in a Thursday statement. \"Structural firefighters remain in the town and are working to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure.\"\n\nCanadian National Railway Co., whose rail link between the country's interior and the Pacific coast passes through Jasper, suspended rail operations in what it described a \"dynamic and fluid\" wildfire situation in the area, according to an emailed statement.\n\n\"Early reports indicate the wildfires caused significant damage to the town,\" Canada's largest rail company said Thursday, adding that the community is home to many employees and their families.\n\nThe newly expanded Trans Mountain oil pipeline passes through Jasper. The wildfires have not damaged Trans Mountain's infrastructure and pipeline operations continue to operate, the company said in a Thursday statement. The operator is using its own firefighting equipment in Jasper and has deployed a sprinkler system to protect its facilities.\n\nSome evacuees have ended up in Hinton, a town northeast of Jasper, that is serving as a crisis center and temporary base for the municipality of Jasper.\n\n\"There's been fire trucks coming down the highway from communities all across the province,\" Hinton Mayor Nicholas Nissen said in an interview. \"I can see the lights go as they rip through town, headed quickly toward Jasper.\"\n\nA July heat wave has sparked wildfires across Western Canada. In Alberta alone, 176 wildfires were burning Thursday and 54 are out of control, according to provincial government agency Alberta Wildfire. Cooler temperatures and potential rain is expected to bring some relief in the next several days in the northern part of the province, the agency said.\n\nSome 1,900 firefighters, contractors and support staff are fighting the Alberta blazes, according to Christie Tucker, a spokesperson for Alberta Wildfire. About 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are joining the local crews, according to Alberta's premier.\n\nThe fires have cause deteriorating air quality across Western Canada, with nearby financial hubs Edmonton and Calgary facing unhealthy conditions, according to AirNow.gov.\n\nOil Sands\n\nThe blazes have prompted the curtailment of oil and gas facilities including Suncor Energy Inc.'s Firebag oil sands site, which produced more than 230,000 barrels a day of crude in June, according to Alberta Energy Regulator data. Other companies including Imperial Oil Ltd., Cenovus Energy Inc. and MEG Energy Corp. have evacuated some workers from oil sands sites. Alberta's oil sands are the world's third-largest crude reserves.\n\nThe equivalent of about 389,000 barrels a day of oil and more than 19,000 barrels a day of gas production was within 10 kilometers (6.2 miles) of one or more wildfires that were larger than 10 hectares (25 acres) as of early Thursday, according to Alberta Energy Regulator and Alberta Wildfire data.\n\nFor several years, major fires have burned large swaths of Western Canada, razing communities and sending residents fleeing while ruining air quality across the country and into the US.", "source": {"uri": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/jasper-updates-wildfire-reaches-south-outskirts-of-townsite-1.6976628", "title": "Jasper updates: Wildfire reaches south outskirts of townsite", "body": "One of two wildfires threatening the townsite in Jasper National Park has reached the southern outskirts of the Alberta Rockies community.\n\nIn an early evening statement, officials with Parks Canada and the Municipality of Jasper said the south fire, as of 6 p.m., was at the town's south limits by strong wind gusts from the south and southeast.\n\nThe statement said firefighters remain in the community to combat spot fires and maintain sprinkler lines.\n\nThe officials said 10-20 millimetres of rain is forecast to arrive in the next 24 hours, beginning later tonight.\n\n\"If the area receives rain, it will help to reduce fire activity,\" said the statement from Parks Canada Incident Commander Katie Ellsworth and Municipality of Jasper Incident Commander Christine Nadon.\n\nThey said afternoon work to fight the fire by helicopter bucketing \"proved ineffective\" and that fireguard work by heavy equipment wasn't able to be completed before workers had to remove it from the fireline for safety reasons.\n\nThe officials said water bombers from Alberta were unable to help because of dangerous conditions.\n\nThey said an ignition specialist that came to Jasper to help \"complete landscape-level ignition in order to bring the fire to large holding features such as Highway 16 and Athabasca River\" has been prevented from doing the work due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nWildfire moving 'faster than expected' toward townsite\n\nTodd Loewen, Alberta's minister of forestry and parks, said in a statement to CTV News Edmonton on Wednesday afternoon the \"active and aggressive\" fire in Jasper National Park is moving toward the townsite \"faster than predicted.\"\n\n\"It's still hard to determine the boundary of the fire because of the intensity of the flames and smoke, and things are very fluid right now,\" Loewen said.\n\n\"Crews are moving to safe locations. It's not uncommon during a fire as the fire changes.\n\nFirst responders relocated to Hinton due to wildfire activity\n\nParks Canada has confirmed that first responders are being relocated to Hinton as a result of \"significant fire activity and forecasted strong winds.\"\n\nVehicles and heavy equipment have been seen leaving Jasper National Park throughout Wednesday afternoon.\n\nThe park and townsite were evacuated on Monday night, leaving only essential personnel and firefighters behind.\n\n\"If you have not yet evacuated town you must leave now,\" Parks Canada wrote in a social media post. \"This is for your own safety and to allow these critical operations to protect the town of Jasper to continue unimpeded. This decision has not been made lightly.\"\n\nThe sky over the park has grown steadily darker throughout Wednesday afternoon as a result of wildfire smoke, and ash is raining from the sky.\n\nCTV News {"uri": "8242303532", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "03:53:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T03:53:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T03:53:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.princegeorgecitizen.com/national-news/multiple-structures-ablaze-as-wildfire-roars-into-jasper-alta-townsite-9259948", "title": "Multiple structures ablaze as wildfire roars into Jasper, Alta., townsite", "body": "EDMONTON -- One of two raging, wind-whipped fires menacing Jasper, Alta., roared into town Wednesday night and began burning buildings.\n\nParks officials say the fire entered the southern edge of the community about 6:40 p.m.\n\nPictures on social media depicted lodges and other buildings wrapped in fiery sheets of orange flame.\n\nSome fire crews were ordered out as the battle switched from the forest to the streets.\n\n\"(The) air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses needed to evacuate to Hinton,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline and others.\"\n\nA few hours earlier, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThat launched a line of cars and trucks snaking east to the town of Hinton, outside the park gates.\n\nJasper was under attack by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 park visitors -- have already left.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong earlier Wednesday did go wrong.\n\nFire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nThe 25,000 fled at a moment's notice two nights earlier.\n\nThe order to go went out around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nJasper National Park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is considered a national and international treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIt has hosted glitz and glitter. In 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelor\" was filmed there.\n\nJasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nIt is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 24, 2024.\n\n-- with files from Fakiha Baig in Grande Prairie\n\nDean Bennett and Lisa Johnson, The Canadian Press", "source": {"uri": "princegeorgecitizen.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Prince {"uri": "8243669046", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:40:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:40:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:39:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/devastating-wildfire-burns-down-part-of-western-canadian-tourist-town/article_09fe703b-d1f9-5e85-8230-5246b61d6f2a.html", "title": "Devastating wildfire burns down part of western Canadian tourist town", "body": "By David Ljunggren and Nia Williams\n\n(Reuters) -A raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper, potentially destroying up to 50% of structures, and firefighters were working on Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of mountainous Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draw more than 2 million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were up to 10,000 people in the town and a further 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, while choking back tears.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild,\" she said, adding the fire was still out of control.\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage, or which areas had been hit and it urged residents not to return.\n\nVideo from the town showed vehicles and entire blocks burned to the ground, including a historic Anglican church.\n\nJasper resident Eva Korduliakova heard the news that her home was burning from thousands of kilometers away Thursday morning, while visiting family in the Czech Republic with her seven-year-old son.\n\n\"I am single mum who became homeless and jobless overnight,\" she wrote in an email. \"Our house is gone. I didn't get a chance to grab any of my belongings.\"\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of the fire.\n\n\"Last night's wildfires have simply ravaged our small tight-knit mountain community, the destruction and the loss that so many of our residents are facing simply defies description,\" he told a press conference, his voice breaking.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire damages the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nCN Rail said it suspended rail operations through the town on Wednesday afternoon as the wildfire conditions worsened.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\n'WALL OF FLAMES'\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where there 423 wildfires burning and dozens of evacuation orders and alerts.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be a catastrophic year for wildfires in Canada.\n\nThe Jasper fire was caused by a lightning strike on Monday afternoon and fuelled by strong winds, according to Parks Canada.\n\nFlames from the blaze rose 100 meters high (3 feet), and strong wind gusts on Wednesday afternoon pushed the fire 5 kilometers (3 miles) in less than 30 minutes, said Alberta public safety minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"Any firefighter will tell you there's little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that,\" Ellis said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents and destroying 10% of all structures in the city.\n\n(Reporting by David Ljunggren in Ottawa, Nia Williams in British Columbia and Anna Mehler Paperny in Toronto: Editing by Angus MacSwan and Aurora Ellis)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, {"uri": "8243606226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:37:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:37:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:36:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/devastating-wildfire-burns-down-part-of-western-canadian-town/article_09fe703b-d1f9-5e85-8230-5246b61d6f2a.html", "title": "Devastating wildfire burns down part of western Canadian town", "body": "By David Ljunggren\n\n(Reuters) -A raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper and firefighters were working on Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draw more than 2 million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, saying the fire was still out of control.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage or which areas had been hit.\n\nVideo from the town showed entire blocks had burned to the ground, including a church.\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of a fire that had ravaged the community.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension,\" he said in a letter to residents.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire reaches the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\n'END OF AN ERA'\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where dozens of fires are also out of control.\n\n\"Many of the wildfires we're seeing at this time of year are lightning caused and we unfortunately can't control the weather,\" said Alberta forestry minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada.\n\nOfficials said that at one point on Wednesday the flames had reached a height of 400 feet and were moving at 15 meters (50 feet) a minute.\n\nAshley Kliewer, co-owner of a restaurant in the middle of Jasper, told the Canadian Broadcasting crop she was devastated.\n\n\"I don't think anyone will be returning to Jasper any time soon and life is not going to be anywhere near what it was - it really is the end of an era,\" she said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents. The blaze destroyed 10% of all structures in the city and shut in more than a million barrels per day of oil output.\n\nFort McMurray is forecast to receive up to 65 mm of rain in the next day, according to Environment Canada.\n\n(Reporting by David Ljunggren: Editing by Angus MacSwan; Editing by Aurora Ellis)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com",
