{"uri": "8243228774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:30:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:30:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:29:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10642975/jasper-alberta-wildfire-july-25/", "title": "Jasper wildfire: Mayor expresses 'pain and heartache' as flames enter townsite  | Globalnews.ca", "body": "The mayor of the Municipality of Jasper extended \"heartfelt sympathy and solidarity\" to residents late Wednesday after a wildfire entered the townsite after it prompted the evacuation of 25,000 people in Jasper National Park.\n\n\"The news this evening that the fire has entered our town has rocked us all,\" Richard Ireland wrote in a Facebook post shortly before midnight local time Wednesday.\n\nEarlier in the evening, Parks Canada confirmed multiple buildings in the mountainous tourist community in western Alberta were impacted.\n\n\"There has been structural loss at this point. I can't confirm how many locations or specific structures,\" said James Eastham, a wildfire information officer with Parks Canada.\n\n\"The pain and heartache that you feel is shared by each one of us,\" Ireland wrote. \"Please know that my thoughts are with all of you during this incredibly difficult time.\n\n\"To all the responders on the ground in our town -- our home -- words cannot express the admiration and gratitude we have for your professionalism, your dedication and your unyielding efforts.\"\n\nThe Alberta government confirmed Wednesday night that it has asked the federal government for assistance from the Canadian military to deal with the provincial wildfire situation.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau confirmed in a statement his government is sending help.\n\n\"We've approved Alberta's request for federal assistance,\" he said. \"We're deploying Canadian Forces resources, evacuations support, and more emergency wildfire resources to the province immediately -- and we're coordinating firefighting and airlift assistance.\n\n\"Alberta, we're with you.\"\n\nIn a video posted to social media Wednesday night, Premier Danielle Smith said her thoughts are with everyone forced to flee their homes or lodging because of the wildfires and to \"those who are still in the community.\"\n\n\"Make sure if you can leave, please leave safely and take care of yourself,\" she said. \"Also to the emergency responders and firefighters, we wish you all the luck in fighting this fire and keeping safe as well.\"\n\nAs of Thursday morning, there have been no reports from emergency officials of injuries as a result of the fire.\n\nThe company that owns the iconic Jasper Park Lodge resort confirmed that the fire had reached its grounds but said that the extent of the damage was not yet clear.\n\nThe company that owns the Maligne Lodge confirmed the hotel had been destroyed by flames.\n\n\"Sadly, we lost our beloved hotel The Maligne Lodge this evening,\" said Karyn Decore, president and CEO of Decore Hotels.\n\n\"We are so devastated and we are also so sad for all the other business owners, operators, residents and wonderful people who call Jasper home.\"\n\nParks Canada officials acknowledged late Wednesday that the day had been \"exceptionally difficult\" but noted firefighters would be working through the night to try to save the rest of the townsite.\n\n\"While the road ahead is daunting and remains uncertain, please remember that you are not alone,\" Ireland said. \"Our community is resilient, and united we will find a way to get through this, together.\"\n\nIt was not immediately clear when military assistance would arrive in the national park but officials confirmed help is also arriving from various municipalities in Alberta.\n\nGlobal News spoke to evacuees staying in nearby Hinton, Alta., on Wednesday night, when wet ash could be seen in the air.\n\nAman Singh, who works in Jasper, said that he left on Tuesday and that everybody realizes it is an \"intense situation.\"\n\n\"(It's a) hard situation for everyone who lives in Jasper,\" he said, adding he could feel \"ashes going into my lungs\" when he was outside.\n\nAs the wildfire situation in the Jasper townsite grew more intense Wednesday afternoon, some first responders were forced to leave because the situation had become too dangerous to stay.\n\nParks Canada officials said the air quality had deteriorated to the point that wildland firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses needed to leave.\n\nA Parks Canada official reiterated Wednesday night that safety is the agency's priority and that it was vitally important that all evacuees register at reception centres as soon as they can so officials know their The blaze has caused significant structural damage and forced evacuations. Firefighters are working tirelessly to protect infrastructure. The fire threatens the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, while emergency crews and international firefighters are being deployed to assist.\n\nA raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper, with firefighters striving to save as many buildings as possible, authorities reported on Thursday. Jasper, located in the heart of Jasper National Park, Alberta, was evacuated earlier this week as flames threatened the community.\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith described the situation as a 'worst nightmare' for any community, highlighting an estimated 30% to 50% structural damage. Parks Canada confirmed significant building losses in Jasper, though specific details remain undisclosed. Imagery from the scene showcased entire blocks decimated, including a church.\n\nMayor Richard Ireland expressed sorrow over the 'devastating impact' on the town, acknowledging the profound destruction residents are grappling with. Concerns are also growing regarding potential threats to the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, yet operator Trans Mountain assured that the infrastructure is currently undamaged and operational.", {"uri": "8243208288", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:16:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:16:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:15:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/25/our-worst-nightmare-raging-wildfire-hits-western-canada-town-of-jasper", "title": "'Our worst nightmare': Raging wildfire hits western Canada town of Jasper", "body": "Authorities say damage is 'significant' in Canadian Rockies town as firefighters work to save as much as possible.\n\nA fast-moving wildfire has hit the town of Jasper in the Canadian Rockies, causing \"significant\" losses as firefighters work to hold back the flames.\n\nIn a statement in the early hours of Thursday, Jasper National Park said firefighting crews were trying \"to save as many structures as possible and to protect critical infrastructure\" and more firefighters were en route.\n\nLocated about 370km (230 miles) west of Edmonton in the province of Alberta, the park and the town of Jasper, home to 4,700 residents, draw more than two million tourists annually.\n\nThousands of people were evacuated from the area earlier this week as two blazes edged closer.\n\n\"As the pictures and videos circulating online show, significant loss has occurred within the townsite,\" Jasper National Park said in a post on X.\n\n\"We are sensitive that residents, business owners, visitors and those with connections to Jasper want to know the state of their homes, businesses, treasures and favourite places,\" it continued.\n\n\"Our focus continues to be on saving as many structures as possible. Unfortunately, we can't report on the extent of damage to specific locations or neighbourhoods at this time.\"\n\nThe blaze is one of hundreds ravaging Alberta and the neighbouring province of British Columbia, fuelled by a weeks-long heatwave and surge in lightning strikes.\n\nOfficials said the flames in Jasper reached a height of 122 metres (400 feet) and moved at 15 metres (50 feet) a minute.\n\nCanadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said early on Thursday that his government had approved Alberta's request for federal assistance.\n\n\"We're deploying [Canadian Armed Forces] resources, evacuations support, and more emergency wildfire resources to the province immediately -- and we're coordinating firefighting and airlift assistance. Alberta, we're with you,\" Trudeau wrote on X.\n\nParks Canada spokesperson James Eastham told reporters outside Jasper that the town is filled with smoke and there \"has been structural loss\".\n\n\"At this point, I can't confirm how many, locations or specific structures. The fire continues to burn,\" he said.\n\nExperts say the climate crisis has extended the Canadian wildfire season, which typically runs from late April until September or October, and increased lightning - a major cause of the blazes.\n\nMike Flannigan, research chair for predictive services, emergency management and fire science at Thompson Rivers University in British Columbia, told Al Jazeera last year that a warmer atmosphere also dries out fire fuels, such as the vegetation on forest floors.\n\nCanada saw its most intense fire season on record in 2023, with more than 6,600 wildfires burning 15 million hectares (37 million acres) across the country, an area roughly seven times the annual average.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, Jasper's Mayor Richard Ireland told the Canadian public broadcaster CBC News that multiple structures were burning in the community and \"it appears that the damage will be extensive\".\n\n\"This is simply, absolutely, our community's worst nightmare,\" Ireland said. \"Residents watching from afar, [it's] far beyond nervousness. I think like all residents, I feel devastated, shattered, and absolutely helpless in the face of nature, which is just so powerful.\"\n\nOne of the buildings destroyed by the fire was the Maligne Lodge hotel in the south of the town.\n\n\"It's just so sad to know that so many families and people have lost not just their belongings but their livelihood and a beautiful park,\" owner Karyne Decore told CBC.\n\nThere are 175 wildfires currently burning in Alberta, according to a provincial tracker, and more than 50 of them are out of control.", "source": {"uri": "aljazeera.com", {"uri": "8243216954", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "14:22:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T14:22:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T14:21:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://chatnewstoday.ca/2024/07/25/jasper-wildfire-burns-buildings-while-poor-air-quality-forces-some-fire-crews-out-2/", "title": "Jasper wildfire burns buildings, while poor air quality forces some fire crews out", "body": "As the fire consumed more fuel, officials said the air quality dropped to dangerous levels, prompting fire crews without breathing apparatus to flee to the nearby community of Hinton.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nPhotos on social media show lodges and other buildings wrapped in sheets of orange flame.\n\n\"Structural firefighters remain in town and are working to save as many structures as possible,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\nMeanwhile, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced on social media that Ottawa has approved Alberta's request for federal assistance.\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked for help from the Canadian military.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nEarlier in the day, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThe fires are burning on the north and south sides of the town, which is home to 5,000 people. The residents have left, along with 20,000 park visitors.\n\nThe order to leave was issued around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to Jasper. Residents and visitors fled west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight procession through swirling smoke and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make the long drive around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday. The southern fire was farther away, but Parks Canada says strong winds sent it racing toward the town.\n\nThat forced crews using heavy equipment to pull back for safety. Water bombers were grounded due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled arriving in Jasper from Edmonton only to be told to get out.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" the 24-year-old said in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said she went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.", {"uri": "8242090270", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:42:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:42:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:41:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/saskatchewan/family-joins-thousands-evacuating-jasper-national-park-1.7274018", "title": "Sask. family joins thousands evacuating Jasper National Park as 'aggressive' wildfires approach | CBC News", "body": "A Saskatoon family joined thousands of people evacuating the town of Jasper and surrounding area beginning Monday evening.\n\nMultiple fires are burning in Jasper National Park. Two of them, burning to the north and south, are threatening the town of Jasper. As of 12 pm. CST Wednesday, flames were five kilometres from the Jasper townsite.\n\nAround 25,000 people have left the national park since the evacuation notice Monday -- all with little advance warning.\n\nSaskatoon paddling instructor Bryan Sarauer, his wife and his daughter are on a road trip, and had stopped at Whistlers Campground just outside of Jasper.\n\nAfter emergency alerts Monday night, the family packed up and left at approximately 10:20 p.m. Sarauer said the evacuation order was sudden, but the leaving was slow. He said it took about three hours to travel three kilometres onto Highway 16.\n\n\"We never felt that we were that threatened by [the fire]. We felt that we needed to get out of harm's way to make room for the parks people to do their jobs ... taking care of the safety of tourists and visitors,\" said Sarauer.\n\nIt wasn't until 3:30 a.m. that the family arrived in the village of Valemount in east central B.C., where they were able to get gas and find a quiet place to park.\n\n\"And by four in the morning, we were curled up in the car as best we could in our car seats, you know, to try and get a little bit of rest,\" Sarauer said.\n\nThey managed to sleep a few hours before hitting the road again to head east back to Saskatoon.\n\nThis isn't the first time the family has encountered wildfires in their recent travels.\n\n\"We've driven by a lot of fire this summer. We've had numerous fires that we could see from the highways as we were driving and we even paddled through one fire on the Teslin River [in southern Yukon],\" Sarauer said.\n\n\"So lots of concern, I guess. And you do have to wonder how much of this is a new normal.\"\n\nSarauer said wildfires generally are a natural part of life. However, learning that flames are drawing nearer to Jasper does have him concerned for the locals.\n\n\"It's scary when it's threatening your home, your business, your livelihood, the place you work, the place you live,\" he said.\n\n\"Those of us who play there, I mean, it's sad to see that damage. It is part of the cycle and regrowth. But it's an entirely different story when you've got property, livelihoods and so on that are at risk.\"\n\nIn a news conference Wednesday morning, Parks Canada incident commander Katie Ellsworth said crews were facing another challenging day attempting to keep the flames away from homes and businesses.\n\nShe said \"aggressive\" fire behaviour is expected to continue.\n\nAs of Wednesday morning, the fire had scorched at least 270 hectares.\n\nThe fire burning south of town doubled in size overnight. It has now burned an estimated 10,800 hectares of forest.\n\nEmergency officials warned that the fire perimeters are changing minute by minute as volatile conditions persist.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8242069212", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "01:07:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T01:07:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:16:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/jasper-evacuees-arrive-calgary-relieved-230758552.html", "title": "Jasper evacuees arrive in Calgary, relieved but unsure about resort town's future", "body": "After a long, winding journey out of Jasper and through a series of small B.C. communities, dozens of evacuees arrived in Calgary on Wednesday, relieved to be away from the wildfire danger but unsure about the resort town's future.\n\nTim Strozen was camping in the area with his wife and two daughters when he noticed that people in the townsite were filling up their cars with gas.\n\n\"That was our indication that maybe we should just pack up and leave,\" Strozen said. \"And we're so glad we did because then everyone was rushed getting out.\"\n\nAfter the order to leave Jasper was issued, thousands of vehicles were gridlocked on roads leading to safety. Many were forced west into British Columbia, then later redirected east toward Alberta.\n\nStrozen said he feels \"horrible\" for people who were stuck in the massive, early morning exit out of Jasper.\n\n\"And then seeing the pictures with the fires coming closer, that would be a horrible situation to be in, for sure.\"\n\nTim Strozan was camping in the Jasper area with his wife and two daughters. His family decided to leave after seeing people fill up their cars with gas, and he says they beat the massive rush out of the townsite that led to a major gridlock. (Benjamin Lopez Steven/CBC)\n\nOther evacuees like Maryn Longley, a Jasper resident, described her experience as a \"wild ride\" that began with seeing a red sky and \"ash falling from the sky as I was walking home from work.\"\n\nLongley was caught up in the gridlock and said it took her \"two or three hours just to get out of town.\"\n\n\"I just wanted to get out of there,\" Longley said. \"I'm very antsy when it comes to traffic jams and stuff like that.\"\n\nAs Longley spoke to CBC News, she was waiting to be picked up by her dad and sister, who would take her to Edmonton.\n\nLongley said she's now taking things \"day-by-day\" and trying not to \"stress about anything too much.\"\n\nIn a media statement, the City of Calgary said that as of 9 a.m. on Wednesday, 108 evacuees had registered in the city, almost evenly split between Jasper residents and tourists.\n\n\"We are able to help people find shelter and additional supports they may need as the firefight continues,\" the statement read. \"Currently, there have been no further requests for support.\"\n\nEvacuees unsure about town's future\n\nAs of Wednesday, the two wildfires burning north and south of Jasper have moved within five kilometres and eight kilometres of the townsite.\n\nParks Canada incident commander Katie Ellsworth told reporters Wednesday morning the \"aggressive\" fire behaviour was expected to continue.\n\nLongley said she's \"not entirely sure what the future holds,\" adding that the situation is \"kind of in God's hands.\"\n\nWarren Waxer, who has lived in Jasper for 44 years, was in southern B.C. visiting friends when the evacuation order came through. He said his son packed up their belongings and made his way out of the tourist town.\n\nWarren Waxer, who has lived in Jasper for 44 years, said he's hopeful but a little nervous for the townsite's future since the fire could damage tourist infrastructure and harm the local tourism industry. (Benjamin Lopez Steven/CBC)\n\nAs for Jasper's future, Waxer said he's \"hopeful but a little bit nervous because you just can't imagine rebuilding a town like Jasper.\"\n\n\"There's so much tourist infrastructure in and around the town that [the fire] doesn't necessarily have to hit the town to have a pretty major impact on the tourist industry,\" Waxer said.\n\nHowever, Waxer added that residents have been preparing for an evacuation like this after a series of harsh fire seasons.\n\n\"It was on everyone's mind since Fort McMurray [and] Edson last year,\" Waxer said, noting that residents had attended a wildfire preparation session as recently as two weeks ago.\n\n\"We did know [the session] was important, it's just we didn't think it would happen so quickly or to us,\" Waxer {"uri": "8243731096", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:51:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:51:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:50:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://theglobalherald.com/news/devastating-wildfire-impacts-jasper-canada-displacing-thousands/", "title": "Devastating Wildfire Impacts Jasper, Canada, Displacing Thousands - The Global Herald", "body": "A significant wildfire has wreaked havoc in the Canadian town of Jasper, leading to substantial damage and displacement for its residents. Official estimates suggest that the wildfire may have affected between 30% to 50% of the town.\n\nThe inferno, fueled by a recent lightning storm and high winds, prompted the evacuation of approximately 25,000 individuals from the region. In response, around 400 firefighters from various countries, including teams from Mexico, South Africa, Australia, and New Zealand, have been mobilized to assist with firefighting efforts.\n\nA heartfelt statement from Alberta Premier Danielle Smith highlighted the extensive rebuilding efforts required for the township. \"Jasper will require a significant rebuild,\" she commented during a press briefing.\n\nIn addition, Jasper's mayor, Richard Ireland, expressed deep concern over the situation, stating that the wildfire has \"ravaged our small, tight-knit mountain community.\" He further extended gratitude towards the emergency responders for their unwavering dedication.\n\nAs of now, detailed assessments of structural damage remain limited as efforts focus primarily on fire containment. Pierre Martel, who oversees national fire management at Parks Canada, described the fire's rapid escalation as \"just a monster,\" emphasizing the challenges faced by firefighters.\n\nWitness accounts from those in the area paint a vivid picture of the peril. Mike Ellis, Alberta's public safety minister, mentioned that the fire advanced swiftly, estimating that just moments passed between when it was 5 kilometers away and when it struck the town.\n\nThe community of Jasper, home to approximately 5,000 residents, has faced challenging conditions as they cope with the effects of the wildfire. The local infrastructure, vital to both residents and tourists, is under significant strain. In 2022, Jasper National Park welcomed nearly 2.5 million visitors, making this incident especially concerning for both the local economy and community wellbeing.\n\nThis wildfire event occurs in a context of ongoing wildfire challenges across Canada, with previous years witnessing severe fire conditions. Environment Canada has indicated the possibility of rainfall, providing a glimmer of hope for alleviating the dry conditions that have exacerbated the wildfire's spread.\n\nAuthorities and scientists continuously link the increase in natural disasters, including wildfires, to human-induced climate change, raising concerns about the future resilience of communities such as Jasper.\n\nThe emotional toll on residents is profound, with many grappling with the uncertainty of recovery. One local resident recounted her family's escape as they witnessed the ferocious storm preceding the fire: \"We are some of the last travellers to see Jasper in its full beauty - it will be a very long time before it will recover. It's utterly devastating for them all, and my heart is breaking,\" she shared.\n\nThe wildfire incident in Jasper serves as a stark reminder of the growing threats posed by climate change and the urgent need for effective emergency response systems. {"uri": "8243807428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:27:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/wildfire-engulfs-parts-of-main-town-in-canadas-jasper-national-park/article_2f57b3b2-780b-54fa-bda8-f81aef9e24e1.html", "title": "Wildfire engulfs parts of main town in Canada's Jasper National Park", "body": "An \"out of control\" wildfire has devoured up to half of the main town in western Canada's popular Jasper National Park, authorities said Thursday, with 400 foreign firefighters called in to help battle the blaze.\n\nWhile the fire has so far caused no casualties, as many as 25,000 residents and tourists were evacuated from the area before the conflagration suddenly grew in size, overtaking firefighters.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" said Danielle Smith, Alberta province's premier, adding that damage to the town was estimated at between \"30 to 50 percent.\"\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau called images of the damage \"heartbreaking,\" and said his government had asked more than 400 firefighters from Australia, New Zealand, Mexico and South Africa to aid local authorities.\n\n\"Thank you for your courage, and for working non-stop to fight these wildfires,\" he said in a post on social media platform X.\n\nA video circulating on social media showed the city of Jasper's streets covered in ash, with cars turned to charred carcasses and buildings reduced to rubble.\n\nMayor Richard Ireland wrote in an online post of a sense of destruction and loss that was \"beyond description and comprehension.\"\n\nOn Thursday, firefighters were still hard at work in the town, with much-anticipated rain having \"no significant impact\" on the blaze, according to Jasper National Park authorities.\n\n\"Jasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight. While the rain helped reduce fire activity slightly, it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control,\" read a post on the park's X account.\n\nIn places, the flames reached a height of 120 meters (390 feet) and were moving at a speed of 15 meters per minute.\n\nThe fire entered the deserted town on Wednesday evening after advancing very rapidly late in the day, pushed by strong winds in a region hit by severe drought and which has seen record heat in recent days.\n\nMore from this section Head of Myanmar Junta Assumes Presidential Powers as Civil War Drags On - TaiwanPlus News Trump Finally Reveals What Biden Told Him After Assassination Attempt: 'You're Lucky To...' | US News Olympics chance for USA to 'come together', says flagbearer Gauff\n\nJasper National Park, Canada's largest, is known for its mountains, glaciers, lakes and waterfalls, and attracts 2.5 million visitors every year.\n\n- 'Devastation' -\n\n\"Everyone has a total feeling of devastation,\" said Pattie Pavlov, a Jasper resident who drove for hours on Monday night to escape the advancing fire.\n\n\"Many people are feeling very helpless. Because there's nothing that we can do.\"\n\nThe general manager of the Jasper Park Chamber of Commerce said she had taken refuge with friends more than 500 kilometers (310 miles) away from her home.\n\nIn tears, Alberta Premier Smith provided an assessment of the damage and recalled that \"for many generations\" the town and Jasper National Park were \"a source of pride.\"\n\nIn recent days, numerous fires have been started by lightning in western Canada.\n\nIn Alberta province, more than 170 fires were active on Thursday, including more than a dozen in the Fort McMurray region, a hub of oil sands development.\n\nBritish Columbia, Alberta's neighboring province, was grappling with 400 active fires, more than half of which were burning out of control.\n\nFifty-six fires have The town and the park, which draws more than two million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe blaze is one of hundreds ravaging the western provinces of Alberta and British Columbia. The federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada.\n\nOfficials said the flames in Jasper reached a height of 400 feet and moved at 15 meters a minute.\n\n\"As the pictures and videos circulating online show, significant loss has occurred within the town site,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending help. One major focus is the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"Losing structures, community, is like losing a close friend ... (but) the people have been saved and that is significant. We can find a way to rebuild,\" Jasper mayor Richard Ireland told the Canadian Broadcasting Corp.\n\nOne of the buildings destroyed by fire was the Maligne Lodge hotel in the south of the town.\n\n\"It's just so sad to know that so many families and people have lost not just their belongings but their livelihood and a beautiful park,\" owner Karyne Decore told the CBC.\n\nThere are currently 175 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil center of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents. The blaze destroyed 10% of all structures in the city and shut in more than a million barrels per day of oil output.\n\n(Reporting by David Ljunggren: Editing by Angus MacSwan)", "source": {"uri": 'Significant loss' in townsite | Flames hit Jasper Park Lodge grounds", "body": "This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.\n\nA few hours earlier, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate.\n\nThat launched a line of cars and trucks snaking east to the town of Hinton, outside the park gates.\n\nJasper was under attack by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 park visitors -- have already left.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday.\n\nThe southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong earlier Wednesday did go wrong.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"", "source": {"uri": "edmontonjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Edmonton Journal"}, {"uri": "8243600443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:31:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:31:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:31:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/americas/2024/07/25/wildfires-burn-down-part-of-jasper-in-canada-as-thousands-evacuated-in-california/", "title": "Wildfires burn down part of Jasper in Canada as thousands evacuated in California", "body": "Tourist town in Alberta province 'seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage' and 'significant loss' of buildings\n\nA raging wildfire has devastated the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper and firefighters were working on Thursday to save as many buildings as possible, authorities said.\n\nJasper is in the middle of Jasper National Park, in the province of Alberta. The town and the park, which draw more than 2 million tourists a year, were evacuated on Monday, when officials estimated there were 15,000 visitors in the park.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, saying the fire was still out of control.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30 per cent to 50 per cent structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage or which areas had been hit.\n\nVideo from the town showed entire blocks had burned to the ground, including a church.\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of a fire that had ravaged the community.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire reaches the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where dozens of fires are also out of control.\n\nOfficials said that at one point on Wednesday the flames had reached a height of 120m and were moving at 15m a minute.\n\nAshley Kliewer, co-owner of a restaurant in the middle of Jasper, told the Canadian Broadcasting crop she was devastated.\n\n\"I don't think anyone will be returning to Jasper any time soon and life is not going to be anywhere near what it was - it really is the end of an era,\" she said.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents. The blaze destroyed 10 per cent of all structures in the city and shut in more than a million barrels per day of oil output.\n\nElsewhere, thousands of people were evacuated in northern California overnight, as yet another rapidly growing wildfire raged, joining hundreds of blazes in the Pacific Northwest and Canada that are sending smoke across swathes of the region, fire officials and weather services said.\n\nThe Park Fire in Butte County, California, exploded overnight from about 566 hectares on Wednesday to about 18,400 hectares on Thursday, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.\n\nIt's burning in California's Central Valley about 130km north of the state capital Sacramento, and was only 3 per cent contained on Thursday morning, said Cal Fire public information officer Dan Collins. No injuries were reported. Thousands were ordered to leave their homes.\n\n\"We have 400 firefighters and personnel on the scene, but we have units headed our way from all across the state,\" Collins said. \"The help is needed.\"\n\nMore than 4,000 people were evacuated in Butte County and the city of Chico, said Megan McMann a spokesperson for the Butte County Sheriff's Office.\n\nThe largest fire now burning in the United States, Oregon's Durkee Fire, has burned at least 97,000 hectares, threatened multiple small towns, scorched ranch land and killed cattle by the hundreds, local media reports said.\n\nHigh winds with lightning strikes Wednesday and overnight could fan the flames, said Marc Chenard, a forecaster with the National Weather Service in College Park, Maryland.\n\nThe fire, about 160km northwest of Boise, Idaho, was zero per cent contained on Thursday morning. More wind was forecast and lightning possible. - Reuters", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Irish Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": As of Wednesday it was still operating, with sprinklers being used to protect it.\n\nThere have been more than 400 fires recorded in British Columbia and 176 in the neighbouring province of Alberta.\n\nFires were first reported in Jasper last week. The town's mayor, Richard Ireland, told CBC that the town was facing its \"worst nightmare\".\n\nEleonor Dumlao told the Edmonton Journal she was filled with panic when her family received the evacuation order. They left Jasper on Monday night and headed to an evacuation centre in Edmonton.\n\n\"It was so very terrible experience for us, and I was so panicking that time. I don't know what to do. I don't know what to get first,\" she told the newspaper.\n\nJasper National Park said on X that \"air quality had deteriorated\" in the area. The park is the largest national park in the Canadian Rockies.\n\nAfter evacuations were issued, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith told residents to \"leave safely\" on Wednesday. In a post on Facebook, she said she was in \"constant contact\" with the authorities.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau says his government has approved a request for federal assistance for Alberta.\n\n\"We're deploying @CanadianForces resources, evacuations support, and more emergency wildfire resources to the province immediately -- and we're coordinating firefighting and airlift assistance,\" Mr Trudeau said on X.\n\nDaniel Turner also recounted how he evacuated the wildfires to the Edmonton Journal, saying he followed evacuation orders with three of his friends but hit bumper-to-bumper traffic fleeing Jasper and turned around.\n\nThe group slept in a Canadian Tire parking lot.\n\n\"You could see it deteriorating, like ash falling,\" he said of the wildfire smoke.\n\nEarlier in the week, several US states including California and Utah were hit by wildfires.\n\nMore than 30 million people in the US have been affected by heat warnings since early July, according to the National Weather Service. Some residents of Jasper National Park who were trapped in traffic for hours while evacuating due to wildfires say they are feeling relieved they've found safety. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Jeff McIntoshEDMONTON - One of two raging, wind-whipped fires menacing Jasper, Alta., has roared into town and begun burning buildings. Park officials say the fire entered the southern edge of the community at about 6:40 p.m. They say crews are battling multiple structural fires and working to protect key infrastructure. Officials say wildland firefighters and others without self-contained breathing apparatuses have been told to evacuate to the nearby town of Hinton, with structural firefighters staying behind. A few hours earlier, all first responders were ordered out of Jasper National Park for their safety and to give fire crews more room to operate. Jasper is being menaced by fires from the north and south, and the town's 5,000 residents -- along with 20,000 more park visitors -- fled on short notice late Monday night when the fires flared up. {"uri": "8243118943", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:17:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:17:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:15:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/3029943-raging-wildfire-devastates-jasper-alberta", "title": "Raging Wildfire Devastates Jasper, Alberta | Science-Environment", "body": "A fierce wildfire has ravaged parts of Jasper, a western Canadian tourist town in Alberta. Authorities evacuated the area and are working to save buildings. Forecasted rain may aid firefighting efforts. The fire is among hundreds across Alberta and British Columbia, marking one of Canada's worst wildfire seasons.\n\nA raging wildfire has burned down part of the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper. Firefighters are working to save as many buildings as possible, according to authorities.\n\nJasper, located in Jasper National Park in Alberta, was evacuated on Monday. The park attracts more than two million tourists annually.\n\nEnvironment Canada predicts rain, which may help firefighters. This fire is one of hundreds in Alberta and British Columbia, making it one of Canada's worst years for wildfires.\n\nFlames in Jasper reached 400 feet in height, moving at 15 meters per minute. Parks Canada confirmed significant damage within the town.\n\nThe federal government and Alberta cities are providing support, with focus on the Trans Mountain oil pipeline. Mayor Richard Ireland emphasized the significance of saving lives despite the loss.\n\nThe Maligne Lodge hotel was among the destroyed buildings. Owner Karyne Decore expressed sadness over the loss of livelihoods and the park's beauty.\n\nCurrently, 175 wildfires are burning in Alberta, with over 50 out of control. The Jasper fire could be the most damaging since the 2016 Fort McMurray fire, which destroyed 10% of structures and halted significant oil output.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8243612054", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:43:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:43:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:42:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://edmonton.citynews.ca/2024/07/25/jasper-wildfire-structures-loss-alberta-premier/", "title": "Alberta premier says up to half of Jasper's structures destroyed in wildfire", "body": "In an emotional update Thursday, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith tried to hold back tears as she spoke of her memories of Jasper and the loss, fear, and loneliness residents of the town must be feeling.\n\nSmith said the blaze, which reached the townsite Wednesday, is estimated to have damaged between 30 and 50 per cent of structures in Jasper.\n\n\"If you've seen the images as I have, we don't know particularly which structures have been damaged and which ones have been destroyed,\" she said. \"But that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nThe wildfire in Jasper National Park is still out of control, according to the province.\n\nSmith adds while photos and videos are being posted to social media on the destruction and loss cause by the wildfire, the province hasn't been able to confirm the losses.\n\nParks Canada officials echoed that sentiment in its afternoon update, saying right now, they are focused on getting the fire out.\n\nThe premier said the province is doing all it can to help those impacted by the Jasper wildfire.\n\nShe says the Emergency Management Cabinet Committee has been meeting daily for the last several days, and will continue to do.\n\nSmith has also been in contact with Federal Minister of Public Safety, Dominic Leblanc, Jasper Mayor Richard Ireland, and Minister of Emergency Preparedness, Harjit Sajjan, as well as the Alberta Management Agency.\n\nSajjan is set to arrive in Edmonton Thursday for a meeting with provincial officials. A call between Smith and Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is also scheduled for 2:30 p.m.\n\nMinister of Public Safety and Emergency Services, Mike Ellis was also on hand during Thursday's provincial update and confirmed that the flames hit 100 metres in some areas Wednesday night.\n\nThe fire was accelerated by a significant gust of wind.\n\n\"That fire was about five kilometres out [and] there was an enormous wind gust,\" he said. \"That wind gust moved the fire five kilometers in probably less than 30 minutes, with a wall of fire that was about 100 meters high.\n\n\"I think people need to picture what those wildfire folks were experiencing at that time. Any firefighter will tell you, there's little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming in like that.\"\n\nEllis also confirmed that Edmonton, Calgary, and Grand Prairie are accommodating evacuees, noting mental health supports are also available.\n\nSome acute care patients have, however, have been taken to Edson and Hinton, with two patients being taken to Prince George.\n\nFirefighters from across 34 municipalities, Lakeland College and industrial firefighters from across the province have been called in to help battle structure fires in Jasper, according to Minister Ellis.\n\nIn total, nearly 1,900 Alberta firefighters, contractors and support staff are working to battle wildfires in the province.\n\nIn addition to this, Alberta Wildfire says crews from Australia landed over the weekend, and at least 400 additional firefighters from overseas are expected in the coming days -- 100 from Mexico later Thursday, 200 from South Africa are expected to arrive on Friday, and an additional 100 from Australia and New Zealand are expected Sunday and Monday.\n\n\"These resources will be sent around the province to areas where they will be most effective in the wildfire response,\" said Christie Tucker, the information unit manager with Alberta Wildfire. \"Alberta Wildfire has been active supporting Parks Canada in their response to wildfires.\"\n\nTucker adds the province has supplied water, trucks, heavy equipment, helicopters, and unit crews to Parks Canada officials, and offered air tanker and night vision equipped helicopters.\n\nDuring her opening speech on the update, Smith also went on to thank everyone who is currently helping battle wildfires across Alberta, before reassuring everyone from around the world that the magic of Jasper \"is not lost, and it will never will be.\"\n\n\"To the brave men and women currently in Jasper, I want to express my deep gratitude and the gratitude of all Albertans, whether you are part of the initial efforts or whether you were activated and drove in there last night or early this morning,\" said Smith.\n\n\"There really are not enough words to express our thanks and our wishes for your safety and your success. Once again, you put yourselves on the front lines in the show of true heroism. Thank you for your bravery and your commitment to keeping Albertans safe.\"\n\nAdding that residents, families, and business owners will recover from the wildfire.\n\nAlberta wildfire also provided an update on existing wildfires that are impacting the province.\n\nEvacuation orders are still in effect for John D'Or Prairie, Fox Lake, Garden River and Chippewan Lake.\n\nEvacuation orders have been lifted for the hamlet of Janvier due to recent rainfall in that part of the province, which has helped crews get the fire under control.\n\nIt is estimated that over 17,500 people have been displaced from wildfires. It is also believed that roughly 25,000 people were in the Jasper National Park at the time of its evacuation order earlier this week, with the majority of those being visitors.\n\nThe province added that those who are part of the mandatory evacuation order can register online, and receive some temporary funding from the province.", "source": {"uri": "edmonton.citynews.ca", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8243150923", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "13:37:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T13:37:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T13:36:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/world/thousands-evacuated-as-canada-wildfire-threatens-energy-pipelines-and-peoples-lifelines-744144", "title": "Thousands evacuated as Canada wildfire threatens energy pipelines and people's lifelines", "body": "Prime Minister Justin Trudeau announced federal assistance for Alberta, including the deployment of federal Canadian resources and additional emergency wildfire support.\n\nThe picturesque Canadian tourist town of Jasper, about 790 km north of Vancouver, has been engulfed in flames due to raging wildfire. A total of 25,000 residents have been evacuated as the fires continue to ravage Jasper National Park.\n\nThe inferno is part of a larger crisis that has gripped Canada's western provinces of Alberta and British Columbia (BC). The British Columbia Wildfire Service has said that the surge in fires is due to over 58,000 lightning strikes in the past week followed by a three-week heat wave.\n\nApproximately 1,900 firefighters from Alberta have been deployed to combat the blazes.\n\nAlso read | Mass evacuation: Wildfires force 9,000 to leave homes in Canada\n\nTheir efforts include protecting critical infrastructure, such as the Trans Mountain Pipeline, a Canadian government-owned pipeline that traverses Jasper National Park. Sprinklers are being used to safeguard the pipeline, which remains operational as of Wednesday (July 24).\n\nThe wildfire situation is dire with more than 400 fires recorded in British Columbia and 176 in Alberta.\n\nThe fires first erupted in Jasper last week. Mayor Richard Ireland described the situation as the town's \"worst nightmare\" in an interview with CBC.\n\nJasper National Park officials warned on X that the air quality in the area has significantly deteriorated. The park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is facing unprecedented damage.\n\nIn response to the crisis, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith urged residents to evacuate safely in a Facebook post on Wednesday (July 24).\n\nThe wildfires in Jasper are part of a broader pattern of extreme weather impacting North America. Several U.S. states, including California and Utah, have also been battling wildfires. The National Weather Service reports that over 30 million people in the US have been under heat warnings since early July, affecting regions such as California, Arizona, Nevada, Oregon, and Washington {"uri": "8243359790", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:05:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:05:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:02:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.rocketnews.com/2024/07/famous-rockies-resort-of-jasper-on-fire-as-thousands-flee/", "title": "Famous Rockies resort of Jasper on fire as thousands flee - RocketNews", "body": "Buildings in the Canadian tourist town of Jasper have been burning after wildfires forced 25,000 people to evacuate the area earlier this week, officials said. The blaze has spread through Jasper National Park, causing \"significant loss\" within the local town, according to park officials on X, formerly Twitter.Hundreds of wildfires have sparked in the western provinces of Alberta and British Columbia (BC).The region has been hit by more than 58,000 lightning strikes within the last week, sparking new blazes after a three-week heat wave, according to BC Wildfire Service.Around 1,900 Alberta firefighters have been deployed, assisted by personnel from Alaska and Australia, and are working to save local infrastructure.That includes the Trans Mountain Pipeline, a Canadian government-owned pipeline that runs through Jasper National Park. As of Wednesday it was still operating, with sprinklers being used to protect it.There have been more than 400 fires recorded in British Columbia and 176 in the neighbouring province of Alberta. Fires were first reported in Jasper last week. The town's mayor, Richard Ireland, told CBC that the town was facing its \"worst nightmare\". \"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Mr Ireland wrote on Facebook on Thursday morning. \"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension; my deepest sympathies go out to each of you.\"Mr Ireland noted first responders were still working to protect the town from further destruction. The wildfire reached the grounds of Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge on Wednesday night, Anastasia Martin-Stilwell, a spokesperson for the historic resort said. {"uri": "8243525634", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:14:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:14:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:17:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.rmoutlook.com/banff/parks-canada-assessing-damage-after-fire-ravaged-jasper-firefighting-efforts-continue-9267355", "title": "Parks Canada assessing damage after fire 'ravaged' Jasper, firefighting efforts continue", "body": "JASPER - An out-of-control fire ravaged the community of Jasper overnight Wednesday (July 24), burning down homes, businesses and hotels, but firefighters are not in a position to say the extent of the damage at this point.\n\nIn a news release from Parks Canada at 10:30 a.m. Thursday, the agency said no one has been injured in the disaster and all residents, visitors and first responders made it out safely.\n\nDue to the ongoing explosive fire conditions, efforts continue to fight the blaze and Parks Canada says it is \"impossible to share information about specific locations and the extent of damage at this time.\"\n\n\"As you can understand, the accuracy of this information is critical because it has a direct impact on members of the community. We will share more information as soon as we are able to ensure its accuracy,\" the federal agency stated.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, workplaces, businesses, and cherished places, we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures.\"\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland penned a heartfelt message to his community earlier this morning.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" he said.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension; my deepest sympathies go out to each of you.\"\n\nParks Canada officials say Jasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight, but it was not enough to help fan the flames and the fire continues to burn out-of-control.\n\nThey said significant structural firefighting reinforcements were brought in throughout the night and have continued to help with daunting firefighting efforts in the community overnight and this morning.\n\n\"Parks Canada, the Municipality of Jasper, and our partners from Alberta and across Canada are continuing to respond to this emergency,\" said Parks Canada.\n\n\"In Unified Command, Parks Canada and the Municipality of Jasper continue to manage this crisis from the Town of Hinton.\"\n\nMore than 25,000 people fled Jasper overnight on Monday and into Tuesday, with two fires approaching the national park townsite from both the south and the north.\n\nThe fast-moving fires blocked off evacuation routes along Highway 93 North towards Lake Louise and Highway 16 to Hinton, leaving only one heavily-clogged road out along Highway 16 west into British Columbia.\n\nParks Canada says the emergency evolved rapidly from the first report of a wildfire starting to the northeast of the Jasper townsite on Monday evening just after 7 p.m., to a second more explosive fire south of town shortly after.\n\n\"Within 48 hours, the wildfires reached town,\" they said.\n\nIreland sent sincere thanks to Parks Canada and other partners along with municipal fire agencies who sent firefighters, fire personnel and equipment to help protect Jasper and the surrounding national park.\n\n\"We also wish to acknowledge and thank all the communities who have received everyone who has been displaced by this fire,\" he said.\n\nIreland said the No. 1 priority continues to be safety and well-being.\n\n\"The Incident Management Team together with responders on the ground, continue to work valiantly to protect our town - our home - and to coordinate supports for evacuees in other communities,\" he said.\n\n\"I want to assure you that your mayor and councillors are committed to supporting our community through this truly unprecedented challenge and beyond,\" he added.\n\n\"We will work closely with all levels of government, other organizations, and volunteers to coordinate relief efforts and provide essential resources and information.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nThe following are a list of resources provided by the Municipality of Jasper:\n\n\ud835\uddd8\ud835\uddfa\ud835\uddfc\ud835\ude01\ud835\uddf6\ud835\uddfc\ud835\uddfb\ud835\uddee\ud835\uddf9 \ud835\udde6\ud835\ude02\ud835\uddfd\ud835\uddfd\ud835\uddfc\ud835\uddff\ud835\ude01 \ud835\uddee\ud835\uddfb\ud835\uddf1 \ud835\udde0\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddfb\ud835\ude01\ud835\uddee\ud835\uddf9 \ud835\udddb\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddee\ud835\uddf9\ud835\ude01\ud835\uddf5 \ud835\uddd6\ud835\uddfc\ud835\uddfa\ud835\uddfa\ud835\uddfc\ud835\uddfb \ud835\udde6\ud835\ude01\ud835\uddff\ud835\uddf2\ud835\ude00\ud835\ude00 \ud835\udde5\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddee\ud835\uddf0\ud835\ude01\ud835\uddf6\ud835\uddfc\ud835\uddfb\ud835\ude00: It's normal to feel overwhelmed, anxious, or sad. Some physical symptoms might include headaches, stomach aches, or muscle tension. \ud835\uddea\ud835\uddf5\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddfb \ud835\ude01\ud835\uddfc \ud835\udde6\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddf8 \ud835\udddb\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddf9\ud835\uddfd: If you experience severe emotional reactions, such as excessive guilt, anxiety, or thoughts of self-harm, please reach out for professional help. \ud835\udde7\ud835\uddee\ud835\uddf8\ud835\uddf6\ud835\uddfb\ud835\uddf4 \ud835\uddd6\ud835\uddee\ud835\uddff\ud835\uddf2 \ud835\uddfc\ud835\uddf3 \ud835\uddec\ud835\uddfc\ud835\ude02\ud835\uddff\ud835\ude00\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddf9\ud835\uddf3 \ud835\uddee\ud835\uddfb\ud835\uddf1 \ud835\udddf\ud835\uddfc\ud835\ude03\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddf1 \ud835\udde2\ud835\uddfb\ud835\uddf2\ud835\ude00 Eat Well and Stay Hydrated: Good nutrition and hydration are crucial for maintaining your energy, focus, and overall health. Stay Active: Gentle physical activities, like walking or stretching, can help relieve stress and improve your mood. Get Enough Rest: Ensure you and your family get adequate sleep to better manage stress and emotions. Practice Relaxation Techniques: Deep breathing exercises can calm your nervous system and help you think more clearly. Support for Children and Teens Limit Media Exposure: Protect children from repeated exposure to distressing news. When they do see or hear about the disaster, discuss it calmly and reassure them. Model Positive Coping: Children learn from your reactions.\n\n\ud835\udddb\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddf9\ud835\uddfd\ud835\uddf6\ud835\uddfb\ud835\uddf4 \ud835\uddd6\ud835\uddf5\ud835\uddf6\ud835\uddf9\ud835\uddf1\ud835\uddff\ud835\uddf2\ud835\uddfb \ud835\uddd6\ud835\uddfc\ud835\uddfd\ud835\uddf2:\n\nEncourage Open Communication: Let children express their feelings and ask questions. Answer honestly at a level they can understand. Maintain Routines: Keeping regular meal and sleep times can provide a sense of normalcy and security.\n\n\ud835\udde5\ud835\uddf2\ud835\ude00\ud835\uddfc\ud835\ude02\ud835\uddff\ud835\uddf0\ud835\uddf2\ud835\ude00:\n\nPsychologists' Association of Alberta: 3 free sessions with a volunteer psychologist. 1-888-424-0297 | [email protected] Mental Health Help Line (24/7): 1-877-303-2642 Addiction Help Line: 1-866-332-2322 First Nations & Inuit Hope for Wellness Help Line: 1-855-242-3310 Crisis Text Line Text: \"CONNECT\" to 741741 Alberta 211: 211 Alberta is a 24/7 crisis line and single point of contact for digital supports and services near you - no matter where you are in the province. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, urged them to stay strong.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Ireland wrote.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nAbout 25,000 people, including about 5,000 residents in the Jasper townsite, were forced to flee west at a moment's notice late Monday night as twin wildfires from the south and north roared up and cut off access to the east and south.\n\nA day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist.\n\nOn Wednesday, efforts to contain the fires -- include buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by raging, gusting winds.\n\nAround 6 p.m. Wednesday, the fire roared in and began torching structures.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.", {"uri": "8243761523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:27:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:27:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:26:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://theprint.in/environment/devastating-wildfire-burns-down-part-of-western-canadian-town/2191787/", "title": "Devastating wildfire burns down part of western Canadian town", "body": "\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, saying the fire was still out of control.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild.\"\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage or which areas had been hit.\n\nVideo from the town showed entire blocks had burned to the ground, including a church.\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of a fire that had ravaged the community.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension,\" he said in a letter to residents.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire reaches the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where dozens of fires are also out of control.\n\n\"Many of the wildfires we're seeing at this time of year are lightning caused and we unfortunately can't control the weather,\" said Alberta forestry minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada.\n\nOfficials said that at one point on Wednesday the flames had reached a height of 400 feet and were moving at 15 meters (50 feet) a minute.\n\nAshley Kliewer, co-owner of a restaurant in the middle of Jasper, told the Canadian Broadcasting crop she was devastated.\n\n\"I don't think anyone will be returning to Jasper any time soon and life is not going to be anywhere near what it was - it really is the end of an era,\" she said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents. The blaze destroyed 10% of all structures in the city and shut in more than a million barrels per day of oil output.\n\nFort McMurray is forecast to receive up to 65 mm of rain in the next day, according to Environment Canada.\n\n(Reporting by David Ljunggren: Editing by Angus MacSwan; Editing by Aurora Ellis)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, {"uri": "8243742074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:06:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:06:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:03:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/devastating-wildfire-burns-down-part-of-western-canadian-tourist-town/2191839/", "title": "Devastating wildfire burns down part of western Canadian tourist town", "body": "\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" Alberta premier Danielle Smith told reporters, while choking back tears.\n\n\"We're seeing potentially 30% to 50% structural damage ... that's going to be a significant rebuild,\" she said, adding the fire was still out of control.\n\nParks Canada said there had been a \"significant loss\" of buildings inside the town but added it could not give specific details of the damage, or which areas had been hit and it urged residents not to return.\n\nVideo from the town showed vehicles and entire blocks burned to the ground, including a historic Anglican church.\n\nJasper resident Eva Korduliakova heard the news that her home was burning from thousands of kilometers away Thursday morning, while visiting family in the Czech Republic with her seven-year-old son.\n\n\"I am single mum who became homeless and jobless overnight,\" she wrote in an email. \"Our house is gone. I didn't get a chance to grab any of my belongings.\"\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland said the town was beginning to come to terms with \"the devastating impact\" of the fire.\n\n\"Last night's wildfires have simply ravaged our small tight-knit mountain community, the destruction and the loss that so many of our residents are facing simply defies description,\" he told a press conference, his voice breaking.\n\nOne major concern for responders is if the fire damages the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"At this time there is no indication of damage to our infrastructure, and the pipelines continue to operate safely,\" pipeline operator Trans Mountain said in a statement.\n\nCN Rail said it suspended rail operations through the town on Wednesday afternoon as the wildfire conditions worsened.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. In addition, a total of 400 firefighters from Mexico, South Africa, Australia and New Zealand are due to arrive in the coming days.\n\nThere are currently 176 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where there 423 wildfires burning and dozens of evacuation orders and alerts.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be a catastrophic year for wildfires in Canada.\n\nThe Jasper fire was caused by a lightning strike on Monday afternoon and fuelled by strong winds, according to Parks Canada.\n\nFlames from the blaze rose 100 meters high (3 feet), and strong wind gusts on Wednesday afternoon pushed the fire 5 kilometers (3 miles) in less than 30 minutes, said Alberta public safety minister Mike Ellis.\n\n\"Any firefighter will tell you there's little to nothing you can do when you have a wall of flames coming at you like that,\" Ellis said.\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil town of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents and destroying 10% of all structures in the city.\n\n(Reporting by David Ljunggren in Ottawa, Nia Williams in British Columbia and Anna Mehler Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n11:30 a.m.\n\nParks Canada says \"significant\" structural firefighting reinforcements arrived in Jasper overnight to help get the wildfire situation under control.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIt says officials with Parks Canada and the Municipality of Jasper are based in the Town of Hinton, about 80 kilometres to the east, as they manage the emergency.\n\nThe agency says officials understand that people are desperate for information about the status of their homes and community, but officials cannot yet share information about the extent of the damage at specific locations.\n\n-- -\n\n11:15 a.m.\n\nParks Canada says Jasper National Park saw a small amount of rain overnight, helping reduce fire activity \"slightly,\" but it wasn't enough to have a meaningful impact on the out-of-control blaze.\n\nThe agency says the emergency unfolded rapidly Monday night as two fires north and south of Jasper both reached the town within 48 hours.\n\nIt says the evacuation involved about 25,000 people from the town and the national park, and there have been no injuries reported as a result of the blazes.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n-- -\n\n10:44 a.m.\n\nCalgary emergency officials say they're sending crews to help battle the Jasper wildfire.\n\nSue Henry, the head of Calgary's emergency services, says 19 Calgary crews were headed north to the fire scene.\n\nCalgary is the location of one of two evacuation centres set up to handle those fleeing the fires in Jasper National Park, with the other in Grande Prairie.\n\n-- -\n\n10:44 a.m.\n\nA social media video is showing widespread destruction in Jasper.\n\nThe images depict rain-slicked streets in the town and grey-black structures razed to charred foundations.\n\nThe video appears to have been shot from an emergency vehicle, with radio chatter about the firefighting efforts before the truck stops in front of a destroyed property and {"uri": "8243480453", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:38:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:38:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:37:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/jasper-evacuees-1.7274885", "title": "'It's just surreal': What Jasper wildfire evacuees are saying | CBC News", "body": "Jasper evacuees are fearing the worst as they flee two wildfires tearing through the historic Alberta mountain town.\n\nImages and videos on social media show flames consuming multiple buildings, including homes and well-known businesses in the Jasper National Park townsite.\n\nTim Urbanovitch has his RV, and has a home in Alberta to get back to. He just doesn't know how he is going to get there.\n\nHe was camping just south of the Jasper townsite on Monday when a wildfire ignited.\n\n\"We were sitting in a sun shelter, having a cool one, and the storm blew in and we saw lightning strikes,\" he said. \"All of a sudden -- a big brown cloud, which was kinda spooky looking. People started to panic in the campground, pulling out.\"\n\nShortly after that, a ranger came through the campsite and told everyone it was time to evacuate.\n\nHe and his companions spent the night camped out near Mt. Robson, on the B.C. side of the border. But most the RV-suitable roads home are blocked. Finding places to stop on a route full of detours is challenging. All the RV campgrounds are already booked, he said.\n\nAshley Kliewer and her husband drove to Edmonton with their two kids, pet guinea pig and two cats in the vehicle. Now they are waiting to hear whether the fire reached their home.\n\n\"The lack of information is excruciating,\" she said. \"I know at least a dozen families whose homes are gone. My understanding is the east end of town is completely burned.\"\n\nShe doesn't know if her home is still there, or if either of her family's restaurants is still standing.\n\nOne of those restaurants, the Peacock Cork & Fork, opened just last month.\n\n\"We poured every dollar, and then some, into getting this space open and it's such a beautiful concept. And now ... it's gone.\"\n\nKliewer is also co-owner of Raven Bistro in Jasper.\n\nShe said she doesn't know what to do next.\n\n\"We're very grateful ... people's outpouring of support has been amazing. But we have what's in our van and I don't think anyone will be returning to Jasper any time soon,\" she said. \"Life is not going to be anything near what it was. Really it's the end of an era.\"\n\nBen Nearingburg is owner of Starry Summit Mountain Adventures, a Jasper hiking guiding company. It's a small business he started operating with his fianc\u00e9e just two years ago.\n\nHe has been looking at pictures of the fire tearing through the town, and wondering how he can save his livelihood.\n\n\"It's just surreal the images you see of everyone's places on fire. Places you have so many memories of. It's so unbelievable how quickly things change.\"\n\nHe said he's been emailing everyone who had trips booked in the coming weeks, trying to explain the situation. To keep his business going, he will have to convince visitors to change their itineraries to activities outside of the park.\n\nP.E.I. musician Catherine MacLellan was visiting friends in Jasper during her tour of Western Canada when the evacuation order came at 10 p.m. She says traffic was \"bumper to bumper for hours and hours,\" with two of three exits out of Jasper closed due to encroaching fires.\n\n\"It was scary because there was this feeling that the fire could breech the town at any point. If you were stuck there in traffic and not able to get out, just the thought of that,\" said MacLellan.\n\n\"Once you hit the mountain road there's no cell service, so it's an intense place to be fleeing from in very slow traffic.\"\n\nThe group made it safely to Valemount, B.C. After a few hours of rest, MacLellan made the 12-hour drive to Calgary, where she had a place to stay with other friends.\n\nJasper was under threat from the north and south, and mandatory evacuation orders were issued Monday as the fires flared, forcing as many as 25,000 residents and visitors out.\n\nPark officials have reported \"significant loss\" in Jasper but have not detailed the damage to specific buildings or neighbourhoods.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campsite", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-433524446", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:09:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:09:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:08:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://dailyhive.com/calgary/last-best-campio-banff-ave-discounts-jasper-evacuees", "title": "Alberta pubs offering 50% off food for Jasper evacuees", "body": "A collection of Alberta brewpubs is offering 50% discounts on food for those impacted by the evacuation of Jasper.\n\nEarlier this week, an evacuation order was posted for the town of Jasper and Jasper National Park due to multiple wildfires burning in the area.\n\nNow, three spots in Alberta are offering their help to Jasper evacuees who have made their way to Calgary, Edmonton and Banff.\n\nLast Best Brewing in Calgary, Campio Brewing in Edmonton, and Banff Ave Brewing in Banff -- all part of the Bearhill family -- will offer hefty discounts on food for those who have been displaced.\n\nIn Instagram posts, each of the pubs said communities in Calgary, Edmonton and Banff are \"rallying to support our friends in Jasper,\" adding that they want to help as best they can.\n\n\"If you are taking refuge... and need a place to hang out, come down to the pub,\" the posts read.\n\n\"We'd like to offer evacuees 50% off regular-priced food items until it is safe for them to return to Jasper,\" the spots said.\n\nBearhill also owns Jasper Brewing, a popular spot in the heart of the town.\n\nJasper National Park is expected to be closed for at least two weeks due to the wildfires, but no estimate has been given for its reopening.
