{"uri": "8243828073", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:58:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:58:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:57:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "http://theconversation.com/the-2024-jasper-fire-is-a-grim-reminder-of-the-urgency-of-adopting-a-canadian-national-wildfire-strategy-235567", "title": "The 2024 Jasper Fire is a grim reminder of the urgency of adopting a Canadian national wildfire strategy", "body": "Queen's University, Ontario provides funding as a member of The Conversation CA-FR.\n\nIn what is becoming an unfortunately common occurrence, the town of Jasper, Alta. has been ravaged by a wildfire of unprecedented scale. Crews report witnessing \"300- to 400-foot flames,\" while up to 50 per cent of Jasper's buildings may be damaged. Luckily, there have been no reported fatalities so far.\n\nIf a fire can burn the town of Jasper in a national park that has the resources to deal with fire, what does the future hold for hundreds of small boreal forest towns across the country that do not have the means, know-how or resolve to accept that fire will come someday?\n\nJasper is the latest in a growing number of communities affected by wildfires. Twenty thousand people living in Yellowknife were evacuated from their homes for more than three weeks in 2023. The B.C. town of Lytton is still rebuilding after it burned in 2021.\n\nIndigenous people, who represent five per cent of the population, are disproportionately affected by wildfires, as First Nations communities comprise 42 per cent of evacuations. Residents of Fort Good Hope, a community that is mainly Indigenous in the Northwest Territories, were recently displaced from their homes for three weeks due to a wildfire.\n\nJasper reinforces just how much we need a national wildfire strategy to bring together all levels of governance within the business and Indigenous communities to map out a blueprint for how to better predict, prevent, mitigate and manage fires, and how to provide small boreal communities with the resources they need to make them more resilient.\n\nLongtime coming\n\nIn the summer of 2010, Parks Canada fire manager Dave Smith conducted aerial and ground surveys of three main valleys in Jasper National Park and found that 400 trees had been attacked by the mountain pine beetle.\n\nUntil then, Jasper had been one of the few regions on the east slopes of the Rockies that had not been seriously affected by this slow-moving catastrophe. This beetle species has destroyed pristine views, shuttered lumber mills, increased the threat of forest fires while dead needles are still in the trees and reshaped British Columbia's economy.\n\nIn 2011, I joined Smith on an aerial and ground survey to see how the infestation was progressing. So many trees in Jasper had been reddened by the pine beetle that Smith decided there was no use counting again; he would have to find some other way of monitoring the situation.\n\nRead more: How to protect your home from wildfires - here's what fire prevention experts say is most important\n\nBefore he retired, Smith told me that, although he loved his job, he had trouble sleeping at night on hot summer days. He worried about a wind-driven wildfire sweeping through the highly combustible needles still clinging to all those dead trees and the living stands of 80-year-old spruce and pine that were at risk of burning. It wasn't just the aging forest and dead needles that worried him; it was the intense heat, extended droughts and lightning that were intensifying in a rapidly warming world.\n\nParks Canada fire specialists like Smith have done a lot to prevent fire from coming into Jasper, Banff and other park towns across the country. Forests have been thinned, controlled burns have been ignited to reduce the threat of fire, and business and residential owners have been encouraged to make their properties fire smart.\n\nBut even that was not enough to save Jasper from the heartbreak its residents are going through. Jasper's aggressive response came too late to take the necessary actions to make the national park more resilient to fire. Perhaps, most critically, a century of fire suppression has left behind too many aging trees and not enough space for more resilient stands to be regenerated.\n\nThe scenes in Jasper are devastating but also depressingly predictable given the trajectory we've been heading towards since 2003 when Parks Canada was overwhelmed by fires burning in Kootenay, Jasper and Banff and other parts of the country -- and when more than 45,000 people were evacuated from the Okanagan.\n\nWaterton Lakes Park in Alberta dodged a bullet for nearly a century before the exceptionally intense Kenow fire ripped through it in 2017. Jasper got a scare in 2022 when the Chetamon Fire lit up the night sky. Is Banff next?\n\nAs Rob Walker, a former Parks Canada fire and vegetation specialist, noted in a Facebook post on July 25: \"Wildfire seasons will continue to worsen, and our political leadership must find a way to stop the madness of our addiction to oil and gas.\" It was Walker who told me the 2003 wildfire season was a harbinger of what we could expect in a rapidly warming world.\n\nRead more: COP28: Why we need to break our addiction to combustion\n\nLack of foresight\n\nAlberta no longer has a wildfire rappel team that can get to fires that are inaccessible to ground crews. Its fire science co-ordinator has long departed, and its wildfire budget is heavily weighted in favour of suppression over wildfire science. That has been left to the University of Alberta to do, even though its budget has been cut by more than 20 per cent.\n\nIn 2024, The Government of Canada invested close to $800 million in initiatives to improve wildfire management, including helping provinces and territories purchase additional firefighting equipment and training 1,000 firefighters across the country.\n\nIts investment in wildfire science pales in comparison.\n\nThere was a glimmer of hope in June when the Canadian Council of Forest Ministers met in Cranbrook, B.C. and ended their meeting with a promise to follow through on a national wildfire prevention and mitigation strategy. This time may be different, but we have heard this kind of promise many times before.\n\nMore dark days may be coming unless we develop a culture, and political policies, that respect fire, drawing upon the wealth of valuable insights in Indigenous fire stewardship practices.\n\nRead more: How Indigenous burning practices can help curb the biodiversity crisis\n\nFire has no ideology or preferences; it will always be quite simply a chemical reaction, a propulsive oxidation of hydrocarbons shaped by terrain, weather, climate and the combustible material around it. We must learn to live with fire, and find ways of containing it for fire will never learn to live with us.", "source": {"uri": "theconversation.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Conversation"}, official | RCI", "body": "The wildfire, whipped into a firestorm by intense winds, burned with such intensity and speed, it sent plumes of ash and flames shooting hundreds of feet into the air.\n\nJames Eastham, a Parks Canada wildfire information officer, said firefighters were faced with a wall of flame that proved impossible to contain.\n\nFire behaviour was intense, Eastham said in an interview Wednesday night after the flames entered the townsite.\n\nFire crews were witnessing 300 to 400 foot flames in a fully-involved, continuous crown fire and a fire spread rate of approximately 15 meters per minute.\n\nThe extent of the damage is unknown but park officials say numerous buildings in the historic townsite in the heart of Jasper National Park have been lost.\n\nImages and videos shared overnight on social media showed multiple buildings, including homes and businesses, consumed.\n\nPark officials have reported significant loss in Jasper but have not detailed the damages to specific buildings or neighbourhoods.\n\nCrews were fighting to save as many buildings as possible, officials said.\n\nCritical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, the hospital, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline were among the buildings under threat.\n\nThe fight has been a battle waged on numerous fronts.\n\nJasper was under threat from the north and south, and mandatory evacuation orders were issued Monday as the fires flared, forcing as many as 25,000 residents and visitors out.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday but continued to draw closer to the town. The southern fire had been reported eight kilometres out from town but within a matter of hours, it had reached the outskirts of the community.\n\nThe situation only grew worse as the hours passed.\n\nWATCH | Firefighters in Jasper facing wall of flames:\n\nBucketing efforts by helicopters failed. Crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed.\n\nWATCH | Jasper wildfire 'our community's worst nightmare,' mayor says:\n\nFirst responders were eventually forced out of town.\n\nOnly structural firefighters equipped with personal respirators remained.\n\nThe fire made a significant push driven by winds and very receptive fuels, Eastham said. The fire came into town very quickly.\n\nWeeks of relentless heat made for tinder box conditions in the forest, a volatile mix of extremely dry fuels that fed the flames toward the community, he said.\n\nWhen the flames reached the townsite, it was an impossible battle, even with hundreds of people and machines on the ground and in the sky working to safeguard the community, he said.\n\nWe got as many resources as we were able to here as fast as we could to respond to this fire, he said.", "source": {"uri": "ici.radio-canada.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Radio Canada"}, "authors": {"uri": "8243647890", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:18:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:18:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:17:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/in-photos-tragic-scenes-from-jasper-unfold-as-wildfire-leaves-trail-of-destruction/article_dfe268a2-4ab0-11ef-8a1b-5fcab634c280.html", "title": "In photos: Tragic scenes from Jasper unfold as wildfire leaves trail of destruction", "body": "The fire reached Jasper on Wednesday evening and has begun ravaging the town, with a third of it destroyed.\n\nA wildfire is engulfing Jasper, Alta. in flames and burning parts of the town to the ground.\n\nPhotos and videos from the scene show large plumes of yellow and white smoke rising near the town and Premier Danielle Smith said as much as a third of the town may have been destroyed.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nOthers show blocks of the town burned to the ground, with only skeletons of houses and cars left.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nJasper mayor Richard Ireland published an open letter to residents, saying the wildfire has \"ravaged our beloved community.\"\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community,\" Ireland wrote. \"In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nJasper -- along with about 20,000 other nearby residents -- was evacuated Monday night as two wildfires closed in and cut off road access to the east and south.\n\nEvacuees have gone elsewhere in Alberta after they were directed away from British Columbia.\n\nB.C. is dealing with its own fires and does not have the capacity to take additional evacuees.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nJasper National Park said in a statement that is \"impossible to share information about specific locations and the extent of damage at this time.\" There have been no reported injuries.\n\nWith files from The Canadian Press", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8243816769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:42:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:42:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:41:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.cjwwradio.com/2024/07/25/200369/", "title": "Fire not out yet in Town of Jasper", "body": "As of late afternoon Thursday, Parks Canada stated in a social media update that fire crews are still fighting fires within the Town of Jasper and continue to deal with fire jumping from one building to another.\n\nParks Canada understands that people are anxious to hear more information about the extent of the impacts to the town, but first conditions need to be safe enough for a detailed assessment to be done. Incident Command confirms that all critical infrastructure in Jasper was successfully protected including the hospital, emergency services building, the schools, the activity centre and the wastewater treatment plant.\n\nHowever, some homes and businesses have been lost. The most significant damage is on the west side of town, southwest of Miette Avenue. The fire also damaged a number of bridges around the town and throughout Jasper National Park, including the Moberly Bridge and the Old Fort Point Bridge.\n\nWith the rain and cooler temperatures, the post from Jasper National Park/Parks Canada says fire activity is significantly subdued. \"However, it is important to note that the fire is still out of control and significant work remains before conditions are safe enough to allow for limited re-entry into the park.\"", "source": {"uri": "cjwwradio.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Country 600 CJWW"}, "authors": [{"uri": "carol_thomson@cjwwradio.com", "name": "Carol Thomson", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parks_Canada", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Parks Canada"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Town", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Town"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jasper_National_Park", "type": "https://media-cdn.socastsrm.com/wordpress/wp-content/blogs.dir/1785/files/2024/07/jasper-fire-national-park-1024x512.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9760758", "eventUri": {"uri": "8243825637", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "23:56:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T23:56:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T23:53:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/2024-jasper-fire-grim-reminder-234603691.html", "title": "The 2024 Jasper Fire is a grim reminder of the urgency of adopting a Canadian national wildfire strategy", "body": "In what is becoming an unfortunately common occurrence, the town of Jasper, Alta. has been ravaged by a wildfire of unprecedented scale. Crews report witnessing \"300- to 400-foot flames,\" while up to 50 per cent of Jasper's buildings may be damaged. Luckily, there have been no reported fatalities so far.\n\nIf a fire can burn the town of Jasper in a national park that has the resources to deal with fire, what does the future hold for hundreds of small boreal forest towns across the country that do not have the means, know-how or resolve to accept that fire will come someday?\n\nJasper is the latest in a growing number of communities affected by wildfires. Twenty thousand people living in Yellowknife were evacuated from their homes for more than three weeks in 2023. The B.C. town of Lytton is still rebuilding after it burned in 2021.\n\nIndigenous people, who represent five per cent of the population, are disproportionately affected by wildfires, as First Nations communities comprise 42 per cent of evacuations. Residents of Fort Good Hope, a community that is mainly Indigenous in the Northwest Territories, were recently displaced from their homes for three weeks due to a wildfire.\n\nJasper reinforces just how much we need a national wildfire strategy to bring together all levels of governance within the business and Indigenous communities to map out a blueprint for how to better predict, prevent, mitigate and manage fires, and how to provide small boreal communities with the resources they need to make them more resilient.\n\nIn the summer of 2010, Parks Canada fire manager Dave Smith conducted aerial and ground surveys of three main valleys in Jasper National Park and found that 400 trees had been attacked by the mountain pine beetle.\n\nUntil then, Jasper had been one of the few regions on the east slopes of the Rockies that had not been seriously affected by this slow-moving catastrophe. This beetle species has destroyed pristine views, shuttered lumber mills, increased the threat of forest fires while dead needles are still in the trees and reshaped British Columbia's economy.\n\nIn 2011, I joined Smith on an aerial and ground survey to see how the infestation was progressing. So many trees in Jasper had been reddened by the pine beetle that Smith decided there was no use counting again; he would have to find some other way of monitoring the situation.\n\nRead more: How to protect your home from wildfires - here's what fire prevention experts say is most important\n\nBefore he retired, Smith told me that, although he loved his job, he had trouble sleeping at night on hot summer days. He worried about a wind-driven wildfire sweeping through the highly combustible needles still clinging to all those dead trees and the living stands of 80-year-old spruce and pine that were at risk of burning. It wasn't just the aging forest and dead needles that worried him; it was the intense heat, extended droughts and lightning that were intensifying in a rapidly warming world.\n\nParks Canada fire specialists like Smith have done a lot to prevent fire from coming into Jasper, Banff and other park towns across the country. Forests have been thinned, controlled burns have been ignited to reduce the threat of fire, and business and residential owners have been encouraged to make their properties fire smart.\n\nBut even that was not enough to save Jasper from the heartbreak its residents are going through. Jasper's aggressive response came too late to take the necessary actions to make the national park more resilient to fire. Perhaps, most critically, a century of fire suppression has left behind too many aging trees and not enough space for more resilient stands to be regenerated.\n\nThe scenes in Jasper are devastating but also depressingly predictable given the trajectory we've been heading towards since 2003 when Parks Canada was overwhelmed by fires burning in Kootenay, Jasper and Banff and other parts of the country -- and when more than 45,000 people were evacuated from the Okanagan.\n\nWaterton Lakes Park in Alberta dodged a bullet for nearly a century before the exceptionally intense Kenow fire ripped through it in 2017. Jasper got a scare in 2022 when the Chetamon Fire lit up the night sky. Is Banff next?\n\nAs Rob Walker, a former Parks Canada fire and vegetation specialist, noted in a Facebook post on July 25: \"Wildfire seasons will continue to worsen, and our political leadership must find a way to stop the madness of our addiction to oil and gas.\" It was Walker who told me the 2003 wildfire season was a harbinger of what we could expect in a rapidly warming world.\n\nRead more: COP28: Why we need to break our addiction to combustion\n\nAlberta no longer has a wildfire rappel team that can get to fires that are inaccessible to ground crews. Its fire science co-ordinator has long departed, and its wildfire budget is heavily weighted in favour of suppression over wildfire science. That has been left to the University of Alberta to do, even though its budget has been cut by more than 20 per cent.\n\nIn 2024, The Government of Canada invested close to $800 million in initiatives to improve wildfire management, including helping provinces and territories purchase additional firefighting equipment and training 1,000 firefighters across the country.\n\nIts investment in wildfire science pales in comparison.\n\nThere was a glimmer of hope in June when the Canadian Council of Forest Ministers met in Cranbrook, B.C. and ended their meeting with a promise to follow through on a national wildfire prevention and mitigation strategy. This time may be different, but we have heard this kind of promise many times before.\n\nMore dark days may be coming unless we develop a culture, and political policies, that respect fire, drawing upon the wealth of valuable insights in Indigenous fire stewardship practices.\n\nRead more: How Indigenous burning practices can help curb the biodiversity crisis\n\nFire has no ideology or preferences; it will always be quite simply a chemical reaction, a propulsive oxidation of hydrocarbons shaped by terrain, weather, climate and the combustible material around it. We must learn to live with fire, and find ways of containing it for fire will never learn to live with us.\n\nThis article is republished from The Conversation, a nonprofit, independent news organisation bringing you facts and trustworthy analysis to help you make sense of our complex world. It was written by: Edward Struzik, Queen's University, Ontario\n\nRead more:", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243654424", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:25:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:25:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:24:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/3030459-wildfire-devastates-jasper-community-faces-unprecedented-loss", "title": "Wildfire Devastates Jasper: Community Faces Unprecedented Loss | Science-Environment", "body": "A catastrophic wildfire has ravaged Jasper, a prominent tourist town in western Canada, possibly destroying up to 50% of its structures. Evacuations began as firefighters struggled to control the flames. The fire has caused significant structural damage, prompting a large-scale emergency response, including international firefighter support.\n\nA towering wildfire has wreaked havoc in Jasper, a renowned tourist destination in western Canada, potentially demolishing up to half of the town's buildings. Firefighters are racing against time to salvage what they can, authorities reported. Jasper is nestled in the mountainous Jasper National Park, Alberta -- a site drawing over 2 million annual visitors.\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith, visibly emotional, described the situation as the community's worst nightmare. 'We are witnessing between 30% to 50% structural damage, making for a significant rebuild,' she stated, adding the fire remains uncontrollable.\n\nA reported 'significant loss' of buildings has occurred, though Parks Canada cannot confirm specific damages at this stage. Evacuation orders remain, as video footage reveals burnt vehicles and entire blocks, including historical sites like an Anglican church, reduced to rubble.\n\nResident Eva Korduliakova, currently abroad in the Czech Republic, discovered her house had burned. 'I am a single mom who became homeless and jobless overnight,' she shared.\n\nMayor Richard Ireland described the wildfires as having ravaged the tight-knit community, adding the destruction defies description. Critical infrastructure, such as the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, remains unharmed. However, CN Rail suspended operations as conditions worsened.\n\nApproximately 400 international firefighters are due to arrive, complementing local and federal emergency crews. Garlanded with 176 active wildfires in Alberta alone, the region faces a dire forecast, fueled by high temperatures and dry conditions. The Jasper fire, ignited by a lightning strike, escalated rapidly due to strong winds and lack of moisture, pushing the flames at alarming speeds.\n\nDespite potential rainfall relief, the Jasper fire stands as potentially the most devastating since the 2016 Fort McMurray blaze, which forced mass evacuations and destroyed substantial portions of the oil town.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", {"uri": "8243507716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "18:02:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T18:02:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T18:02:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/alberta/alberta-premier-fights-back-tears-promises-help-as-jasper-devastated-by-fire/article_cfdf019d-3ee8-55f4-b593-d2404a0a982e.html", "title": "Alberta premier fights back tears, promises help as Jasper devastated by fire", "body": "JASPER, ALTA. - Alberta Premier Danielle Smith fought back tears Thursday as she sought to console Jasper residents coming to terms with a community devastated by wildfire.\n\n\"The feelings of loss and fear and loneliness must be overwhelming,\" Smith said at a fire update in Edmonton.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nSpecifics on what has been destroyed in the Rocky Mountain resort town of 5,000 remained sketchy.\n\nJasper Park officials, in a statement, said the firefighting situation remains dynamic.\n\n\"Due to the ongoing fire conditions and our focus on the response effort, it is impossible to share information about specific locations and the extent of damage at this time,\" said the statement.\n\n\"The accuracy of this information is critical because it has a direct impact on members of the community. We will share more information as soon as we are able to ensure its accuracy.\"\n\nPhotos shared on social media Wednesday night depicted Jasper structures wrapped in sheets of flame.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nA video Thursday morning showed rain-slicked streets, cloudy skies and a wide swath of blackened, charred homes and buildings razed to their foundations.\n\n\"The images we're seeing out of Jasper are devastating,\" said Forestry Minister Todd Loewen.\n\nThe province has asked for help from the Canadian Armed Forces, and the federal government has said aid is on the way.\n\nCalgary, along with fire crews from Edmonton and Sherwood Park, said they were sending resources to the fire scene.\n\nThe staging area was the town of Hinton, on the eastern outskirts of Jasper National Park.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nIn Hinton Thursday morning, rain fell and wood smoke hung in the air at the roadblock preventing vehicles from entering the park. Five officials in bright neon yellow vests directed traffic. The only vehicle that was seen going through was a fire truck.\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, in an open letter to residents, urged them to stay strong.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community,\" Ireland wrote.\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nAbout 25,000 people, including about 5,000 residents in the Jasper townsite, were forced to flee west at a moment's notice late Monday night as twin wildfires from the south and north roared up and cut off access to the east and south.\n\nA day later they were directed to loop back to Alberta as British Columbia, dealing with its own fires, did not have the capacity to assist.\n\nOn Wednesday, efforts to contain the fires -- include buckets and fire guards and a last-ditch effort to burn a path from the southern fire to the river and highway -- were foiled by raging, gusting winds.\n\nAround 6 p.m. Wednesday, the fire roared in and began torching structures.\n\nJasper, a postcard-perfect mountain town, is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking. It is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears. The United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984.\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.", I don't think anyone will be returning to Jasper any time soon and life is not going to be anywhere near what it was - it really is the end of an era,\" she told the Canadian Broadcasting Corp.\n\nThe Alberta government is due to brief media at 11 am local time (1700 GMT).\n\nEnvironment Canada is forecasting 10 mm (0.4 inches) to 20 mm of rain for Thursday, which might help firefighters.\n\nThere are currently 175 wildfires burning in Alberta, more than 50 of which are out of control. Around 10 of those blazes are close to the border with British Columbia, where dozens of fires are also out of control.\n\nThe federal government said in April that high temperatures and tinder dry forests meant this could be one of the worst years ever for fires in Canada.\n\nThe Jasper Park Lodge, one of the largest hotels in town, said the fire had reached its grounds. The 400-room residence is run by Fairmont, a group owned by France's Accor.\n\nThe federal government and other cities in Alberta are sending emergency crews. One major concern for responders is if the fire reaches the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, which can carry 890,000 barrels per day (bpd) of oil from Edmonton to Vancouver.\n\n\"Losing structures, community, is like losing a close friend ... (but) the people have been saved and that is significant. We can find a way to rebuild,\" Jasper mayor Richard Ireland told the CBC.\n\nThe Jasper fire could be one of the most damaging in Alberta since a 2016 conflagration that hit the oil center of Fort McMurray, forcing the evacuation of all 90,000 residents. The blaze destroyed 10% of all structures in the city and shut in more than a million barrels per day of oil output.\n\nFort McMurray is forecast to receive up to 65 mm of rain in the next day, according to Environment Canada.\n\n(Reporting by David Ljunggren: Editing by Angus MacSwan; Editing by Aurora Ellis)", "source": {"uri": "theprint.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "ThePrint"}, {"uri": "8242065368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:13:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:13:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:12:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/calgary/jasper-wildfire-evacuees-arrive-calgary-1.7274362", "title": "Jasper evacuees arrive in Calgary, relieved but unsure about resort town's future | CBC News", "body": "After a long, winding journey out of Jasper and through a series of small B.C. communities, dozens of evacuees arrived in Calgary on Wednesday, relieved to be away from the wildfire danger but unsure about the resort town's future.\n\nTim Strozen was camping in the area with his wife and two daughters when he noticed that people in the townsite were filling up their cars with gas.\n\n\"That was our indication that maybe we should just pack up and leave,\" Strozen said. \"And we're so glad we did because then everyone was rushed getting out.\"\n\nAfter the order to leave Jasper was issued, thousands of vehicles were gridlocked on roads leading to safety. Many were forced west into British Columbia, then later redirected east toward Alberta.\n\nStrozen said he feels \"horrible\" for people who were stuck in the massive, early morning exit out of Jasper.\n\n\"And then seeing the pictures with the fires coming closer, that would be a horrible situation to be in, for sure.\"\n\nOther evacuees like Maryn Longley, a Jasper resident, described her experience as a \"wild ride\" that began with seeing a red sky and \"ash falling from the sky as I was walking home from work.\"\n\nLongley was caught up in the gridlock and said it took her \"two or three hours just to get out of town.\"\n\n\"I just wanted to get out of there,\" Longley said. \"I'm very antsy when it comes to traffic jams and stuff like that.\"\n\nAs Longley spoke to CBC News, she was waiting to be picked up by her dad and sister, who would take her to Edmonton.\n\nLongley said she's now taking things \"day-by-day\" and trying not to \"stress about anything too much.\"\n\nIn a media statement, the City of Calgary said that as of 9 a.m. on Wednesday, 108 evacuees had registered in the city, almost evenly split between Jasper residents and tourists.\n\n\"We are able to help people find shelter and additional supports they may need as the firefight continues,\" the statement read. \"Currently, there have been no further requests for support.\"\n\nAs of Wednesday, the two wildfires burning north and south of Jasper have moved within five kilometres and eight kilometres of the townsite.\n\nParks Canada incident commander Katie Ellsworth told reporters Wednesday morning the \"aggressive\" fire behaviour was expected to continue.\n\nLongley said she's \"not entirely sure what the future holds,\" adding that the situation is \"kind of in God's hands.\"\n\nWarren Waxer, who has lived in Jasper for 44 years, was in southern B.C. visiting friends when the evacuation order came through. He said his son packed up their belongings and made his way out of the tourist town.\n\nAs for Jasper's future, Waxer said he's \"hopeful but a little bit nervous because you just can't imagine rebuilding a town like Jasper.\"\n\n\"There's so much tourist infrastructure in and around the town that [the fire] doesn't necessarily have to hit the town to have a pretty major impact on the tourist industry,\" Waxer said.\n\nHowever, Waxer added that residents have been preparing for an evacuation like this after a series of harsh fire seasons.\n\n\"It was on everyone's mind since Fort McMurray [and] Edson last year,\" Waxer said, noting that residents had attended a wildfire preparation session as recently as two weeks ago.\n\n\"We did know [the session] was important, it's just we didn't think it would happen so quickly or to us,\" Waxer said.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8242384461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "05:10:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T05:10:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T05:09:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.nationalobserver.com/2024/07/24/news/buildings-burn-jasper-wildfire-overtakes-town", "title": "Buildings burn in Jasper as wildfire overtakes town", "body": "The southern fire had been reported eight kilometres distant from the town, but Katie Ellsworth, with Parks Canada, said strong wind gusts swooping in behind it sent it racing.\n\nEverything that could go wrong earlier Wednesday did go wrong.\n\nFire perimeters changed minute by minute.\n\nEllsworth said bucketing efforts by helicopter failed.\n\nCrews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed due to \"unfavourable conditions.\"\n\nThe hope was that up to 20 mm of rain, forecast to begin falling in the area later Wednesday night, would bring some relief.\n\nAlberta Forestry Minister Todd Loewen has asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\n\"We are requesting firefighting resources, aerial support to move wildfire crews and equipment and more,\" Loewen wrote on the social media platform X.\n\nThe 25,000 fled at a moment's notice two nights earlier.\n\nThe order to go went out around 10 p.m. Monday as fires cut off road access to the Jasper townsite from the east and the south, forcing evacuees to drive west into British Columbia in a long, slow midnight cavalcade through swirling smoke, soot and ash.\n\nThe following day, evacuees in B.C. who didn't have a place to stay were directed to make a long, looping U-turn around the fires back to Alberta to evacuation centres in Grande Prairie and Calgary.\n\nB.C., dealing with its own multiple wildfires and evacuees, did not have the capacity to help Alberta, officials said.\n\nAt the Grande Prairie evacuation centre, Addison McNeill recalled literally just arriving in Jasper when she was told to get out.\n\nMcNeill said she had just put her bags down after moving from Edmonton for her new job as a line cook when she got an alert on her phone that she needed to leave immediately.\n\n\"I moved there two hours before the evacuation notice,\" said the 24-year-old in an interview.\n\nMcNeill said went to a nearby hotel, one of two meet-up points for those without transportation. She hopped in a recreational vehicle with others and headed out -- at a snail's pace.\n\n\"Every single person in town was beelining to one exit from about six different routes and so you get bottleneck, backups and congestion,\" she said.\n\nMcNeill said as she sat inside the vehicle, she felt so close to the wildfires that the windows seemed like they were going to shatter from the pressure of the red, hot, smoky air.\n\nShe saw acts of kindness amid the swirling ash: neighbours loaning their cars to those without; people knocking on doors to see if everyone inside was OK.\n\n\"It was far from a panic,\" she said.\n\nJasper National Park, the largest in the Canadian Rockies, is considered a national and international treasure.\n\nThe United Nations designated the parks that make up the Canadian Rockies, including Jasper, a World Heritage Site in 1984 for its striking mountain landscape.\n\nIt has hosted glitz and glitter. In 1953, Hollywood star Marilyn Monroe visited to make the movie \"River of No Return.\" More recently, the TV show \"The Bachelor\" was filmed there.\n\nJasper is famous for hiking, skiing, kayaking and biking.\n\nIt is also home to dozens of species such as elk, mountain goats, cougars, lynx, black bears and grizzly bears.", "source": {"uri": "nationalobserver.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8241883946", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:05:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:05:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:04:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.esquire.com/news-politics/politics/a61689217/climate-crisis-canada-fire/", "title": "Spare A Thought For Canada, Which Is On Fire (Again)", "body": "Thousands of people have been evacuated from around Jasper, Alberta.\n\nHere is a handy map of Canada, the western half of which is, at the moment, burning down. There have been nearly 4,000 separate wildfires raging in the country this year and there are nearly 1,000 going at the moment. Two million acres have been lost to fires this year. The area around Jasper, Alberta, which includes one of Canada's most popular national parks, had to be hurriedly evacuated when a wildfire in the vicinity suddenly jumped up in intensity. From the CBC:\n\nParks Canada staff say aggressive fire behaviour prompted the decision to have thousands of people flee the Jasper area late Monday night. Parks Canada said at a media briefing Tuesday evening that the evacuation of the remaining hikers in the backcountry is still ongoing, but thousands of people have safely evacuated the park and the town. Up to 25,000 residents and visitors were evacuated since the order was made Monday night, as two fires raged south and north of Jasper, reaching within 12 kilometres of the townsite. By Tuesday afternoon, the wildfire south of the town had burned a minimum of 6,750 hectares, Parks Canada said, and the north wildfire, located between the Jasper Transfer Station and the Jasper Air Strip on both sides of Highway 16, had burned at least 270 hectares. When asked how the fire was able to come so close to the townsite before the alert was sent, incident commander Katie Ellsworth recounted a rapidly evolving situation leading up to the evacuation order. \"The situation unfolded very, very quickly,\" Ellsworth said, noting it was only a two-hour time frame from the start of the fires to when they were estimated to be of significant size.\n\nMuch of the evacuation had to be taken at night, which must have been a joy. Those clever Chinese climate hoaxsters are really on the job this year.\n\nRecently, the Pew Research Center published a report that found that there was a direct correlation between Americans who believe that the climate crisis and Americans who were immediately touched by its effects. This seems like it should be an obvious development but, hey, many of these people keep voting for people whose policies make the crisis worse, or who deny the existence of the crisis at all.\n\nSupport for regulating construction, but not for bans or mandates. Most Americans (73%) want stricter building standards in areas vulnerable to extreme weather. But more aggressive steps, like requiring people to move out of these areas, are unpopular (just 13% approve).Reports of extreme weather are common, though they vary by party. About seven-in-ten Americans say that in the past year, they've experienced at least one of five types of weather we asked about: severe weather, like floods or intense storms; unusually hot weather; droughts; wildfires; or rising sea levels. Democrats are more likely to report these experiences than Republicans, across each type of extreme weather, though the size of these differences vary by type.\n\nClimate change seen as a factor. Among those who say they've experienced any of these extreme weather events, a large majority say climate change contributed at least a little. Most Republicans - and nearly all Democrats - say climate change played a role. Hardships caused by extreme weather are wide-ranging. Those who say they suffered negative impacts of extreme weather events describe a host of challenges, in their own words. These include property damage, elevated utility and insurance bills, disruptions to daily life, and anxiety.\n\nAs the above evidence shows, this was a perfect time in history for the Supreme Court to defang the various regulatory agencies by eliminating the so-called \"Chevron deference.\" In Montana, the extraction industries already have heard the dinner bell ringing. From the Montana Free Press:\n\nTalen advised the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit that justices could no longer defer to EPA's judgment on new emissions standards affecting Colstrip. \"Courts must exercise their independent judgment in deciding whether an agency has acted within its statutory authority\" and \"may not defer to an agency interpretation of the law simply because a statute is ambiguous,\" Talen said in its advisory to the court.At issue are new pollution standards requiring tighter control of mercury and air toxics and, for the first time, carbon dioxide emissions. In corporate filings Talen and power plant shareholder NorthWestern Energy indicate the new rules, formalized in May, could render Colstrip uneconomical.\n\nRight now, today, the wildfires in western Canada are wreaking havoc with the air quality in Missoula and Butte and all over Montana, so why not let a corporation toss some mercury and excess CO2 into the mix as well? It was proudly owned and operated by our family since 1961,\" she wrote. \"We are so devastated and we are also so sad for all the other business owners, operators, residents and wonderful people who call Jasper home.\"\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith said she was \"heartbroken\" that the flames had reached the town but was thankful all residents and visitors were successfully evacuated earlier in the week.\n\nThe plan to erect fireguards was also thwarted by the approaching flames forcing heavy equipment operators \"to be pulled off the fireline for safety,\" they said.\n\n\"An ignition specialist also arrived, with the goal to complete landscape-level ignition in order to bring the fire to large holding features such as Highway 16 and Athabasca River,\" they wrote. \"Unfortunately, unfavourable conditions prevented this.\"\n\nTen to 20 millimetres of rain is forecasted to hit Jasper beginning overnight, the statement said.\n\n\"If the area receives rain it will help to reduce fire activity.\"\n\nJasper is home to 4,700 residents and hosts tens of thousands of visitors from around the globe each year as the townsite for one of Canada's most famous national parks.\n\nThe {"uri": "8243478164", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "17:36:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T17:36:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T17:35:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/alberta/article-mayor-of-jasper-says-wildfire-destruction-beyond-description-and/", "title": "Mayor of Jasper says wildfire destruction 'beyond description and comprehension'", "body": "The mayor of Alberta's beloved mountain town of Jasper said wildfires that laid siege to the community Wednesday evening have caused destruction and loss that is \"beyond description and comprehension.\"\n\nMayor Richard Ireland, in a message posted to social media, said the small town must come together as it reels from the devastation of wildfires that are still burning out of control in the area that have rolled through the townsite and Jasper National Park. He said the incident management team and fire responders are working valiantly to protect the town but that people's safety is the first priority.\n\n\"I write to you today with profound sorrow as we begin to come to terms with the devastating impact of last night's wildfire that has ravaged our beloved community. The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension; my deepest sympathies go out to each of you,\" said Mr. Ireland on Thursday.\n\n\"Your resilience and strength have always been the backbone of our community. In the coming days and weeks, we will rally together, support one another, and begin the daunting process of recovery.\"\n\nHe said the local government is working closely with other levels of government, volunteers and other organizations to co-ordinate relief efforts and provide essential information and resources to those that have been affected.\n\nParks Canada, in an update on Thursday, said approximately 25,000 people were safely evacuated from the Town of Jasper and the national park and no injuries have been reported.\n\nThe agency said this emergency \"evolved rapidly\" with the wildfire hitting the town about 48 hours after it was first reported.\n\nJasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight. While the rain helped reduce fire activity slightly, it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control,\" said the update.\n\nFirefighting reinforcements arrived throughout the night, said Parks Canada, and are continuing to fight back the blazes and protect infrastructure.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures,\" said the agency.\n\nThe Canadian military is also on its way to help battle Alberta's raging wildfires, which are burning in every corner of the province, said federal Employment Minister Randy Boissonnault on X (formerly Twitter) Thursday morning. The army will help with evacuations, firefighting and airlift assistance, after the provincial government requested their help on Wednesday.\n\nFederal Emergency Preparedness Minister Harjit Sajjan also wrote on social media on Thursday that he is on his way to Edmonton to help co-ordinate efforts with \"various government agencies\" to respond to the rapidly-evolving wildfire situation.\n\n\"Our priority is the safety and well-being of the affected community members,\" said Mr. Sajjan.\n\nThe extent of the damage in Jasper is not yet known as dangerous conditions forced fire crews to retreat but videos and photos surfacing of the town show utter devastation with businesses, homes and vehicles burned to a crisp.\n\nThe owner of the Maligne Lodge, Karyn Decore, wrote on social media that the hotel was completely consumed by flames. Fairmont-owned Jasper Park Lodge also confirmed that the fire had reached the historic resort's ground on Wednesday night.\n\nAnnelies Lagger, who has owned and lived in the Austrian Haven B&B for over three decades, said she is patiently waiting to find out if her establishment was among the many that were burned to ashes Wednesday night. Ms. Lagger evacuated her lodge on Monday night with her 13 cats and a dog.\n\nNow, she said the only way to know the fate of her home and business is through photos circulating on Facebook groups. When she learned the Maligne Lodge had burned down, she said she lost the little hope she had remaining.\n\nShe has lived in Jasper for over 50 years, more than half of which she dedicated to building the bed and breakfast up.\n\n\"In these years, I have never been on holiday. Now, it's probably gone. All I could save were my cats and one dog,\" said Ms. Lagger, who added that she had no time to take any of her personal belongings when she fled. \"I'm 82 years old. I don't think I will survive much longer. My home was like my soul, my heart. It was everything.\"\n\nAs of Thursday morning, she said she is sheltering in Valemount at the home of a generous stranger who let her and her 14 pets in on Monday night after they were stranded on the roadside with nowhere else to go after having left their lives behind in Jasper.", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Globe and Mail"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8243042933", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:26:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:26:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:26:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/wildfire-that-roared-into-jasper-was-a-wall-of-fast-moving-flame-says-fire-official-1.7274825", "title": "Wildfire that roared into Jasper was a wall of fast-moving flame, says fire official | CBC News", "body": "One of two wildfires threatening the historic resort town raged into Jasper Wednesday, consuming homes and businesses in a wall of flame.\n\nThe wildfire, whipped into a firestorm by intense winds, burned with such intensity and speed, it sent plumes of ash and flames shooting hundreds of feet into the air.\n\nJames Eastham, a Parks Canada wildfire information officer, said firefighters were faced with a wall of flame that proved impossible to contain.\n\n\"Fire behaviour was intense,\" Eastham said in an interview Wednesday night after the flames entered the townsite.\n\n\"Fire crews were witnessing 300 to 400 foot flames in a fully-involved, continuous crown fire and a fire spread rate of approximately 15 meters per minute.\"\n\nThe extent of the damage is unknown but park officials say numerous buildings in the historic townsite in the heart of Jasper National Park have been lost.\n\nImages and videos shared overnight on social media showed multiple buildings, including homes and businesses, consumed.\n\nPark officials have reported \"significant loss\" in Jasper but have not detailed the damages to specific buildings or neighbourhoods.\n\nCrews were fighting to save as many buildings as possible, officials said.\n\nCritical infrastructure, including the wastewater treatment plant, the hospital, communications facilities, the Trans Mountain Pipeline were among the buildings under threat.\n\nThe fight has been a battle waged on numerous fronts.\n\nJasper was under threat from the north and south, and mandatory evacuation orders were issued Monday as the fires flared, forcing as many as 25,000 residents and visitors out.\n\nThe northern fire was spotted five kilometres from Jasper earlier Wednesday but continued to draw closer to the town. The southern fire had been reported eight kilometres out from town but within a matter of hours, it had reached the outskirts of the community.\n\nThe situation only grew worse as the hours passed.\n\nBucketing efforts by helicopters failed. Crews using heavy equipment to build fireguards couldn't complete the work before having to pull back for safety.\n\nWater bombers couldn't help due to dangerous flying conditions.\n\nA last-ditch effort to use controlled burns to reroute the fire to natural barriers like Highway 16 and the Athabasca River failed.\n\nFirst responders were eventually forced out of town.\n\nOnly structural firefighters equipped with personal respirators remained.\n\n\"The fire made a significant push driven by winds and very receptive fuels,\" Eastham said. \"The fire came into town very quickly.\"\n\nWeeks of relentless heat made for tinder box conditions in the forest, a volatile mix of extremely dry fuels that fed the flames toward the community, he said.\n\nWhen the flames reached the townsite, it was an impossible battle, even with hundreds of people and machines on the ground and in the sky working to safeguard the community, he said.\n\n\"We got as many resources as we were able to here as fast as we could to respond to this fire,\" he said.\n\n\"Unfortunately, given the conditions and given the fire behaviour today, there was nothing that those resources could do to prevent the spread of the fire into the town.\"", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wildfire", {"uri": "2024-07-433304436", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "12:47:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T12:47:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T12:35:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/sick-to-my-stomach-people-grieve-jasper-national-park-by-sharing-favourite-photos-1.6977049", "title": "'Sick to my stomach': People grieve Jasper National Park by sharing favourite photos", "body": "As an out-of-control wildfire roared through Alberta's famed Jasper National Park and its townsite late Wednesday, many are fearing the worst as officials warned of \"significant loss\" within the area.\n\n\"Our focus continues to be on saving as many structures as possible. Unfortunately, we can't report on the extent of damage to specific locations or neighbourhoods at this time,\" Parks Canada said in a statement. \"We are sensitive that residents, business owners, visitors, and those with connections to Jasper want to know the state of their homes, businesses, treasures and favourite places.\"\n\nWhile residents and visitors await to see the extent of the damage, many are already grieving Jasper National Park by sharing favourite images of the famed area.\n\n\"My favourite photos I took when I last visited Jasper. Hard to think about what we will wake up to,\" reads a post on X.\n\n\"One of my genuine favorite places in the world is burning and in a catastrophic state,\" reads another. \"My heart goes out to everyone who lives there, it's in shambles.\"\n\n\"Was through Jasper last year at this time. My thoughts with all evacuees and first responders,\" reads another post.\n\n\"Sick to my stomach seeing the tweets & photos from Jasper. One of my fav places on earth. Camped there last week. {"uri": "8242006339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:04:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:04:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:02:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/canada/jasper-fire-south-fire-now-at-10-800-hectares-voyent-alert-glitch-highway-16-partially/article_c1c563b4-2057-5b36-a0a8-a1e94a21a584.html", "title": "Jasper Fire: south fire now at 10,800 hectares, Voyent Alert! glitch, Highway 16 partially reopened", "body": "By Abigail Popple, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter The Rocky Mountain Goat\n\nThe south fire in Jasper National Park has grown over 4,000 hectares since yesterday evening, now totalling at least 10,800 hectares. It is roughly eight kilometres away from the Town of Jasper, according to Incident Commander Katie Ellsworth.\n\nThe north fire, which is about five kilometres away from town, is still about 270 hectares.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nRain is forecasted for this evening and into Thursday morning. Ellsworth says commanders anticipate a reduction in fire activity if Jasper does receive precipitation, but gusty conditions mean the fire will likely grow before then.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nEllsworth confirmed to media that the town has not been impacted by fire.\n\nThe status of structures outside of town - such as the Palisades Centre, Caribou Recovery Centre, and the HI Athabasca Falls Wilderness Hostel - is unknown at this time. Heavy smoke and aggressive fire behavior have made it unsafe for responders to access these structures, according to Ellsworth.\n\n\"In terms of the Palisades Centre, we can confirm that it has been impacted. Because of the fire behavior yesterday, we don't know the extent of those impacts,\" Ellsworth said. \"We are hoping to be able to confirm those impacts as soon as we can, so that we can share that information both to the public and the business owners. But we do ask for your continued patience.\"\n\nFirefighters are taking steps to protect the town's infrastructure in case the southern fire continues to move northward. This includes the installation of high-volume sprinklers on the south side of the Parks Canada compound, and around the southwest perimeter of town from Patricia Place to the entrance of Stone Mountain Village. Sprinklers will also be installed around Pyramid Bench from west to east. Additionally, firefighters are removing combustible material and dry vegetation from town today, Ellsworth added.\n\nEllsworth asks that the public look to Parks Canada, the Municipality of Jasper, and Alberta Wildfire for accurate information on the fire, rather than using other resources like NASA's MODIS and FIRMS satellite imagery.\n\n\"At this time due to heavy, thick smoke conditions in Jasper, we cannot confirm the MODIS or FIRMS hits that you can see if you're looking at the satellite imagery,\" she said. \"These satellites do indicate heat registers, and it's not uncommon after a fairly aggressive burning day when things calm down for that heat to sink back down to the surface and be registered as a fire point.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nVoyent Alert! glitch\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland, who also attended the press conference, thanked Jasper residents and visitors for their cooperation during the evacuation. However, he said he received reports this morning that the Voyent Alert! system used by the municipality did not work as intended.\n\n\"We gave out an emergency alert on our system - we use something called Voyent,\" he told journalists. \"It has come to my attention that some subscribers to that service did not receive the messages that we thought that they had received.\"\n\nIreland added that the Alberta Emergency Alerts system worked as expected.\n\nThe Voyent Alert! glitch has been fixed since the municipality learned of it earlier this morning, according to Ireland.\n\n\"All of these incidents undergo an after-action debrief. The whole system will be reviewed and we will see whether any corrections have to be made to prevent this happening, either in our location or other locations with the same sorts of mass alert systems,\" he said.\n\nHighway 16 partially cleared\n\nAccording to Drive BC, about 350 kilometres of Highway 16 has been cleared between Victoria Street and the B.C.-Alberta border, as of 11:01 a.m. today. There is still limited visibility due to smoke from 16 kilometres east of Tete Jaune to the Alberta border.\n\nHighway 16 eastbound is closed from the Mount Robson Visitor Centre to the Alberta border. The westbound lane is open only for evacuation purposes. Drive BC anticipates an update to Highway 16 at 4:30 p.m. today.", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243761224", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:26:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:26:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:25:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5529412031173706, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/emotional-alberta-premier-says-a-third-to-half-of-jasper-structures-destroyed-by-wildfire-5693823", "title": "Emotional Alberta Premier Says a Third to Half of Jasper Structures Destroyed by Wildfire", "body": "Between 30 and 50 percent of the buildings in Jasper have been destroyed by a wildfire that hit the town overnight, according to Alberta's premier.\n\nPremier Danielle Smith gave an emotional update to the media on July 25.\n\n\"We don't know particularly which structures have been damaged and which ones have been destroyed, but it's going to be significant rebuild, and significant displacement for a long period of time.\"\n\nClearly upset by the damage in Jasper, Ms. Smith said the park was a jewel for the province.\n\n\"We share the sense of loss with all of those who live in the town, who care for it, and who have helped build it. Jasper, we will continue to stand by you as everyone works to get their feet back under them.\"\n\nAt one point in the conference, a staffer handed the premier a box of tissues as she was visibly crying.\n\nMs. Smith described the overnight situation as \"extremely volatile\" and said the province would support those who are displaced.\n\n\"Alberta's government will provide the support needed to families and community to recover and to rebuild stronger than ever so that future generations can continue to experience this one-of-a-kind community and to feel the magic of being able to come home.\"\n\nPierre Martel, director of the National Fire Management program at Parks Canada, said that structural firefighters were still on site trying to save what they could.\n\nParks Canada said it needs to accurately assess what has been damaged before it can provide details on lost structures. The agency adds that crews are continuing to try to subdue the wildfire.\n\n\"Jasper National Park received a small amount of rain overnight,\" Parks Canada said in a statement.\n\n\"While the rain helped reduce fire activity slightly, it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nThe wildfire reached town limits around 6 p.m. local time on July 24.\n\n\"Right now the wildfire is still out of control and crews are working in dangerous conditions to try and protect critical infrastructure in the town,\" she said.\n\nThe province has been getting fire crews and help from 32 municipalities from across the province, and has also asked the Canadian Armed Forces for help.\n\nAs well, Australia, Mexico, and South Africa {"uri": "8241957969", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:11:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:11:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:10:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/jasper-s-wildfire-preparedness-work-put-to-the-test-as-out-of-control-fires-threaten-townsite-1.7273212", "title": "Jasper's wildfire preparedness work put to the test as out-of-control fires threaten townsite | CBC News", "body": "For years, Parks Canada and the Municipality of Jasper have removed trees and branches, logged a firebreak, ignited controlled burns and asked residents to clear yard debris in hopes of protecting the forest-nestled town from a dangerous blaze.\n\nThose mitigations may now be put to the test as out-of-control wildfires bear down on the Jasper townsite, according to wildfire experts.\n\nThousands of people were forced to flee the Jasper townsite and national park Monday night, as the threat of wildfire grew rapidly.\n\n\"A big part of these treatments is not necessarily to stop the fire cold in its tracks, but to slow the fire and keep the fire on the surface rather than spreading fire in the canopy,\" said Jen Beverly, a University of Alberta associate professor of agricultural, life and environmental science who studies wildfires.\n\nFlames high up in the trees, rather than at ground level, are more difficult for firefighters to extinguish and will spew sparks and embers that inevitably land on buildings and set them ablaze, she said.\n\nParks Canada's website says it uses strategies like prescribed burns and the maintenance of a fireguard west of the townsite to protect properties and important sites in Jasper National Park.\n\nThe federal agency and the municipality have been working to thin the forest around the town since 2003, and have removed more than 10 square kilometres of forest, it says.\n\nIn 2018 and 2019, they also hired Canfor to carefully cut down trees on a slope west of town to create a protective firebreak.\n\nMathieu Bourbonnais, a University of British Columbia-Okanagan assistant professor who is part of the university's Centre for Wildfire Coexistence, said these prevention strategies likely won't halt an encroaching wildfire, but can change its behaviour to make it easier for firefighters to battle.\n\n\"It might drop out of the [tree] crowns, it might just become a surface fire, or it might actually just run out of energy and stop,\" he said.\n\nBourbonnais, who was also a rappel team firefighter in Alberta and has worked for Parks Canada, says the federal agency is one of the most proactive authorities in the country at setting prescribed burns and trying to restore what used to be more frequent cycles of fire in the forest.\n\nWildfire ecologist and private consultant Robert Gray says historic photographs show Jasper National Park wasn't always densely covered with conifer trees. Indigenous people who previously lived on the land ignited some fires, and, governments and agencies didn't use to extinguish forest fires.\n\nThese smaller, more frequent fires would run out of fuel more quickly, he said.\n\n\"And now we have this just large buffet out there, which is just what fire needs,\" he said.\n\nComplicating the situation is the mountain pine beetle, which has ravaged parts of the park in the last two decades. The experts interviewed for this story said it leaves behind a heterogeneous network of dried debris that is sometimes extremely flammable, and at other stages, is at lower risk of igniting.\n\nClimate change and increased spells of hot, dry weather are no help, Gray said.\n\nThe Chilliwack, B.C.-based consultant said the number of prescribed burns happening in western Canada and the funding for such programs is inadequate to combat the volume of forest that's ready to burn.\n\n\"Right now it's stop, start, stop, start,\" he said. \"There's funding there one year, not the next. You can't retain people because there's no steady employment. It's a recipe for disaster.\"\n\nPrograms like FireSmart, which encourage property owners to build with less flammable materials, among other measures, have had limited success because these changes are expensive for citizens, Gray said.\n\nCBC News has requested an interview with FireSmart Alberta.\n\nBeverly says she's done research showing the Jasper townsite is particularly vulnerable to wildfire because it is located at the confluence of three mountain valleys, which fire would naturally migrate along.\n\nAnd no preventative burn or tree removal will allow the forest to withstand the power of a strong wind or an intense hot, dry spell, Beverly said.\n\n\"When it's really extreme, you can't expect these treatments to fulfil their goal,\" she said.\n\nSo far this wildfire season, about 540,000 hectares has burned in Alberta. In 2023, considered the worst wildfire season on record, about 2.2 million of hectares burned.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": Jasper is burned to the ground,\" Ryan Jespersen wrote.\n\nThe video, taken from inside a truck, shows a view of a community forever changed.\n\nWhere buildings once stood, charred rubble remains. Many homes in the historic townsite have been destroyed, leaving only the foundations.\n\nThe video shows vehicles blackened by fire lining the streets. Scorched trees stand like matchsticks. Flashing vehicle lights flare red over the low chatter of an emergency radio.\n\nThe truck pauses briefly in front of one of the burned homes and a man's voice can be heard saying, \"That's Mom and Dad's house.\"\n\nCBC has verified that the video shows Geikie Street and Larch Avenue.\n\n\"We have all seen on the news and social media that horrific pictures and videos coming out of Jasper, homes and businesses have been lost to a wildfire that people are calling a 'wall' of flames,\" Smith said, according to The Guardian.\n\n\"There is no denying that this is the worst nightmare for any community,\" she added.\n\nEarlier in the day, Jasper's mayor, Richard Ireland, told residents in a video message that the scope of damage had left him and others with \"profound sorrow\".\n\n\"The destruction and loss that many of you are facing and feeling is beyond description and comprehension; my deepest sympathies go out to each of you,\" he said.\n\nJustin Trudeau said on Thursday that his government had approved Alberta province's request for federal assistance, adding that it was deploying military resources and evacuation support, as well as coordinating firefighting and airlift assistance.\n\n\"As the heartbreaking images from Jasper emerge, I want to thank the brave first responders who are in Alberta right now, fighting to save every home and every community they can. Thank you for your courage, and for working non-stop to fight these wildfires,\" Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau said.\n\n\"And, to reinforce their efforts, over 400 firefighters from our friends in Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, and South Africa are on their way to fight wildfires in Alberta, shoulder-to-shoulder with our Canadian teams,\" he added.\n\n\"Just convened an Incident Response Group meeting on the Alberta wildfires. {"uri": "8243706268", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:20:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:20:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:20:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/science-environment/3030476-raging-wildfire-devastates-jasper-massive-destruction-feared-in-tourist-town", "title": "Raging Wildfire Devastates Jasper: Massive Destruction Feared in Tourist Town | Science-Environment", "body": "A devastating wildfire has engulfed the western Canadian tourist town of Jasper, threatening to demolish up to 50% of local structures, officials reported on Thursday. Firefighters are engaged in an intense battle to save as many buildings as possible.\n\nJasper, situated within the mountainous region of Jasper National Park in Alberta, faced a full-scale evacuation on Monday. Authorities estimated that approximately 10,000 people were in town, with an additional 15,000 visitors within the park. Alberta Premier Danielle Smith described the situation as the community's 'worst nightmare,' citing potential structural damage of 30% to 50% and labeling the situation as a significant rebuild challenge.\n\nParks Canada acknowledged 'significant loss' in the town, though specifics were pending, and videos showed extensive destruction, including the total loss of a historic Anglican church. The wildfire, ignited by a lightning strike and fueled by strong winds, remains unchecked, with flames reaching heights of 100 meters and spreading rapidly. Concerns persist over the potential impact on the Trans Mountain oil pipeline, although it continues to operate safely. Federal, provincial, and international assistance is being deployed to combat one of Alberta's most catastrophic wildfires since the 2016 Fort McMurray blaze.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", It reached the outskirts Wednesday evening, but now structures in the community, including the Maligne Lodge, are aflame.\n\nParks Canada has started relocating first responders to Hinton, Alta. But some firefighting personnel, aircraft and \"a small number\" of incident command staff are still in Jasper, trying to protect the town about 365 kilometres west of Edmonton. A cavalcade of RCMP vehicles drove out of the community Wednesday evening.\n\n\"If you have not yet evacuated town, you must leave now,\" said a joint news release from Parks Canada and the Municipality of Jasper.\n\nMeanwhile, the Alberta government is seeking help from the military to help combat wildfires burning throughout Alberta.\n\nPublic Safety and Emergency Services Minister Late in the day, the inferno advanced quickly and spread into the town of Jasper. Early pictures show extensive damage in what is one of the country's most beloved travel destinations.\n\n\"The wildfire situation in Jasper is dynamic and fluid. As conditions worsened yesterday afternoon, CN suspended rail operations in coordination with the Unified Command Centre,\" railway spokesperson Ashley Michnowski said in a statement.\n\nThe town of Jasper and the national park in which it is situated were ordered evacuated on Tuesday, forcing as many as 25,000 residents and tourists to flee. The municipality of Jasper and Parks Canada are responding to the incident jointly as a unified command centre.\n\nMs. Michnowski said it is coordinating with the centre and other parties that are responding to the fire, and is monitoring weather and fire patterns closely.\n\nVIA Rail, the Crown-owned passenger service that operates on the CN mainline through Jasper, said it has stopped operating through that corridor as well. {"uri": "8243692655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:05:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:05:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:05:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.mapleridgenews.com/news/17-bc-wildfire-fighters-join-battle-to-protect-jasper-as-blaze-burns-on-7457573", "title": "17 B.C. wildfire fighters join battle to protect Jasper as blaze burns on", "body": "Alberta premier estimates 30-50% of Jasper damaged or destroyed as of Thursday morning\n\nThe BC Wildfire Service sent 17 firefighting crew members and four fire engines to Jasper late Wednesday night (July 24) as wildfires entered the alpine town and began devouring structures.\n\nThe fire, which forced the evacuation of 25,000 residents and tourists on Monday, scorched its way into the mountain community around 6 p.m. Wednesday after wind gusts caused a sudden surge in activity. Hundreds of firefighters worked to battle the blaze through the night, but Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said Thursday that 30 to 50 per cent of the town's structures may be burned.\n\n\"We don't know which structures have been damaged and which ones are destroyed, but that's going to be a significant rebuild and significant displacement,\" she said.\n\nREAD ALSO: Alberta premier fights back tears as wildfire devastates iconic Jasper\n\nSeveral officials estimated the flames were about 100 metres tall when they entered Jasper.\n\n\"It's just a monster at that point. There are no tools we have in our tool box to deal with that at that point. You get out of the way, you retreat,\" Pierre Martel, director of fire management at Parks Canada, said. He added that no injuries have been reported so far.\n\nFirefighters continue to battle the wildfire Thursday and are working to save what remains of the popular tourist town. The Canadian Armed Forces have also been called into assist.\n\nThe BC Wildfire Service says the engines and crew members it sent were what it could spare while ensuring it still has enough resources to fight the more than 400 blazes burning in B.C.\n\nJasper evacuees were detoured through B.C. on Monday and Tuesday as they fled the town and made their way back to reception centres in Alberta. B.C. communities along the border did their best to support the influx of thousands of people, with some campgrounds providing sites free of charge and some residents opening up their homes.\n\nPremier David Eby noted earlier in the week that Alberta has supported B.C. in its wildfire fight on numerous occasions, and that B.C. was going to do its best to return the favour.\n\nDealing with its own evacuation orders though, the province was unable to support the Albertan evacuees for long.\n\nAs of Thursday morning, an estimated 1,400 British Columbians are under evacuation order and another 6,000 are under alert, according to the Ministry of Emergency Management and Climate Readiness.\n\nThere are 423 wildfires burning in the province, five of which are considered wildfires of note, meaning they are especially visible or pose a threat to the public. Two of those - the Shetland Creek Wildfire south of Ashcroft and Dogtooth Wildfire south of Golden - are believed to have destroyed some structures.\n\nREAD ALSO: New evacuation orders issued even as cooler weather aids B.C. wildfire fight\n\n-With files from The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "mapleridgenews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Maple Ridge News"}, "authors": [], "concepts":
