{"uri": "8243580254", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:10:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:10:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:10:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10643691/jasper-wildfire-rebuilding-challenges/", "title": "Jasper wildfire: Why rebuilding Alberta town may be 'logistical nightmare'  | Globalnews.ca", "body": "As a raging wildfire devastates the Alberta town of Jasper, there are growing concerns about the immediate toll on the community and the \"logistical nightmare\" of recovery that lies ahead.\n\nWhile the extent of the structural damage remains unclear, multiple buildings have been impacted, according to Parks Canada.\n\nIt's a familiar sight for Halifax Mayor Mike Savage, who said he understands how challenging it can be for a community to leave their homes with little notice.\n\n\"When you hear something like this, regardless of your experience, you start to think about the human toll,\" Savage said in an interview with Global News on Thursday.\n\n\"Obviously the built infrastructure to lose is amazingly awful, but the impact that it has on humans is even more dramatic.\"\n\nLast May, a historic wildfire that broke out in the Halifax-area community of Upper Tantallon upended the lives of thousands of people.\n\nThat fire burned 969 hectares, destroyed 151 homes and forced more than 16,000 residents to flee the area.\n\nMore than one year later, people in Halifax and other parts of Nova Scotia who were impacted by the blazes are still recovering and rebuilding.\n\n\"We went through that here in Halifax last year, and I know the toll that it takes,\" Savage said.\n\n\"It's a really tough circumstance and our hearts go out to the people in the (Jasper) community.\"\n\nFlames have entered the Jasper townsite and set at least two hotels on fire. While the town is home to 4,700 people, Jasper National Park draws thousands of visitors each year as it is one of Alberta's top tourist destinations.\n\nWarren Singh, executive director of the Alberta Construction Association, said it is too soon to fully understand the extent of the damage and just assessing those could take up to six months.\n\nPointing to the example of Alberta's Fort McMurray, which was swept by a ferocious 2016 wildfire, Warren said recovery for Jasper could also take five years or longer, depending on the damages.\n\nIn the aftermath of the wildfire, Singh said rebuilding communities like Jasper could be a \"logistical nightmare,\" involving sorting out what is needed in terms of cleanup, critical infrastructure damage and reckoning with the effects of blazes on the local environment.\n\nSpeaking from his own experience in Halifax, Savage said there is no set timeline for recovery from a wildfire as there are several challenges along the way and that rebuilding work only begins after the immediate danger is over.\n\nThings like finding emergency housing, feeding people and rescuing pets come before and that's where communities from across the country have to step in and come together to help, he said.\n\n\"I think the key is to come together and recognize that whether your house is there or gone, you're part of the solution and you work with your neighbours and make things better.\"\n\nNorthern Alberta town Slave Lake is among those offering assistance, with its fire chief and a crew en route to support, Mayor Francesca Ward told Global News.\n\nFor the people of Jasper, she said: \"We understand what you are going through, and our entire town's hearts are breaking with you.\"\n\nSlave Lake was in a similar situation in 2011, when a wildfire burned about one-third of the town.\n\n\"Patience is what is needed, and time to process,\" Ward said.\n\n\"To this day, when I smell smoke from wildfires and hear reports of fires in the vicinity, it causes that little hint of anxiety and memories to flood back of the wildfires. \"\n\nShe said the community's most immediate need will be financial resources and having access to immediate funding will aid in the recovery efforts in the weeks ahead.\n\nBecause Jasper, which is located in the Rocky Mountains, is a mountainous region, that presents its own unique set of challenges for rebuilding, such as access for services and having to cut through rock beds, Singh said.\n\nIn terms of environmental issues, wildfires also cause complex problems, such as vegetation loss, soil erosion, a decrease in water quality and a rise in the potential for flash flooding, he added.\n\nWard said the most significant challenge, other than locating builders and resources in more remote communities, would be communication.\n\n\"Evacuation, interim housing and rebuilding all require substantial moving parts, and communicating this to the relevant stakeholders is a huge hurdle.\"\n\nIn British Columbia, rebuilding efforts for fire-devastated Lytton have been slow.\n\nCement for Lytton's first home rebuild was finally poured in December 2023 - more than two years after a massive wildfire devastated the B.C. village.\n\nSingh said building permit processes can take time, while residents will be eager to move back quickly.\n\nSupply chain issues and safety concerns may also arise in the rebuild process, he said.\n\nFrom figuring out insurance to building to current standards to getting the workforce, there is a lot required to rebuild following a natural disaster, while also making sure the infrastructure can withstand future calamities, Savage said.\n\n\"The simple fact is, we can't just build back to the way it was with the changing climate,\" he said.\n\nAnd no matter how long it takes Jasper to rebuild, it's never really quite the same.\"", "source": {"uri": "globalnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "Global News"}, Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\n\"Despite the ongoing determined and courageous collective efforts of all the partners involved - including Parks Canada team members, the Town of Jasper, and Alberta Wildfire - it is with heavy hearts that we report this aggressive and fast-moving fire continues to burn in Jasper National Park,\" Martel said. \"Although we do not have specific details, we do know that multiple structures, including a number of businesses and homes in and around the Town of Jasper, have been lost.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nMartel later added that while he can't confirm the specific extent of the damage, it is significant.\n\nAt the time of the press conference, Martel did not have an update on the status of the wildfires raging outside of town. In a Facebook post earlier this morning, Jasper National Park wrote that the area received rain overnight, but \"it is not enough to have made a meaningful impact to the overall wildfire situation, which remains out of control.\"\n\nLast night, firefighters without self-contained breathing apparatuses were evacuated to Hinton. However, a number of structural firefighters remain in town to preserve what structures they can, according to Martel.\n\n\"We know many residents and business owners will be anxious to hear about the status of their own businesses,\" Martel added. \"We ask that people respect the area closure. We'll be able to provide further updates and more information as soon as conditions allow.\"\n\nJasper Mayor Richard Ireland echoed these comments.\n\n\"We simply need to have verifiable information,\" Ireland said. \"Until we can verify from people on the ground, our stance is that it would be irresponsible to try and confirm things based on unverified facts.\"\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"We are as anxious as anybody to get detailed, verified information so we can share it with other residents. But until we have that, we have nothing to share.\"\n\nWhile Alberta Premier Danielle Smith told journalists in an earlier press conference that there is structural damage in 30 to 50 per cent of the town, Parks Canada was unable to confirm these numbers, according to External Relations Manager Natalie Fay.\n\nChief of the Valemount and District Volunteer Fire Department, Rick Lalonde, messaged The Goat with his assessment of the situation.\n\nAccording to him, the fire boss in Jasper estimated 25 per cent of structures had been destroyed when volunteers from Valemount arrived last night. Since then, more structures have been destroyed due to strong winds carrying sparks.\n\n\"Today there are 60 fire trucks, 6 pieces of equipment, 160 firefighters mopping up structures and burning brush,\" Lalonde said.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nHowever, Parks Canada reminds people to take images and information from social media with a grain of salt. In response to a question from The Goat about whether Parks Canada is regulating the sharing of images and information from people on the ground, Fay said the organization is not attempting to stop the spread of images on social media. Instead, they hope people will consult official sources like the Parks Canada website or Jasper National Park Facebook page.\n\n\"Obviously, there are images circulating (social media). What we are doing to try to manage that is to provide as many updates with good, confirmed information as possible,\" she said. \"We are doing our best to get information out of the incident, but right now we are still dealing with a very volatile situation and we have to focus on that. We are working on getting confirmed information, and we will put information out as soon as possible.\"", "source": {"uri": "thepeterboroughexaminer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8242859030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "10:33:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T10:33:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T10:33:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://theglobalherald.com/news/major-wildfires-lead-to-evacuations-in-jasper-canada/", "title": "Major Wildfires Lead to Evacuations in Jasper, Canada - The Global Herald", "body": "Recent wildfires in Canada have prompted the evacuation of approximately 25,000 residents from the town of Jasper. This situation escalated significantly on Tuesday as flames engulfed buildings, affecting the local community and the natural environment.\n\nAs reported by officials, the wildfires have caused substantial damage within Jasper National Park, leading to what has been described as \"significant loss\" within the town's vicinity. The fires are part of a broader series of wildfires affecting parts of western Canada, specifically Alberta and British Columbia.\n\nIn the past week, the region has experienced over 58,000 lightning strikes, which have contributed to the ignition of new fires following a prolonged heat wave lasting three weeks. The BC Wildfire Service highlighted the connection between the extreme weather and the rise in fire incidents.\n\nAn extensive firefighting operation is currently underway, with around 1,900 firefighters from Alberta deployed to tackle the flames. In addition to local efforts, teams from Alaska and Australia have also been brought in to assist in preserving critical infrastructure from the advancing fires.\n\nAmong the structures under threat is the Trans Mountain Pipeline, which runs through Jasper National Park. While the pipeline continues to operate safely as of Wednesday, precautions, including the use of sprinklers, are being implemented to mitigate any potential risks.\n\nBritish Columbia and Alberta have individually reported over 400 and 176 active fires, respectively. The initial fires around Jasper were identified last week, with the town's mayor describing the unfolding events as their \"worst nightmare.\"\n\nDue to the smoke and fire activity, air quality in the area has sharply declined, impacting residents and visitors of the park, which is known as the largest in the Canadian Rockies.\n\nFollowing the evacuation orders, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith has urged residents to evacuate in safety. She mentioned being in \"constant contact\" with emergency authorities to coordinate the response. Additionally, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has affirmed that federal assistance is being mobilized to support Alberta's firefighting efforts.\n\n\"We're deploying @CanadianForces resources, evacuations support, and more emergency wildfire resources to the province immediately -- and we're coordinating firefighting and airlift assistance,\" stated Mr. Trudeau.\n\nThis particular crisis in Canada is part of a larger trend of wildfires affecting the United States and Canada. {"uri": "8243773430", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:44:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:44:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:44:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5098039507865906, "url": "https://www.thebeaverton.com/2024/07/danielle-smith-the-loss-of-jasper-is-tragic-but-we-can-all-take-comfort-in-how-much-money-the-oil-industry-is-still-making/", "title": "Danielle Smith: The loss of Jasper is tragic, but we can all take comfort in how much money the oil industry is still making", "body": "EDMONTON - Premier Danielle Smith fought back tears today as she announced that at least 30-50% of the town of Jasper, Alberta has been severely damaged by wildfires but she was adamant that all is not lost, because the Alberta oil industry is still going strong.\n\n\"This event has been utterly devastating for the residents of Jasper,\" Smith said today in a news conference. \"All any of us can do in the face of such horrifying destruction is hold tight to what really matters. And the only thing that matters in this province is the ability of fossil fuel producers to continue to do their work mostly unhindered by the effects of the extreme weather that has become increasingly common during this century for some reason.\"\n\nWhile the vast majority of scientific experts agree that there is an unequivocal connection between global warming caused by the burning of hydrocarbons and the increase in wildfires that have turned summers in Canada into deadly, smokey infernos, Premier Smith has made it clear that she is not interested in playing the blame game about these fires, unless she can blame Trudeau.\n\n\"While I don't want to point fingers during this ongoing tragedy, this is all very likely Trudeau's fault,\" Smith continued. \"Not because of his own support of the oil industry and its wonderful pipeline,\" Smith hastily added, \"but for not taking better care of Jasper National Park, a federal responsibility.\"\n\n\"The UCP has spent most of the last five years cutting Alberta's wildfire preparedness budget, and Trudeau's government should've known that this kind of fire was going to grow out of control in this province because of our cuts and should've been better prepared for it.\"\n\n\"Finally, I want to assure the folks in Jasper that we will rebuild,\" Smith said. \"I don't care how long it takes. And I mean that literally, rebuilding Jasper will likely take a very long time and I sincerely doubt I or anyone else in my government will sincerely care about this a year from now, or five, or ten. Though I will always be available to cut a ribbon or two on camera once it's all done.\"\n\nSmith concluded her remarks by saying a special thank you to the firefighters working to keep the Trans {"uri": "2024-07-433759353", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:12:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:12:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:52:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/hundreds-of-jasper-wildfire-evacuees-arrive-in-edmonton-1.6977852", "title": "Hundreds of Jasper wildfire evacuees arrive in Edmonton", "body": "Hundreds of evacuees have arrived in Edmonton from Jasper since the town was evacuated, with more expected in the coming days.\n\nAround 25,000 residents and visitors were forced to flee Jasper National Park and its historic townsite on Monday night due to two nearby wildfires.\n\nOn Thursday afternoon, 436 evacuees had registered at the emergency reception centre in Edmonton.\n\n\"This is an emotional time for everyone, and especially for those who are seeing the updates of their homes through social media: Their business is being destroyed, their homes being destroyed and their livelihood being destroyed,\" said Mayor Amarjeet Sohi.\n\n\"The gravity of these fires are being felt by everyone. I want the people of Jasper to know that Edmontonians are here for you.\"\n\nFire burns in a residential neighbourhood in Jasper, Alta. on July 24, 2024. (Credit: Mel Dressler)Interim city manager Eddie Robar said more evacuees are expected to arrive over the next few days. However, he doesn't believe the city will see \"thousands and thousands\" of people, because many evacuees were forced to flee south or west as routes were cut off.\n\nAn evacuation support terminal is available for wildfire evacuees at the Kennedale Building at 12814 58 St. in Edmonton.\n\nThe Red Cross is on site to help with lodging. Other services include food and water, pet care, clothing and toiletries.\n\nMedical and mental health services will be available, and Robar said multiple insurance agencies are on site as well.\n\n\"Knowing what we know now, people are going to be impacted quite substantially,\" Robar said. \"Having these insurance agencies here is going to help them navigate that as quickly as they can, in one spot, and get them through this facility and then out into what's next in the journey for them.\"\n\nPhotos posted July 25, 2024 show destruction in Jasper after wildfire ravaged the town. (Source: CFWE)Edmonton acting fire chief David Lazenby said dozens of local firefighters and support staff left on Wednesday night to help with structural firefighting efforts in Jasper.\n\n\"They got there in the earlier hours of this morning, and they got to work straight away,\" Lazenby said. \"They've been working and running on adrenaline ever since.\n\n\"I think they're just approaching the rest period now, and then we'll transition in the next crews that are en route as we speak.\"\n\nLazenby said the fire is a difficult one to fight. Not only is it aggressive, but it's in an area dear to many Albertans.\n\n\"It's hitting hard,\" Lazenby said. \"So many people have got memories there from life growing up as a child.\"\n\nFor more {"uri": "8242715716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "09:08:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T09:08:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T09:06:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4901960790157318, "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-our-whole-life-its-gone-jasper-wildfire-evacuees-find-refuge-in-bc/", "title": "'Our whole life  --  it's gone': Jasper wildfire evacuees find refuge in B.C. town amid shock and grief", "body": "Around 5:30 p.m. Wednesday, the mood suddenly shifted at the Three Ranges Brewery in Valemount, B.C., a town a safe distance from the ferocious wildfire that swept into Jasper.\n\nSeveral dozen Jasper evacuees who had fled their tiny Alberta town overnight Monday had congregated at the outdoor pub. They had been waiting to find out when they could go home.\n\nSuddenly, word began trickling in that the firefighters guarding their homes had pulled out -- it was too dangerous to keep fighting the fire threatening the picturesque mountain community.\n\nFifteen minutes later, someone shouted: \"The Petro Canada just blew up.\"\n\nA photo of Jasper's Wicked Cup Caf\u00e9 in flames started circulating.\n\nA group of four grabbed one another in a hug.\n\n\"There's not going to be a lot left of Jasper by tomorrow,\" said Jeff Morris, through tears.\n\nMr. Morris was working as a guide at Sun Dog Tours on Monday night, when his boss phoned to tell him he had to get out because the entire town was under evacuation order. Mr. Morris drove quickly to the office, jumped into a tour bus and headed for the local senior's home, loading everyone inside for the frightening, late night drive to Valemount.\n\nThe tiny B.C. town of Valemount is like a sister community to Jasper, Nicole Dryden explained. \"It's where Jasper folks go to settle down when they finally grow up,\" added Jasper bartender, Hannah Basso.\n\nValemount is small enough that each of the 11 graduating students from Valemount Secondary has their photo displayed on a lamp post on Fifth Avenue, the town's main drag. That kind of community spirit has also embraced the evacuees.\n\n'Significant loss' in Jasper as wildfires close in, burning buildings and forcing fire crews to retreat\n\nAround 11:45 p.m. on Monday, Ms. Dryden and her husband learned people from Jasper were headed their way. Within hours they had taken in a group of eight Ukrainian refugees. Their Ukrainian guests are in shock: \"They keep saying: Two months ago, we evacuated our country. Where do we go now?\"\n\n\"They've never even been outside Jasper until now,\" she added.\n\nSeveral evacuees are sleeping at the Legion, the community hall, and a local church. The Valemount Pines Golf and R.V. Park is letting evacuees camp out on their grounds.\n\n\"I've never met nicer people -- ever,\" said Jasperite Eric Daniels. He and his wife Katie Potter manage a Bearcat Pizza in Jasper.\n\n\"When the fire started, it was 30 kilometres from town. Two hours later, the whole town was ordered to evacuate. I've never seen a fire move that quick.\"\n\n\"Our whole life -- it's gone.\"\n\nMs. Basso broke down in tears after learning the lodge abutting her apartment was in flames.\n\n\"I don't even have shoes,\" she said. \"We left with the clothes on our backs. The last thing we took was our marriage certificate. Unfortunately, I forgot my Permanent Resident documents. That's going to be quite a problem,\" she added..\n\nThe former lawyer from Australia and her Canadian-born husband are camping at a friend's house in Valemount.\n\n\"I feel numb and devastated,\" she said, adding a recent heat wave and continuing drought had left her and many others in Jasper with a sense of dread that the town was a tinder box.\n\n\"We're used to fires back home. But this one moved faster than any fire I've ever seen.\"\n\nValemount resident Swanny Pleister is also anxious. She took in 15 Jasper evacuees -- mostly friends and family -- at her farm outside Valemount. But conditions in the area, too, are threatened by wildfire.\n\n\"The problem is, we have two more fires threatening our home,\" she explained..\n\nShe and her husband spent the night before their evacuees arrived installing a sprinkler system on their roof. It's dampening their home day and night.\n\n\"One more storm, one more stupid incident, and it's, 'here we go, we're all going to have to leave Valemount.'\"", "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", It's devastating times,\" he said.\n\nTocher added that he hopes the free meals will help ease the blow, as it is important for the community to rally together and be there for one another.\n\n\"These poor people are devastated, and who knows what their financial situation was like? We'll survive it. {"uri": "8243689413", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "21:03:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T21:03:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T21:02:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.thepeterboroughexaminer.com/news/canada/there-was-no-notice-hundreds-of-jasper-evacuees-stopped-in-valemount-monday-night/article_8f163c1e-8492-5f28-a867-efc9e50191a2.html", "title": "\"There was no notice\": Hundreds of Jasper evacuees stopped in Valemount Monday night", "body": "By Abigail Popple, Local Journalism Initiative Reporter The Rocky Mountain Goat\n\nHundreds of evacuees from the Town of Jasper and Jasper National Park wound up in Valemount late Monday night and early Tuesday morning after the area was ordered to evacuate at 10 p.m. MT (9 p.m. PDT), just 90 minutes after the Municipality of Jasper issued an evacuation alert.\n\nEvacuees went west on Highway 16, and eventually crowded into Valemount's Community Hall, where a welcome centre with water and public washrooms had been established.\n\n\u00d7\n\nAlready a Subscriber? Sign in You are logged in Switch accounts\n\nJasper residents Dorothy and David Marquis told The Goat it was the first time they'd been evacuated after living in the town for 40 years.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\n\"This was just crazy. There was no notice,\" Dorothy said. \"There was a notice that there was a severe thunderstorm in Jasper, that's all we heard. And then next thing we knew, we were under alert, and then we were out. If you weren't ready to go, you just left.\"\n\nDorothy said she was only prepared to evacuate because a neighbour who worked for the Municipality of Jasper advised her to pack her car before the evacuation alert was issued. She was particularly frustrated because her husband, David, has mobility issues and would have struggled to leave on shorter notice.\n\nThis was the second evacuation that Hunter Chateau, a summer student working at Jasper National Park, has been through. Last year, she had to evacuate her hometown of Grande Prairie, Alberta - this time around, she felt more prepared.\n\n\"This one was much more organized. There was actually time, and people actually put in the effort to notify residents,\" Chateau said. \"From experience with that last one, and having family and friends go through it, I was already packing two days before the evacuation.\"\n\nNot everyone was as prepared as Chateau. Teresa and Douglas Wright, who were visiting Jasper National Park from California, were unable to return to their trailer in time to collect their things.\n\nARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW ARTICLE CONTINUES BELOW\n\nThe Wrights had just driven into the Town of Jasper after spending the afternoon driving through the park when they got the evacuation alert. It caught them off-guard, Teresa said.\n\n\"Earlier I had called the visitors centre, and I said, 'How do we know if there's a fire? It's getting awfully smoky over here.' She said it was smoke coming from Washington, there was one small little fire but they had it under control.\"\n\nOnce they got notice of the evacuation order, the Wrights tried to return to their trailer in Wapiti Campground, but were told they couldn't drive back into the park. Someone who was managing traffic control at the park advised them to head west.\n\nWord about Valemount's welcome centre spread through Facebook and the hospitality industry in a hectic game of telephone. Chateau had friends who sent her Facebook posts about the village's community hall, while the Wrights were instructed to go to the community hall when they tried to book a hotel in town.\n\n\"I'm feeling much better now that I'm not in a car following the convoy. I understand that's what everybody had to do, but it's nice to be out,\" Chateau said. \"I'm just praying for everybody to make it out safe, and wishing the firefighters all the best.\"", "source": {"uri": "8243582804", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:13:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:13:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:13:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/Canada/498648/-Need-to-stay-strong-Jasper-evacuees-anxious-as-they-await-word-on-wildfire-damage", "title": "'Need to stay strong': Jasper evacuees anxious as they await word on wildfire damage - Canada News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Alice Varshavska is shown in Calgary on Thursday July 25, 2024. Varshavska was forced to flee Jasper and has registered at an evacuation cente in Calgary. Two years ago she fled the war in Ukraine to find a safer life in Canada. THE CANADIAN PRESS/Bill Graveland\n\nAlice Varshavska didn't expect this to happen again.\n\nTwo years ago, she fled war-torn Ukraine seeking a better life. She found it in Jasper, Alta.\n\nBut the 26-year-old restaurant server was forced to flee the picturesque Rocky Mountain tourist town as wildfires encroached on Monday night. On Thursday, she found herself registering at an evacuation centre in Calgary.\n\n\"I'm still trying to have a good mood. We flew from Ukraine and cried out all of our tears and collected all those things and left everything behind and now like it's just happened again and you are like, 'OK, I need to stay strong,'\" Varshavska said.\n\n\"I need to keep going and figure things out. If God wants it like that, then maybe it makes us stronger.\"\n\nVarshavska, who said she may look for work in Calgary, said nobody initially suspected anything was wrong. Then she saw drivers lined up to buy gasoline.\n\n\"I come out of work and then I see the ashes falling down and like, 'What is going on?' And you look on the other side there is this huge smoke coming up.\"\n\nShe said she packed quickly, bringing only documents, her phone and her most important belongings. It took two days to get to Calgary and the possibility of going back to Jasper is fading.\n\n\"I just got the video from my friends and it's all burned ... Even the houses made of stone all burned,\" she said.\n\n\"We still had a hope, me and my friends, that maybe some of the things will still be there when we come back and it's just hard to realize that all of your memories are just gone.\"\n\nPreliminary reports indicate a third and perhaps up to half of the structures in the Jasper townsite have been destroyed, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said Thursday.\n\nAbout 25,000 people, including about 5,000 Jasper residents, were forced to flee west at a moment's notice late Monday night as twin wildfires from the south and north roared through, cutting off access to the east and south.\n\nRhett Fleming has worked at the golf course at the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge for the past five years. He said he was waiting for an update from resort management about the damage.\n\nFleming said the smoke came out of nowhere, followed by a strong wind that blew it through town.\n\n\"It was scary and I never experienced anything like that and wouldn't wish that upon anybody,\" Fleming said as he was entering the Calgary evacuation centre.\n\n\"A lot of people I know who have been in that community 40, 50, 60 years ... their lives are there. Their houses are gone. You can rebuild houses, you can rebuild businesses but it's people's lives.\"\n\nDonny Woodcox described getting a late-night call at the Maligne Lake work camp he's been staying at for the past three years.\n\n\"It's a shock. It still hasn't kicked in, I don't think,\" he said.\n\nWoodcox said he and other workers carpooled to Calgary and he is praying the fire doesn't spread any further.\n\n\"I'm going to stay for a week and see how it goes. Hopefully the fire goes out and we see where we go from there.\"", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8243641804", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:11:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:11:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:11:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "url": "https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/arts-and-life/life/sci-tech/2024/07/25/now-lost-jasper-fire-torching-cherished-memories-along-with-forests", "title": "\"Now lost\": Jasper fire torching cherished memories along with forests", "body": "I agree to the Terms and Conditions, Cookie and Privacy Policies, and CASL agreement.\n\nThe black clouds billowing from the fires razing Jasper National Park hold more than the reek of charred timber and scorched earth. For thousands of Canadians and mountain-lovers around the world, it's the smell of cherished memory going up in smoke.\n\n\"It's a huge amount of history and memories that are now lost,\" said Alexis Keinlen, an Edmonton writer who recalls the winter 2015 wedding of a friend.\n\nBefore the ceremony, the party gathered in the evening on the shores of Lake Agnes on the grounds of the Jasper Park Lodge, now at least partially burned. They clasped mugs of hot chocolate around roaring fires or laced up skates for a turn on the ice.\n\nThe dark of the lake and the clarity of the sky felt \"otherworldly,\" she said.\n\n\"You could see all the stars above. It felt really big.\n\n\"One of my friends gave her child the name Jasper.\"\n\nA decade ago, Kelley Ware was living in Prince George, B.C., and her now-husband was in Edmonton. Every few weeks, they'd meet in Jasper.\n\n\"It was completely fundamental to building our relationship. My husband has a tattoo of Pyramid Mountain.\"\n\nFor Janet Millar, the memories go back generations.\n\nHer great-grandfather was on a roadbuilding crew in Jasper in 1948 when he noticed that lots were going up for sale around Lake Edith. He and his wife walked around it, chose their favourite spot and the next year built the cabin that has been in the family ever since.\n\n\"It's the smell of an old log cabin that has had a lot of bacon and pancakes and syrup served in it. It's the sight of old furniture that no one can bear to part with,\" she said.\n\n\"Everyone in my family and all sorts of friends have their own particular thing they like best. There's so much I like about it that I can't bear to part with.\"\n\nSocial media was awash Thursday with memories of Jasper proposals, weddings and honeymoons. But the town is steeped in memory of all kinds.\n\nThere's the generations of skiiers who have partied in the Whistle Stop pub or Athabasca Hotel, known locally as the Atha-B and a fixture since 1929. The families who carbed up for the day's adventures at Smitty's. The holidayers from around the world who met and gabbed in hotel hot tubs.\n\nThe worshippers at the gracious Anglican church of St. Mary and St. George, who have gathered since 1928 to praise God in the midst of some of His finest handiwork.\n\nThe classic fieldstone headquarters of Parks Canada, across the street from where travellers on Via Rail's Rocky Mountaineer disembarked to gape at the vista. The cheeky Fiberglas statue of Jasper the Friendly Bear, rubbed shiny since the '60s by the hands of children.\n\nThe roadside greeter elk casually grazing, charming visitors turning off Hwy 16 into town.\n\nThe great and famous, too, are part of Jasper's memory.\n\nFilm star Marilyn Monroe, in town with co-star Robert Mitchum to film the 1954 western \"River of No Return,\" was famously escorted from the dining room of the Jasper Park Lodge for inappropriate dress. That same year saw the release of \"The Far Country,\" for which the Lodge hosted Jimmy Stewart.\n\nBing Crosby was by in 1946 to film \"The Emperor Waltz\" and returned regularly to golf on the Lodge's renowned course. Anthony Hopkins and John Travolta have vacationed there.\n\nRoyalty first came to visit in 1939 when King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, stayed at the Jasper Park Lodge's Outlook Cabin. Their daughter, Queen Elizabeth II, stayed there with her husband Prince Phillip in 2005.\n\nBut Jasper's memories are not primarily of glitz and bling. It's an everyone kind of place.\n\n\"Our family had a dock that was always painted yellow,\" said Millar.\n\n\"All of us remember jumping off that dock and watching people come out from town and using it. That was always really special. It was heartwarming for us to see people enjoying the dock.\"\n\nWare remembers the fellowship.\n\n\"Striking up conversations with people and having an hour-long chat. Making friends with the bartenders. And just really feeling like you belonged.\"\n\nThursday morning, Parks Canada reported the fire remained out of control despite a small amount of rain overnight. Firefighting reinforcements had arrived to defend the town.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, workplaces, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures,\" the agency said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate your patience and the community of people who have come together to support the people of Jasper and Parks Canada family.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.", "source": {"uri": "winnipegfreepress.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8243575884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "19:06:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T19:06:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T19:06:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4588235318660736, "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/national/2024/07/25/need-to-stay-strong-jasper-evacuees-anxious-as-they-await-word-on-wildfire-damage", "title": "'Need to stay strong': Jasper evacuees anxious as they await word on wildfire damage", "body": "CALGARY - Alice Varshavska didn't expect this to happen again.\n\nTwo years ago, she fled war-torn Ukraine seeking a better life. She found it in Jasper, Alta.\n\nBut the 26-year-old restaurant server was forced to flee the picturesque Rocky Mountain tourist town as wildfires encroached on Monday night. On Thursday, she found herself registering at an evacuation centre in Calgary.\n\n\"I'm still trying to have a good mood. We flew from Ukraine and cried out all of our tears and collected all those things and left everything behind and now like it's just happened again and you are like, 'OK, I need to stay strong,'\" Varshavska said.\n\n\"I need to keep going and figure things out. If God wants it like that, then maybe it makes us stronger.\"\n\nVarshavska, who said she may look for work in Calgary, said nobody initially suspected anything was wrong. Then she saw drivers lined up to buy gasoline.\n\n\"I come out of work and then I see the ashes falling down and like, 'What is going on?' And you look on the other side there is this huge smoke coming up.\"\n\nShe said she packed quickly, bringing only documents, her phone and her most important belongings. It took two days to get to Calgary and the possibility of going back to Jasper is fading.\n\n\"I just got the video from my friends and it's all burned ... Even the houses made of stone all burned,\" she said.\n\n\"We still had a hope, me and my friends, that maybe some of the things will still be there when we come back and it's just hard to realize that all of your memories are just gone.\"\n\nPreliminary reports indicate a third and perhaps up to half of the structures in the Jasper townsite have been destroyed, Alberta Premier Danielle Smith said Thursday.\n\nAbout 25,000 people, including about 5,000 Jasper residents, were forced to flee west at a moment's notice late Monday night as twin wildfires from the south and north roared through, cutting off access to the east and south.\n\nRhett Fleming has worked at the golf course at the Fairmont Jasper Park Lodge for the past five years. He said he was waiting for an update from resort management about the damage.\n\nFleming said the smoke came out of nowhere, followed by a strong wind that blew it through town.\n\n\"It was scary and I never experienced anything like that and wouldn't wish that upon anybody,\" Fleming said as he was entering the Calgary evacuation centre.\n\n\"A lot of people I know who have been in that community 40, 50, 60 years ... their lives are there. Their houses are gone. You can rebuild houses, you can rebuild businesses but it's people's lives.\"\n\nDonny Woodcox described getting a late-night call at the Maligne Lake work camp he's been staying at for the past three years.\n\n\"It's a shock. It still hasn't kicked in, I don't think,\" he said.\n\nWoodcox said he and other workers carpooled to Calgary and he is praying the fire doesn't spread any further.\n\n\"I'm going to stay for a week and see how it goes. Hopefully the fire goes out and we see where we go from there.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.", "source": {"uri": "brandonsun.com", "dataType": "news", "https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/1024/branded_news/7670/live/401aaba0-4a55-11ef-8f0f-0577398c3339.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9760758", "eventUri": "eng-9760758", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-07-433730851", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:28:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:28:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:02:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4470588266849518, "url": "https://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/jasper-mayor-says-community-preparedness-key-to-safe-evacuation-1.6977759", "title": "Jasper mayor says community preparedness key to safe evacuation", "body": "The mayor of Jasper, Richard Ireland, speaks with Alberta Primetime host Michael Higgins about the evacuation of his community caused by recent wildfires.\n\nMichael Higgins: As you understand it, what is the current threat to the community?\n\nRichard Ireland: Well, the most significant threat is a very large wildfire south of town that is still approaching the southern boundary of the town. Parks Canada are out there with assistance from other firefighters from the province and from other national parks across the country, and they're assisted with aerial support as well. But it is a very aggressive wildfire, really quite large, and still bearing down towards the town - so a significant threat for our entire community.\n\nMH: The aggressiveness of this fire is certainly a big point in this whole discussion. So if we dial back the clock, your thoughts on what it took to safely evacuate such a large number of people from your community, especially considering so many were tourists.\n\nRI: I think it speaks highly, both to all of the individuals who became the evacuees. People have been encouraged to take up incentives to be prepared over the last number of years, starting many years ago with other wildfires in Alberta. The sense, at least for residents, of 72-hour kits and having their documents already organized and ready to go: water and medications and all that stuff. We have really been aggressive with our messaging on that. And for our own residents, I think the uptake was stupendous. For visitors, I can only be somewhat incredulous at their ability to be so responsive, to hear the message and then to comply. The evacuation order came quite quickly on the heels of the evacuation alert. That, again, was just a testament to the really dynamic nature of this particular fire that caused the threat. People had hours to get out, approximately 25,000 people in total. Only one exit route from all of Jasper remained, because of fires north and south of the town, and all of those people safely evacuated beginning - unfortunately - at 10 o'clock in the evening and through the wee hours of Tuesday morning. But everybody got out safely with no significant incidents at all.\n\nMH: Now you're the mayor of a community within a national park, a national park that is within the province of Alberta. How challenging is it to navigate that dynamic in an emergency situation like this?\n\nRI: I suppose many looking from the outside would see that as a challenge, and in some respects it is, but it is our reality. And so we have worked closely with all of those agencies over a number of years and particularly with respect to emergency response and wildfire preparedness. We have held practice scenarios with all of the involved agencies, so that includes Alberta Emergency Management, Parks Canada and our own municipal team. And plans have been coordinated in advance how we're going to deal with this. We have gone into something called Unified Command. The fire is on the landscape, so Parks Canada, as having the expertise in wildland fire management on the landscape, take the lead on that, but we're all in at the same table. We had response from Alberta Emergency Management in our town in the early hours of Tuesday morning, and the level of cooperation and coordination is extremely high. So I can appreciate from an outside perspective you look at all these multiple jurisdictions all in one location and wonder how it will work. Well it works extremely well, because these people are professionals, they've trained for this, they're prepared for this, they know how to cooperate with each other and how to get the job done.\n\nMH: What about coordination with the tourism sector, their need to get all their guests, their own staff moving. How much of a partnership is there with the hospitality industry?\n\nRI: It is significant and critical to our needs. And so for the evacuation itself, we had hotels in the tourism industry become centres for the accumulation of people who needed to then get on buses to get out of town, who might not have had their own transportation. We have rafting companies and tour companies who have access to buses, and those buses were made available. Whatever residents and businesses within the community could do to assist appears to have been done. We had anecdotal evidence at least of residents helping each other and helping visitors. The degree of patience that was exhibited, the degree of preparedness, and responsiveness and just kindness to each other was quite staggering. And yes, the tourism industry steps up as they typically do to help us manage all the visitors that we rely upon through the rest of the year.\n\nMH: It was an Alberta Emergency Alert that prompted the evacuation Monday evening and then a follow up to clarify reference to a five-hour window. What played out in that regard?\n\nRI: I'm not entirely sure. I acknowledged that there was an error in some wording but it didn't impact negatively the evacuation at all. And so, although it may have caused a heightened degree of anxiety among some individuals thinking that the fire was perhaps closer than it actually was, at least in time, as soon as that error was recognized, it was corrected. That took about 50 minutes. But given the nature of the emergency, you can appreciate the first fire, north of town, was detected sometime after 7:00. Within half an hour, there was reports of a second fire south of town. Within another 10 minutes, another report of another fire south of town. And at the same time there was a forest fire already burning in the National Park which was being actioned by Parks Canada. So they were already spread quite thinly. This was a very dynamic, actively evolving situation. The timing between the emergency alert, the state of local emergency and the evacuation order was a really short timeframe. So yes, we acknowledge a mistake was made, but in the overall context it didn't cause damage. We still got everybody out safely.\n\nMH: A majority of evacuees had to head west. Thoughts for your municipal neighbors across the border who rallied around welcoming hundreds, if not thousands of people?\n\nRI: Valemount gets our credit for their response. I think I heard from the mayor in Valemount that they had about 16,000 unexpected visitors Monday night and Tuesday morning for the evacuees from Jasper. They responded as well as could ever be expected and beyond. So a very small community, smaller than Jasper, but they took up the challenge and served our guests and our residents extremely well and we thank them for that.", "source": {"uri": "edmonton.ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV Newsnet                        "}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_D._Higgins", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Michael D. Activate your Online Access Now\n\nThe fire, dubbed Utopia, was reported a week ago and is believed to have started from a lightning strike. As the fire spread out of control Monday, residents in Jasper and those visiting Jasper National Park were ordered to leave. High temperatures, dry conditions and lightning storms have been plaguing much of western North America this month causing numerous fires.\n\nJasper is at the heart of a huge national park that shares its name and at the northern end of the Icefields Parkway, a highway that connects the wilderness area to Banff National Park in the south. It is prime tourist spot and is known for its natural beauty in the Canadian Rocky Mountains.\n\nThe newly expanded Trans Mountain oil pipeline also passes through Jasper and the pipeline operator had deployed sprinkler protection at its station there as a preventative measure. Emails and voice mails left with Trans Mountain before office hours weren't immediately returned.\n\nFor several years now, major fires have burned large swaths of Western Canada, razing small towns, Of that third, he projected about half was gone.\n\n\"There's a few blocks that are just nothing,\" said Penner.\n\nAs the situation in the Town of Jasper worsened on Wednesday night, wildland fire crews and any other personnel without self-contained breathing apparatuses had to evacuate, at which time more structural firefighters moved in. The structural firefighters from municipalities across the province were deployed within the townsite to try to preserve as much of the community as possible, including critical infrastructure.", {"uri": "8243663977", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "20:35:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T20:35:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T20:34:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "url": "https://lethbridgenewsnow.com/2024/07/25/now-lost-jasper-fire-torching-cherished-memories-along-with-forests/", "title": "\"Now lost\": Jasper fire torching cherished memories along with forests", "body": "The dark of the lake and the clarity of the sky felt \"otherworldly,\" she said.\n\n\"You could see all the stars above. It felt really big.\n\n\"One of my friends gave her child the name Jasper.\"\n\nA decade ago, Kelley Ware was living in Prince George, B.C., and her now-husband was in Edmonton. Every few weeks, they'd meet in Jasper.\n\n\"It was completely fundamental to building our relationship. My husband has a tattoo of Pyramid Mountain.\"\n\nFor Janet Millar, the memories go back generations.\n\nHer great-grandfather was on a roadbuilding crew in Jasper in 1948 when he noticed that lots were going up for sale around Lake Edith. He and his wife walked around it, chose their favourite spot and the next year built the cabin that has been in the family ever since.\n\n\"It's the smell of an old log cabin that has had a lot of bacon and pancakes and syrup served in it. It's the sight of old furniture that no one can bear to part with,\" she said.\n\n\"Everyone in my family and all sorts of friends have their own particular thing they like best. There's so much I like about it that I can't bear to part with.\"\n\nSocial media was awash Thursday with memories of Jasper proposals, weddings and honeymoons. But the town is steeped in memory of all kinds.\n\nThere's the generations of skiiers who have partied in the Whistle Stop pub or Athabasca Hotel, known locally as the Atha-B and a fixture since 1929. The families who carbed up for the day's adventures at Smitty's. The holidayers from around the world who met and gabbed in hotel hot tubs.\n\nThe worshippers at the gracious Anglican church of St. Mary and St. George, who have gathered since 1928 to praise God in the midst of some of His finest handiwork.\n\nThe classic fieldstone headquarters of Parks Canada, across the street from where travellers on Via Rail's Rocky Mountaineer disembarked to gape at the vista. The cheeky Fiberglas statue of Jasper the Friendly Bear, rubbed shiny since the '60s by the hands of children.\n\nThe roadside greeter elk casually grazing, charming visitors turning off Hwy 16 into town.\n\nThe great and famous, too, are part of Jasper's memory.\n\nFilm star Marilyn Monroe, in town with co-star Robert Mitchum to film the 1954 western \"River of No Return,\" was famously escorted from the dining room of the Jasper Park Lodge for inappropriate dress. That same year saw the release of \"The Far Country,\" for which the Lodge hosted Jimmy Stewart.\n\nBing Crosby was by in 1946 to film \"The Emperor Waltz\" and returned regularly to golf on the Lodge's renowned course. Anthony Hopkins and John Travolta have vacationed there.\n\nRoyalty first came to visit in 1939 when King George VI and Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, stayed at the Jasper Park Lodge's Outlook Cabin. Their daughter, Queen Elizabeth II, stayed there with her husband Prince Phillip in 2005.\n\nBut Jasper's memories are not primarily of glitz and bling. It's an everyone kind of place.\n\n\"Our family had a dock that was always painted yellow,\" said Millar.\n\n\"All of us remember jumping off that dock and watching people come out from town and using it. That was always really special. It was heartwarming for us to see people enjoying the dock.\"\n\nWare remembers the fellowship.\n\n\"Striking up conversations with people and having an hour-long chat. Making friends with the bartenders. And just really feeling like you belonged.\"\n\nThursday morning, Parks Canada reported the fire remained out of control despite a small amount of rain overnight. Firefighting reinforcements had arrived to defend the town.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, workplaces, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures,\" the agency said in a statement.\n\n\"We appreciate your patience and the community of people who have come together to support the people of Jasper and Parks Canada family.\"\n\nThis report by The Canadian Press was first published July 25, 2024.", "source": {"uri": "lethbridgenewsnow.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8243771239", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:41:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:41:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:40:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4196078479290009, "url": "https://edmontonsun.com/opinion/columnists/gunter-jasper-blaze-exposes-possible-flaws-in-parks-canada-wildfire-strategy", "title": "GUNTER: Jasper blaze exposes possible flaws in Parks Canada wildfire strategy", "body": "The problem is the reverse: Blame the feds for being to slow to ask Alberta to become part of its integrated firefighting efforts inside Jasper National Park, where Parks Canada is in charge.\n\nParks Canada lacks the technology and experience to fight a fire a night, meaning as two wildfires approached the resort town, efforts to control or at least divert them ceased in the dark. But Alberta has night-fighting capability.\n\nAlberta also has the equipment and expertise to throw up giant walls of water in front of giant walls of flame (the fire approaching Jasper at times reach 100 metres high). Parks Canada doesn't, and didn't ask for Alberta's help.\n\nMostly, though, it's fair to blame Parks Canada for ignoring years of warnings that thousands of hectares of forest in the park had become a \"powder keg\" that, when ignited, would lead to a \"catastrophic\" wildfire. For more than a decade, Parks Canada has allowed a pine beetle infestation to kill hundreds of thousands of trees, then left dead trees standing to become drier and more fire-prone every year.", {"uri": "8243433089", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "16:58:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T16:58:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T16:58:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://calgary.citynews.ca/2024/07/25/edmonton-fire-sent-to-jasper/", "title": "Edmonton fire crews to help in Jasper | CityNews Calgary", "body": "As a wildfire roars into the townsite of Jasper, the City of Edmonton is deploying Edmonton Fire Rescue Services resources and equipment to support the ongoing efforts.\n\nLate on Wednesday night, a number of human resources, equipment and supplies arrived in town to support structural firefighting efforts, officials said in a news release.\n\nRELATED: 'Significant loss' in Jasper townsite as firefighters work to protect critical infrastructure\n\nThese include: two type one engines with four staff on each, one platform aerial apparatus with four staff, one Tahoe with a District Chief, one service truck with a mechanic, one pick-up trailer with spare equipment, logistics supplies, PPE, and cots for EFRS members and 50 cots for Emergency Social Services.\n\nEddie Robar, Interim City Manager said, \"Our hearts are with the community of Jasper as they face this devastating evening. We are here to offer our support during this difficult time.\"\n\nThe City of Edmonton continues to welcome evacuees at Kennedale Site. The evacuation centre will provide all immediate needs for evacuees including coordination of lodging and funding for food, water, clothing and hygiene items, pet daycare, and health care. Evacuees can bring their pets and are encouraged not to leave animals in vehicles due to the extreme weather conditions.\n\nThe City of Edmonton is among the many municipalities sending structure fire crews, Strathcona County, Sherwood Park, and Woodlands County have also sent emergency services assistance.\n\nWoodlands County posted on Facebook that four crew members, Engine 31, and a command unit Or sign-in if you have an account.\n\nTwo fires near Jasper converged on the town site Wednesday evening, leaving some structures damaged and reducing air quality to the point some emergency crews had to flee the scene.\n\nOn social media, Parks Canada called Wednesday \"an exceptionally difficult day for Jasperites, incident personnel and everyone who loves Jasper.\"\n\nIt acknowledged that \"significant loss\" had occurred in the townsite but was not confirming which structures had been damaged or the extent of that damage.\n\n\"Due to the ongoing fire conditions and our focus on the response effort, it is impossible to share information about specific locations and the extent of damage at this time. As you can understand, the accuracy of this information is critical because it has a direct impact on members of the community,\" Parks Canada said in a statement early Thursday.\n\n\"While we understand people are desperate to know about the status of our community, homes, work places, businesses, and cherished places we will need some time to stabilize this incident as we access and assess structures.\"\n\nVideo posted to social media from within the townsite showed many homes burnt to their foundations, with scorched cars lining area streets.", "source": {"uri": "edmontonjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Edmonton Journal"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jasper,_Alberta", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Jasper, Alberta"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Jasper, Alberta"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Canada"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parks_Canada", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Parks Canada"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_pollution", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Air pollution"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Social media"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Lifestyle_Choices", "label": "dmoz/Society/Lifestyle Choices", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Advice/Email_Advice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Advice/Email Advice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Survivalism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Survivalism", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://smartcdn.gprod.postmedia.digital/edmontonjournal/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/jasper-fire-0188.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9760758", "eventUri": "eng-9760758", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.1294117647058823, "wgt": 106, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8243778161", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "22:51:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T22:51:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T22:50:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4117647111415863, "url": "https://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/2024/07/25/wildfire-horror-real-for-many-communities-not-just-historic-resort-towns", "title": "Opinion: Wildfire horror real for many Manitoba communities, not just Alberta resort towns", "body": "I agree to the Terms and Conditions, Cookie and Privacy Policies, and CASL agreement.\n\nI'm willing to bet that by the time you read this, you will have heard about the devastating wildfires raging through Jasper, Alberta, and seen images of the devastation.\n\nMandatory evacuation orders were issued Monday to the nearly 25,000 residents and tourists inhabiting the town in Jasper National Park.\n\nDozens of homes and businesses -- including the iconic Maligne Lodge -- were engulfed in flames Wednesday night.\n\nAlberta Premier Danielle Smith held an emotional news conference Thursday to report that as many as half of the buildings in the treasured Rocky Mountain resort community had been burned.\n\nPrime Minister Justin Trudeau approved emergency federal assistance for the province, deployed the military to assist in fighting the fire and evacuations and posted on X: \"Alberta, we're with you.\"\n\nA wildfire in one of the country's most popular tourist destinations is, of course, worth all of the attention.\n\nThe 890,000-barrel-per-day Trans Mountain Pipeline, which runs from Edmonton to Vancouver, passes close to the town, but is, so far, continuing to operate safely, officials said.\n\nAs of Thursday, 54 of the 176 active wildfires in Alberta were classified as \"out of control.\"\n\nSix combined to become one huge blaze last weekend, forcing the evacuation of the 5,200 residents of Little Red River Cree Nation, a group of three communities more than 500 kilometres north of Edmonton.\n\nNearly 100 structures burned in a similar situation last year.\n\n\"I never thought we would be doing this again,\" Little Red River Cree Nation Chief Conroy Sewepagaham said in a video posted to Facebook.\n\nAs of Tuesday, 3,600 fires had consumed 2.2 million hectares across Canada in 2024. Of that number, 950 were burning Tuesday.\n\nThere have been 153 wildfires in Manitoba so far this year, 53 of them currently active. The province's fire map indicates 10, most in the northwest, are \"out of control.\"\n\nThere's a large one about 35 kilometres north of Garden Hill First Nation. Two have joined to create a more-than-2,000-hectare blaze threatening Pukatawagan Cree Nation (also known as Mathias Colomb First Nation). Another is burning about 60 km northeast of Thompson, and two separate fires are closing in on Marcel Colomb First Nation, leading to this week's evacuation of elders, children and other vulnerable residents.\n\nThe communities have lived through the fear and danger before. Pukatawagan residents were forced to flee flames in July 2022. Marcel Colomb has been evacuated multiple times over the last decade.\n\nFirefighters, local leadership and Manitoba's fire protection program, along with plenty of rain, have so far ensured the communities haven't suffered significant damage this summer. Manitoba is down nearly 100 wildfires from last year at this time.\n\n\"I never thought we would be doing this again.\"\n\nBut the forecast over the next few days and into August is heat, in some cases potentially record-setting temperatures, which means there are likely going to be more evacuations of First Nations.\n\nResearch published in 2019 in the International Journal of Disaster Risk Reduction, reported 80 per cent of \"majority-Indigenous\" communities (First Nations and urban areas) are located in \"fire-prone\" regions.\n\nDue primarily to climate change -- resulting in more lightning and drier forests -- the number of wildfires is increasing overall. A massive heat wave this month in Alberta and B.C. undoubtedly contributed to the conditions that sparked the catastrophe in Jasper.\n\nResearch published this year by the Canadian Interagency Forest Fire Centre, the warming global climate is leading to hotter and more devastating fires. The area burned across the country last year was six times higher than the yearly average.\n\nMuch of the territory is First Nations. This week's evacuation of Marcel Colomb is likely just the beginning.\n\nIt's good when Canada acts after losses such as the one in Jasper. No doubt something will be done to ensure it doesn't happen again -- like the protection measures instituted after the terrible fires that destroyed Fort McMurray, Alta., in 2016.\n\nCommunities such as Little Red River Cree Nation or -- in Manitoba's case -- Garden Hill, Marcel Colomb and Pukatawagan are, perhaps, not viewed or valued in the same way Jasper is.", "source": {"uri":
